</ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Understanding_the_instruction">Understanding the instruction</span></h3>
<p>Take a look at the next (64bit) program:
</p>
<pre>1000;256  // addresses 000-127
32;446    // addresses 128-255
128;256   // addresses 256-383
</pre>
<p>The CPU starts executing at address 0, so it will flip the 1000th bit and will jump to address 256.<br/>
The CPU now executes the op 128;256, so it will flip the 128th bit (so, the 2nd op will be overridden to 33;446) and will jump again to address 256.<br/>
The CPU will get stuck in a self-loop here, as it jumps back to 256 forever.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_FlipJump_CPU">The FlipJump CPU</span></h2>
<p>The fj CPU has a built-in width, and starts executing from address 0.<br/>
It halts on a simple self-loop (jumps to itself, while not flipping itself).
</p><p>There are variants of the CPU, let's assume the simplest form:
</p>
<ul><li>The jump address is always w-aligned.</li>
<li>The operation doesn't flip bits in itself.</li></ul>
<p>Here is a 8bit-fj-cpu C emulator:
</p>
<pre>#define BAD_ALIGNMENT 1
#define SELF_FLIP 2
#define SUCCESS_FINISH 0

int fj8(u8* mem) {
    u8 ip = 0;

    while (true) {
        u8 f = mem[ip/8];
        u8 j = mem[ip/8+1]; 

        if (ip % 8)  
            return BAD_ALIGNMENT;
        if (f &gt;= ip &amp;&amp; f &lt; ip+16) 
            return SELF_FLIP;
        if (...) {
            // handle IO  (will be explained next).
        }
        if (ip == j) 
            return SUCCESS_FINISH; 

        mem[f/8] ^= 1&lt;&lt;(f%8);   // Flip
        ip = j;                 // Jump
    }
}
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Assembly_Language">The Assembly Language</span></h2>
<h4><span id="Declaring_constants_.26_labels"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Declaring_constants_&amp;_labels">Declaring constants &amp; labels</span></h4>
<pre>x = 6;
// The fj program starts with 1 predefined constant - w, which is defined with the address-width (word-width). 2^w is the memory size in bits.

label:
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax_sugar">Syntax sugar</span></h4>
<pre>F;J
 ;J  =&gt;  0;J                                                  - Just jump (it does flip the address 0).
F;   =&gt;  F;$     ($ is the address of the next instruction)   - Just flip.
 ;   =&gt;  0;$
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Flipping_a_whole_word">Flipping a whole word</span></h4>
<pre>wflip dst, val            - Assembles to multiple dst+i; ops (for 0&lt;=i&lt;w which the i'th bit is 1 on val).
// <i>wflip 128, 69</i> will be assembled to <i>128+0; 128+2; 128+6;</i> (actually, something equivalent, it's the assembler's choice).
wflip dst, val, jmp_addr  - Same as above, but jumps to <i>jmp_addr</i> at the end.

// The wflip op is promised to take 1 op-size in its local area (and if more ops are needed - they will be at padded spots and at the end of the current segment).
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Padding">Padding</span></h4>
<pre>pad n          // a special assembly-op that fills the current address with arbitrary fj ops, until the address is divisible by (n*dw)
label:         // label % (n*dw) is 0
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Macros">Macros</span></h4>
<pre>def macro_name param1, param2.. @ temp_label1, temp_label2.. &lt; globals.. &gt; externs.. {
    // macro body
}


// For example:

def not4 x {
    x;
    x+1;
    x+2;
    x+3;
}

def notnotjump x y jumper {
    x+y;jumper
}

def skip_bits jump_bits @ end_label {
    ;end_label + jump_bits
  end_label:
}

// if BLA1,BLA2 where not labeled as externs - a warning would come up.
def declarations &gt; BLA1, BLA2 {
    BLA1:
    ;
    BLA2:
}

// if C was not labeled as a global - a warning would come up.
def flipC &lt; C {
    C;
}

// Using macros
not4 100
notnotjump a, w, b
skip_bits 2*w
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Repetitions">Repetitions</span></h4>
<pre>rep(n, i) macro_name arg1, arg2, ..    // repeats the macro n times, each with i = [0, 1, .. n-1].
                                       // n is an expression and may contain constants and labels of previous addresses.

// For example, building not4 in a simpler way
def not x {
    x;
}
def not4 x {
    rep(4, i) not x+i
}
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Namespaces">Namespaces</span></h4>
<pre>ns namespace_name {
    // Any variables, labels, macro definitions declared here - will have the namespace prefix.
    // Access inner definitions with the "." prefix.
    ns nested_namespace {
        // Nested namespaces (to any level) are allowed!
        // Access nested_namespace definitions with the "." prefix, namespace_name definitions with the ".." prefix, 
        //  and so on (the number of leading dots, the number of namespaces to go upwards, inc. the current).
    }
    // A namespace can also contain code.
}
ns namespace_name {
    // You can append things to an already defined namespace!
}
// Access namespace_name definitions from outside with the "namespace_name." prefix

// For example:

ns my_ns {
    X = 7
}
ns my_ns {
    def foo dst {
        dst+.X;
    }
    ns inner_ns {
        Y = 8
        Z = .Y + ..X
        def inner_foo dst {
            ..foo dst+.Z
        }
    }
}

startup
my_ns.foo v
my_ns.inner_ns.inner_foo v
v + my_ns.inner_ns.Z + 2*my_ns.X;
loop: ;loop
v: var w, 446
</pre>
<h4><span id="Segments_.26_Reserve"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Segments_&amp;_Reserve">Segments &amp; Reserve</span></h4>
<pre>// some code
segment 0x10000    // The code below will start from address 0x10000
// some code

reserve 0x400      // Will reserve a spot for 0x400 0-bits. They will be filled by the running environment.
// The .fjm file (the assembled file) allows specifying segment-length &gt; data-length, and fills the remaining memory with zeros.
</pre>
<p>The end of the previous segment will be followed by the fj ops needed to complete that segment's wflip ops.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Assembly-time_expressions">Assembly-time expressions</span></h4>
<pre>Many mathematic and logic operations are allowed between numbers/constants/labels at assemble time:
temp + 2*(b-temp) - 13/4 ; temp &amp; 0x67 + 0b00110   
    // You can use the labels (will be resolved to numbers at assemble-time) and many operations to make the flip/jump addresses:
    //  Mathmatical:  +- */% ()  
    //  Logical:  &amp;|^  operations
    //  Shifts  &lt;&lt; &gt;&gt;
    //  C-like trinary operator  ?:
    //  Bit-width operator  #  (minimal number of bits needed to store this number.  #x == log2(x)+1).
    // Also you can use hexadecimal (0x) and binary (0b) numbers, and get the ascii value of chars ('A' == 0x41).
    // The value of a string is the number built of its bytes ("TomH" == 'T' + 256*'o' + 256^2 * 'm' + 256^3*'H')

temp:  ;
b:
c:

b+'A';b+0x41    // The flip and jump addresses are identical in this line.

c+('A' &gt; 'B' ? 1 : 'B');temp+(1&lt;&lt;(c-b))   // Is equivalent to c+0x42;temp+1
</pre>
<h2><span id="Memory_-_how_can_we_implement_variables.3F"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Memory_-_how_can_we_implement_variables?">Memory - how can we implement variables?</span></h2>
<p>A bit can be built using 1 fj operation. Specifically,  <i>;0</i>  or  <i>;dw</i> (defined in the standard library as 2*w).
</p><p>Here the magic happens. The FlipJump operation inherently can't read. It also can't write a specific value.
All it knows is to flip a bit, and then jump. but where to?
</p><p>The FlipJump hidden-power lies exactly in this delicate point. It can jump to an already flipped address.
In other words, it can execute an already modified code.<br/>
I based the main standard library functions, and the implementation of variables, on this exact point.
</p><p>Follow the next example to get the important understanding of this concept:
</p>
<pre>//Let's assume a 64 bits CPU, and that the label branch_target is evaluated to 0x400 (1&lt;&lt;10).
// Follow the {0}, {1}, ... {9} numbers to follow the execution flow.

    ;code_start // {0} code starts at address 0
    ;
    ;
    ;
code_start:

// {1} We can flip the address in the bit_a opcode by the branch_target address (0x400):
    bit_a+64+10;    // The +64 is to get to the 2nd word (the address word), and the +10 is to flip the bit corrospondig to 0x400.
// {2} If we jump to execute the opcode in bit_a, it will flip address 0 and then jump to the address written in it. 
//      So it will jump to 0x400, which is branch_target.
    ;bit_a

try_second_bit:
// {5} We will flip the address in the bit_b opcode by 0x400:
    bit_b+64+10;
// {6} Now we jump to execute the opcode in bit_b. It will flip address 0 and then jump to the address written in it. 
//      So it will jump to 0x480 (was 0x80 from the start), which is second_branch_target.
    ;bit_b


branch_target:          // This is address 0x400
    // {4} Now we get here, and then continue jumping.
    ;try_second_bit
second_branch_target:   // This is address 0x480
    // {8} Another jump.
    ;end


end:  ;end  // {9} The code will get here and then finish (self-loop).

bit_a:  ;0      // {3} Jump to branch_target
bit_b:  ;0x80   // {7} Jump to second_branch_target
</pre>
<p><br/>
The same flip/jump combination on bit_a/bit_b did different things.<br/>
We successfully jumped to different addresses depends on the value of the said bits.<br/>
In that way, we can <b>read</b> the value of such a bit-variable.<br/>
Yep. By jumping to different addresses (based on the bit-variable's value) - we indeed, <b>read</b> its value.
</p><p>In that same way, we can also implement hexadecimal variables in a single op (implemented in hexlib.fj).<br/>
Instead of two options (<b>;0</b>  or  <b>;dw</b>) we will have a bit more (0dw,1dw,2dw,3dw,...,15dw / 0dw,1dw,2dw,3dw,...,9dw).
</p><p>This is very nice, but it only worked because we knew the address of branch_target in advance.
We usually don't, but it is resolved during assemble time.
</p><p>That's why the assembly language provides the wflip operation.
</p>
<pre>wflip bit_a+w, branch_target    // This will work for every branch_target address, not just 0x400.
</pre>
<p>Of course, it is important to make the same wflip again just after the jump to bit_a.<br/>
We assume that the jump-part of these bit-instructions is 0 / dw, so after each wflip we must wflip again, to set it back again to 0 / dw.
</p>
<h2><span id="Input_.2F_Output"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Input_/_Output">Input / Output</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Output">Output</span></h3>
<p>Output is done by flipping a special address. 
</p>
<pre>2*w;    =&gt; will output 0
2*w+1;  =&gt; will output 1
</pre>
<p>To output an ASCII character - output the 8 bits of it in lsb-first order.
</p><p>For example, the next code will output 'T' (0b01010100):
</p>
<pre>2*w;
2*w;
2*w+1;
2*w;
2*w+1;
2*w;
2*w+1;
2*w;
</pre>
<p>The standard library defines a simpler output macro:
</p>
<pre>dw = 2*w
def output_bit bit {
    dw+bit;
}
def output_char char {
    rep(8, i) output_bit (char&gt;&gt;i)&amp;1
}

// Output becomes easy as:
output_char 'T'
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Input">Input</span></h3>
<p>The next input bit is always loaded at address 3w+#w (3w+log(w)+1), reloaded with each time it's read.
</p><p>You can use this bit by jumping to a flip-jump opcode that contains it.
The best way is to jump to <i>;dw</i>.
</p><p>In that way - this bit will reflect either 0x0 or 0x80 in the jump-part of the flip-jump op.<br/>
If we  <i>wflip dw+w, some_padded_address, dw</i>  - the dw-flip-jump-op will make a jump to  <i>some_padded_address</i> / <i>some_padded_address+0x80</i>, based on the input, just like in the Memory section.
</p>
<pre>// For example:

    wflip dw+w, padded_address, dw  // we assume dw+w is 0.

pad 2    // special assembly op, used to assure that padded_address is divisible by 2*dw.
padded_address:
    ;handle_0
    ;handle_1

handle_0:
    wflip dw+w, padded_address  // we make sure dw+w stays 0.
    // do some 0's stuff

handle_1:
    wflip dw+w, padded_address  // we make sure dw+w stays 0.
    // do some 1's stuff
</pre>
<p><br/>
The <i>iolib.fj</i> standard library defines macros to make IO as simple as possible.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Standard_Library">The Standard Library</span></h2>
<p>I Implemented the standard library for the language, found in the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/tree/main/flipjump/stl/README.md" rel="nofollow">Github STL Page</a><br/>
It features some constants (runlib): 
</p>
<pre>* dw   = 2 * w    // double word size
* dbit = w + #w   // bit-distance from variable start to bit value: w + double-w-width (log2(2w))
</pre>
<p>But mostly, it features useful macros, starting with the basic (runlib):
</p>
<pre>* startup       - the first macro in your code - creates the IO label and handles the initial flow.
* startup_and_init_all - replaces "startup", it also initializes anything the stl needs.
* fj f, j       - a basic macro for the FlipJump op - f;j
* wflip_macro   - a basic macro for the WFlip op - wflip dst, val (, jmp_addr)
* comp_if expr, l0, l1      - jump to l1 if expr!=0 else jumps to l0
* comp_flip_if bit, expr    - flip <i>bit</i> if expr!=0
* skip          - skip the next instruction.
* loop          - self-loop (finish executing right here).
* output_bit        - for outputting a constant bit.
* output_char ascii - output an 8-bit constant, like <i>output_char 'T'</i>.
* output str        - output a string constant, like <i>output "Hello, World!"</i>.
</pre>
<p><br/>
The standard library uses 3 main namespaces, and no macro is declared outside these namespaces. The *bit*, *hex* and *stl* namespaces.<br/>
Each namespace offers many macros related to that variable type.<br/>
For example, the stl offers the bit.mov macro for moving bit-variables, and hex.mov for moving hex-variables.<br/>
The stl uses the stl._, bit._, hex._ namespaces for its inner-macros, used only by the stl.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Note_that_the_hex_macros_are_faster_than_the_bit_macros.">Note that the <i>hex</i> macros are faster than the <i>bit</i> macros.</span></h4>
<p>The list of macros might be partial. Check the list in <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/tree/main/flipjump/stl/README.md" rel="nofollow">The stl Github Page</a>, and the stl files themselves too.
</p><p>basic macros (defined under bit and hex namespaces):
</p>
<pre>* if x, l0, l1  - reads the variable <i>x</i>, and jumps to l0/l1 based on its value (0/not0).
* xor dst, src  - flips the <i>dst</i> variable by the <i>src</i> value.
* mov dst, src  - copies the value of <i>src</i> into <i>dst</i>.
</pre>
<p>Mathematical/Logical macros (under the bit namespace, under stl/bit/ - also similar macros can be found under the hex namespace):
</p>
<pre>* add n, dst, src    - adds the <i>n</i>-bit number (<i>n</i> consequative bit-variables) <i>src</i> to <i>dst</i>.
* sub / inc / dec / neg
* xor / and / or  / not
* shr / shl / ror / rol
</pre>
<p>Andvance mathematical macros:
</p>
<pre>// The bit namespace (bit/mul.fj, bit/div.fj):
* mul10 n, x         - multiply the <i>n</i>-bit <i>x</i> by 10.
* div10 n, x         - divide the <i>n</i>-bit <i>x</i> by 10.
* mul n, dst, src    - multiply the n-bit <i>src</i> by <i>dst</i>, and save the result in <i>dst</i>.
* div n, a, b, q, r  - divide the n-bit <i>a</i> by <i>b</i>, save the result in <i>q</i>, and the remainder in <i>r</i>.
* idiv n, a, b, q, r - same as div but for signed numbers.
* div_loop / idiv_loop / imul_loop  - the <i>loops</i> implementations are much smaller in size, but a bit slower.
// The hex namespace ([x] is the hex-width (1/4 of the bit-width) of the number) (hex/mul.fj, hex/div.fj):
* add_mul n, res, a, b   - res[n] += a[n] * b[1]
* mul n, res, a, b       - res[n]  = a[n] * b[n]
* div n, nb, q, r, a, b, div0  - divides the unsigned a[:n] by b[:bn], save the result in q[:n] and the remainder in q[:bn] (jump to div0 if b[:bn]==0).
* idiv n, nb, q, r, a, b, div0  - same as div but for signed numbers.
</pre>
<p>Memory/Comparison (under the bit namespace):
</p>
<pre>* vec n, value             - initialize a <i>n</i>-bit number with value <i>value</i>. 
* zero n, x                - zero's <i>n</i>-bit-variables, starting from <i>x</i>.
* mov n, dst, src          - copies the <i>n</i>-bits <i>src</i> into <i>dst</i>.
* swap n, a, b             - swaps the <i>n</i>-bits <i>a</i> with <i>b</i>.
* xor_zero n, dst, src     - xor's the n-bits <i>dst</i> by <i>src</i>, then zero's the n-bits <i>src</i>.
* cmp n, a, b, lt, eq, gt  - compares the <i>n</i>-bits <i>a</i>/<i>b</i>, and jump to right address (<i>lt</i> for <i>a</i>&lt;<i>b</i>, <i>eq</i> for <i>a</i>==<i>b</i>, <i>gt</i> for <i>a</i>&gt;<i>b</i>).
* if n, x, l0, l1          - jumps to <i>l0</i> if the <i>n</i>-bit <i>x</i> is just zeros, and to <i>l1</i> otherwise.
</pre>
<p>IO for variables (input/output, under the bit/hex namespace):
</p>
<pre>* input dst           - read a char (8-bits) from input, and save it in <i>dst</i>.
* output x            - output the bits in that variable (1 for bit, 4 for hex/dec).
* print x             - output a char (8-bits) from the 8-bit variable <i>x</i>.
* print_as_digit x    - output an ascii representation of this variable.
* print_str n, x      - output n characters starting from x, stops if reaches a null byte ('\0'). 
</pre>
<p><b>Hexadecimal math/logic macros</b> (under the hex namespace - these macros are usually faster than the bit ones):
</p>
<pre>* hex.init (required exactly once to use many of the macros below)
* vec, xor, zero, xor_zero, mov, swap, xor_by, set
* not, or, and, shl_bit, shr_bit, shl_hex, shr_hex, count_bits
* inc, dec, neg, add, sub
* if_flags, if, cmp, sign
* print_int, print_uint
</pre>
<p>Casting and formated-printing (under casting, output, ...):
</p>
<pre>* bit2hex, hex2bit
* bin2ascii / dec2ascii / hex2ascii
* ascii2bin / ascii2dec / ascii2hex
* print_hex_int / print_hex_uint
* print_dec_int / print_dec_uint
</pre>
<p>Pointers, Stack, and Functions -  The hex/pointers/ folder - handles w/4-hex variables as pointers to the memory:
</p>
<pre>* ptr_init        - declare exactly once to use the pointers macros (it's declared in the startup_and_init_all macro).
* call address    - calls a function (pushes the return address to the stack, takes only 1 bit-variable space).
* return          - returns from a function (pops the return address from the stack, and jumps to it).
* fcall / fret    - fast call / fast return (with a constant place to store the return address, other than a stack).
* ptr_inc / ptr_dec / ptr_add / ptr_sub - increase/decrease the pointer.
* stack n         - initializes a stack with <i>n</i> bit-variables.
* sp_inc / sp_dec / sp_add / sp_sub     - increase/decrease the stack pointer.
* push_ret_address / pop_ret_address    - push/pop the return value to/from the stack.
* {push/pop}_{hex/byte} - push or pop a single hex/byte to/from the stack, as a single stack-cell.
* push [n] / pop [n]  - push and pop variables from the stack
</pre>
<p>More pointer macros (under the bit/hex namespaces) - handles w-bit variables / w/4-hex variables as pointers to the memory:
</p>
<pre>* ptr_jmp  ptr    - ;*ptr
* ptr_flip ptr    - *ptr;
* xor_to_ptr / xor_from_ptr   - like ``xor *ptr, var`` / ``xor var, *ptr``. also with {n}.
* ptr_flip_by ptr, value  - wflip *ptr, value
</pre>
<p>Read/Write whole hex/byte from a w/4-hex pointer (read_pointers/write_pointers):
</p>
<pre>* read_hex {n}
* read_byte {n}
* write_hex {n}
* write_byte {n}
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lookup_Tables">Lookup Tables</span></h3>
<p>The hex/dec macros are based on "lookup-tables" (take a loop at hex.exact_xor in stl/hexlib.fj).<br/>
Some of these tables are small enough to be inside a macro definition, but others are just too big (hex.or.init in stl/hexlib.fj for example).<br/>
The latter are initialized by using the hex.init / dec.init macros.<br/>
The idea is simple. Based on the parameters - jump to the right entry in the table, which will set the result variable to hold the right value.
</p><p>The use-flow of the big-tables is as follows: 
</p>
<pre>1. Set the jump part of a fj op (dst) to the start of the padded table, flipped by the parameters' values, to reflect the right table-entry.
   For example - flip dst+dbit+{0-3} by the first hex-param, and flip dst+dbit+{4-7} by the second hex-param.
2. Save the return address in another op (ret), and jump to dst.
3. The table-entry will cause bits to flip, such that a result variable (res) will have the right result.
4. Set the flipped dst-bits back to 0, and jump to ret.
(small tables are the same, except that the return address is known in advance - so no need in ret).
</pre>
<p>The big-tables are initialized once, and can be used anytime and anywhere - it's a way to save up some memory.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_.fjm_Format">The .fjm Format</span></h2>
<p>The FlipJump executable file is saved as a .fjm file. 
It holds all the memory segments and data. In some versions, the data is compressed.
</p><p>The format itself can be found under <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/flipjump/fjm/fjm_consts.py" rel="nofollow">fjm_consts.py</a>.
</p><p>The .fjm file currently has 4 versions:
</p>
<pre>0. The basic version
1. The normal version (more configurable than the basic version)
2. The relative-jumps version (good for further compression)
3. The compressed version
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello_World">Hello World</span></h2>
<p>Using the stl (<a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/programs/print_tests/hello_world.fj" rel="nofollow">source</a>):
</p>
<pre>startup
output "Hello, World!\n(:"
loop
</pre>
<figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File/Frame"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Hello_World_GIF.gif"><img alt="Hello World in FlipJump" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="360" src="/w/images/b/b6/Hello_World_GIF.gif" width="1520"/></a><figcaption>Hello World</figcaption></figure>
<p>Using nothing (<a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/programs/print_tests/hello_no-stl.fj" rel="nofollow">source</a>):
</p>
<pre>def startup @ code_start &gt; IO {
    ;code_start
  IO:
    ;0
  code_start:
}


def output_bit bit &lt; IO {
    IO + bit;
}
def output_char ascii {
    rep(8, i) output_bit ((ascii&gt;&gt;i)&amp;1)
}

def end_loop @ loop_label {
    loop_label:
    ;loop_label
}

    startup
   
    output_char 'H'
    output_char 'e'
    output_char 'l'
    output_char 'l'
    output_char 'o'
    output_char ','
    output_char ' '
    output_char 'W'
    output_char  'o'
    output_char 'r'
    output_char 'l'
    output_char 'd'
    output_char '!'
    
    end_loop
</pre>
<h2><span id="How_To_Run.3F"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="How_To_Run?">How To Run?</span></h2>
<h3><span id="For_a_more_extensive_guide.2C_see_the_Github_README.md."></span><span class="mw-headline" id="For_a_more_extensive_guide,_see_the_Github_README.md.">For a more extensive guide, see the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/tree/main#how-to-download" rel="nofollow">Github README.md</a>.</span></h3>
<p>Download flipjump:
</p>
<pre>pip install flipjump
</pre>
<p>Assemble and Run your programs with the `fj` command line tool:
</p>
<pre>&gt;&gt;&gt; fj hello.fj
Hello, World!
</pre>
<p>You can also assemble and run separately:
</p>
<pre>fj --asm
fj --run
</pre>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Calc_asm.jpg"><img alt="calc.fj assembly" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="49" src="/w/images/thumb/0/0a/Calc_asm.jpg/300px-Calc_asm.jpg" srcset="/w/images/thumb/0/0a/Calc_asm.jpg/450px-Calc_asm.jpg 1.5x, /w/images/thumb/0/0a/Calc_asm.jpg/600px-Calc_asm.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a><figcaption>Assembly</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Calc_run.jpg"><img alt="Run the compiled calculator" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="55" src="/w/images/thumb/1/19/Calc_run.jpg/300px-Calc_run.jpg" srcset="/w/images/thumb/1/19/Calc_run.jpg/450px-Calc_run.jpg 1.5x, /w/images/thumb/1/19/Calc_run.jpg/600px-Calc_run.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a><figcaption>Run</figcaption></figure>
<p>You can also debug (single step, read memory, read flipjump stl variables, stop after 10/100 ops, continue):
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Breakpoint.jpg"><img alt="Debugging in flipjump. Placing breakpoints." class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="159" src="/w/images/thumb/8/8c/Breakpoint.jpg/300px-Breakpoint.jpg" srcset="/w/images/thumb/8/8c/Breakpoint.jpg/450px-Breakpoint.jpg 1.5x, /w/images/thumb/8/8c/Breakpoint.jpg/600px-Breakpoint.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a><figcaption>Debugging</figcaption></figure>
<p>And test:
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Frame"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Pytest.gif"><img alt="Running pytest --regular" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="351" src="/w/images/7/7a/Pytest.gif" width="1488"/></a><figcaption>Running tests</figcaption></figure>
<p>Current list of FlipJump assemblers:
</p>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump" rel="nofollow">original assembler</a> (src/fja.py)</li></ul>
<p>Current list of FlipJump interpreters:
</p>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump" rel="nofollow">original python interpreter</a> (src/fj.py)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/fji-cpp" rel="nofollow">original cpp interpreter</a> (fji.cpp)</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="The_FlipJump_Power">The FlipJump Power</span></h2>
<p>FlipJump is the product of searching for the simplest / most-primitive / weakest instruction set, and see what can be done with this power.
</p><p>It seems like a lot can be done!
</p><p>There is a <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/c2fj" rel="nofollow">C to FlipJump compiler</a>; An example program:
</p>
<pre>int main() {
    printf("Calculate primes up to: ");
    int max_number;
    scanf("%d", &amp;max_number);
    
    ...
    
    for (int p = 3; p &lt;= max_number; p += 2) {
        if (non_prime[p] == false) {
            for (int i = p*p; i &lt;= max_number; i += p) {
                non_prime[i] = true;
            }
            printf("%d\n", p);
        }
    }
    
    return 0;
}
</pre>
<p>Gets compiled to FlipJump, and run:
</p>
<pre>Calculate primes up to: 20
2
3
5
7
11
13
17
19
Program exited with exit code 0x0.
</pre>
<p>More programs:
</p><p>A screen recording that was taken from the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/tests/primes.fj" rel="nofollow">primes.fj</a> program, finding and printing all the primes up to 100:
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Frame"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Prime_sieve.gif"><img alt="Prime sieve written in flipjump, prints the primes up to 100 in less then 2 seconds" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="1080" src="/w/images/1/19/Prime_sieve.gif" width="1920"/></a><figcaption>Prime Sieve</figcaption></figure>
<p>Note that this program was fully written in flipjump.
</p><p>A screen recording that was taken from the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/tests/calc.fj" rel="nofollow">calc.fj</a> program, making multiple mathematical calculations, and printing integers:
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Frame"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Calc-gif.gif"><img alt="Calculations using only FlipJump" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="796" src="/w/images/b/b7/Calc-gif.gif" width="1488"/></a><figcaption>Calculator</figcaption></figure>
<p>A screen recording that was taken from the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/tests/simple_math_checks/series_sum.fj" rel="nofollow">series_sum.fj</a> program, calculating an arithmetic series:
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Frame"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Series_sum.gif"><img alt="Caculates an arithmetic series" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="1036" src="/w/images/9/96/Series_sum.gif" width="1584"/></a><figcaption>Arithmetic Series</figcaption></figure>
<p>A screenshot from the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/tests/func.fj" rel="nofollow">func.fj</a> source, making a function call:
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-none" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:Func4.jpg"><img alt="Function call using the FlipJump Standard Library" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="416" src="/w/images/thumb/4/44/Func4.jpg/300px-Func4.jpg" srcset="/w/images/thumb/4/44/Func4.jpg/450px-Func4.jpg 1.5x, /w/images/thumb/4/44/Func4.jpg/600px-Func4.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a><figcaption>Function Call</figcaption></figure>
<p>A quine (a program that prints itself) using only <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump/blob/main/programs/quine16.fj" rel="nofollow">99 ops of code + 448 ops of data, fully documented</a>
</p><p>The compiler from a RiscV 32bit machine code to fj 64bit code is <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/c2fj" rel="nofollow">Completed!</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Comparison_to_similar_languages">Comparison to similar languages</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="BitBitJump"><a href="/wiki/BitBitJump" title="BitBitJump">BitBitJump</a></span></h3>
<p>BitBitJump is the closest language to FlipJump, with its <b>unconditional</b> jump.
</p><p>Yet, FlipJump Is more basic/primitive than BitBitJump. 
</p>
<ul><li>BitBitJump can copy a bit from one general address to another.</li>
<li>BitBitJump can write zeros and ones directly to an address, without knowing the old value.</li></ul>
<p>Both can't be trivially done with FlipJump, and no implementation ever succeeded in doing that (try to wonder about how to implement it..).<br/>
Flipping a general memory bit in BitBitJump is <a class="external text" href="https://esolangs.org/wiki/BitBitJump#Macro_Library" rel="nofollow">possible</a>, and jumping unconditionally is possible as well (with 0 0 jump_address).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="TOGA_computer"><a href="/wiki/TOGA_computer" title="TOGA computer">TOGA computer</a></span></h3>
<p>Toga is close to FlipJump as well. It flips a bit but then has a conditional jump.
</p><p>FlipJump is clearly more basic/primitive than Toga, as the conditional jump has the power of reading any bit in memory (and so is writing). Also, an unconditional jump can be easily implemented in TOGA using 2 instructions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<p>- <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tomhea/flip-jump" rel="nofollow">Github - Macro Assembler and Standard Library, and 2 interpreters</a>
</p><p>- <a class="external text" href="https://pypi.org/project/flipjump/" rel="nofollow">The flipjump Python Library</a>
</p><p>- <a class="external text" href="https://pypi.org/project/bf2fj/" rel="nofollow">Compile brainfuck to flipjump</a>
</p><p>- <a class="external text" href="https://pypi.org/project/c2fj/" rel="nofollow">Compile C to flipjump</a>
</p>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Flooding Waterfall Model</b> is a modification of <a href="/wiki/The_Waterfall_Model" title="The Waterfall Model">The Waterfall Model</a>, first observed by Deedlit11 and with a name coined by <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=User:FortyTwo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="User:FortyTwo (page does not exist)">User:FortyTwo</a>. It was inspired by an attempt to implement a <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> language in <i>Magic: the Gathering</i>: the existing constructions for implementing The Waterfall Model make use of the card "Dralnu's Crusade", but there are reasons to want a Turing-completeness construction that does not require that card, and if it is removed, the constructions for implementing The Waterfall Model end up implementing Flooding Waterfall Model instead.
</p><p>The primary difference between the original language and its flooding version is that when a flooding waterclock zeroes, instead of its zeroing trigger running once, it runs a number of times equal to the number of cycles since the waterclock was last zero.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Semantics"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Semantics</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Implementation_in_Magic:_the_Gathering"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Implementation in <i>Magic: the Gathering</i></span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Variant:_Staggered_Flooding_Waterfall_Model"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Variant: Staggered Flooding Waterfall Model</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Semantics">Semantics</span></h2>
<p>A Flooding Waterfall Model program consists of a number of <i>waterclocks</i>. Each waterclock has a <i>zeroing trigger</i>, which is a map from waterclocks to integers (i.e. for each waterclock, there is an integer that specifies that waterclock's relationship to each other waterclock); the zeroing triggers stay unchanged for the duration of the program. A running program also stores some numbers that represent the current state of each waterclock, and which vary over the lifetime of the program: each waterclock has an <i>age</i> and a <i>value</i>, which are both non-negative integers that could be arbitrarily large.
</p><p>Program execution consists of alternating between the following two steps:
</p>
<dl><dt>Steady decrement</dt>
<dd>For each waterclock whose value is not zero, that waterclock's age is increased and its value is decreased. (The age and value of waterclocks with zero value remain unchanged.)</dd>
<dt>Zeroing trigger</dt>
<dd>For each waterclock <i>X</i> whose value fell from 1 to 0 in the previous step, the value of each waterclock <i>Y</i> is increased by (the value <i>Y</i> is mapped to by <i>X</i>'s zeroing trigger) × (<i>X</i>'s age). Then the ages of all such waterclocks <i>X</i> are reset to 0.</dd></dl>
<p>(Note that a side effect of these rules is that a waterclock that has zero value will, except while its zeroing trigger is being processed, also have zero age.)
</p><p>Unlike with The Waterfall Model, it is not <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a> for two or more waterclocks to zero as a consequence of the same steady decrement; rather, all of their zeroing triggers run simultaneously. (This undefined behaviour is trivial to avoid in The Waterfall Model by multiplying all values and zeroing triggers by a constant and then using small changes to values to break the tie, but the same solution does not work for Flooding Waterfall Model, and it is much simpler to define the case explicitly.)
</p><p>Another case that is undefined in The Waterfall Model but defined in Flooding Waterfall Model is the case of a waterclock's value remaining at zero for multiple consecutive cycles: in Flooding Waterfall Model, the waterclock's age will remain at zero in that situation, and thus its zeroing trigger will do nothing (because it is multiplied by zero).
</p><p>Unlike with The Waterfall Model, implementations may well not be able to handle all possible age/value combinations at program startup. Implementations must be able to start up in a state where all the waterclocks have arbitrary specified values (including states where some of those values are 0), but need not be able to handle nonzero ages.
</p><p>Halting is handled using a <i>halt waterclock</i>, designated by the program; if the value of this waterclock ever falls to 0, the program exits. (The age of the halt waterclock conceptually exists, but is irrelevant.) A waterclock is generally specified to an interpreter as being a halt waterclock via specifying an all-zero zeroing trigger, which is not otherwise useful.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementation_in_Magic:_the_Gathering">Implementation in <i>Magic: the Gathering</i></span></h2>
<p>jfb1337 and FortyTwo discovered that Flooding Waterfall Model can be implemented in <i>Magic: the Gathering</i> using the following three components, producing an extremely simple construction to prove <i>Magic</i> <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>:
</p>
<ol><li>"Coat of Arms", a card which gives each creature +1 toughness (also +1 power, but that is not relevant to the proof) for each other creature with the same creature type;</li>
<li>A sufficiently large number of permanents with triggered abilities that create a token creature of a specified creature type whenever a creature of a different specified creature type dies (e.g. many token copies of "Bishop of Wings", with "Artificial Evolution" used to change which creature types are listed in its text box and thus to allow the creature types to be specified);</li>
<li>Something that repeatedly damages all creatures until a particular creature dies (typically "Arcbond" plus something that causes it to repeat, such as "Comeuppance" or a second copy of "Arcbond")</li></ol>
<p>The implementation is pretty much direct. Each creature type represents a waterclock, with the waterclock's age being the maximum amount of damage marked on any creature with that type, and its value being the number of creatures of that type minus its age (which, due to 1. above, is also equal to the toughness of the creatures of that type minus the maximum damage marked on any of those creatures, i.e. the minimum amount of remaining toughness that any of the creatures have). 2. handles the zeroing triggers (which run <i>for each</i> creature that died, i.e. a number of times equal to the age + value, which is a number of times equal to the age because the value is 0), and 3. handles the steady decrement. Halting is handled by causing the "particular creature" in 3. to be a creature whose type is the halt waterclock.
</p><p>As long as the implementation is set up in such a way that the triggers from 3. always go on the stack below the triggers from 2. (which in <i>Magic</i> can be done by choosing the controllers of the various cards in question: effects controlled by the active player go on lower positions than effects controlled by the inactive player), this particular Turing-completeness construction has no choices that can usefully be made by any player, and will run to completion (or run forever) automatically. This makes it useful for <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Busy_beaver&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Busy beaver (page does not exist)">busy beaver</a> constructions. In particular, it is useful for "largest non-infinite combo in <i>Magic</i>" challenges, when the size of a combo is measured in terms of, e.g., how far the opponent's life total is sent below 0; although Flooding Waterfall Model can of course construct an infinite loop, non-halting programs give no way to progress with the game and thus the infinite loop does not form a valid combo by this sort of definition, meaning that only the non-infinite loops count.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Flooding Waterfall Model is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a> (and this has been proven via construction of an explicit compiler from <a href="/wiki/The_Waterfall_Model" title="The Waterfall Model">The Waterfall Model</a>; see <a href="#External_resources">#External resources</a> below).
</p><p>There are two key observations:
</p>
<ul><li>The most intuitive way to think about the flooding waterclocks, in terms of programming in Flooding Waterfall Model, is in terms of their <i>velocity</i> and <i>position</i>:
<ul><li>The velocity is the multiplier that will be applied to their zeroing trigger, i.e. the total amount it has been incremented by since it was last zero. This is equal to the waterclock's value plus its age.</li>
<li>The position is the moment in time at which the waterclock was last zero, i.e. a point in time that happened a number of steady-decrements ago equal to the waterclock's age. However, instead of thinking of the position relative to the current time, it is generally more intuitive to think about a few fixed moments in time and think about positions relative to those.</li></ul></li>
<li>It is possible to design a construction in which the waterclocks are divided into two clusters, such that if any waterclock becomes zero, all the waterclocks in its own cluster will become zero before any waterclocks in the other cluster do (and will remain at zero when the first waterclock in the other cluster becomes zero). If the waterclocks zero in any such order, the positions will have no effect on the velocities: the velocities in the second cluster will depend purely on the velocities in the first, not on the positions nor on the sequence in which the waterclocks became zero. (This is because a flooding zeroing trigger is effectively of the form "one waterclock A velocity becomes <i>x</i> waterclock B velocity, plus <i>y</i> waterclock C velocity, etc.", which is entirely linear, so the velocities in the second cluster can be determined as a linear combination of the velocities in the first cluster.)</li></ul>
<p>The basic idea is to measure velocities with respect to a "baseline" <i>b</i><sup><i>c</i></sup>, where <i>b</i> is a sufficiently large fixed constant, and <i>c</i> is the number of times execution has gone back and forth between one cluster and the other. The relative velocity of each nonzero flooding waterclock against the baseline can be made to form a fixed cycle, via maintaining "baseline waterclocks" which are at fixed distances from the baseline, or that follow a very simple pattern (e.g. +1 compared to the baseline for 1 cycle, followed by being +0 compared to the baseline for <i>n</i> cycles). Because the velocities do not depend on the positions, the velocities that would be caused by any given zeroing trigger can be predicted and compensated for, meaning that the baseline waterclocks can effectively force the baseline-relative velocities of every waterclock in the construction to follow a fixed repeating pattern, and it is possible for the programmer to choose what that pattern is.
</p><p>It is then possible to emulate the values of waterclocks from the program being compiled by using the positions (rather than values) of the program being compiled into. When a flooding waterclock zeroes, it will grant its position plus velocity as a new position for any waterclocks that change from zero to nonzero due to its zeroing trigger, but the positions of other waterclocks will remain unchanged (even if they were affected). If you have two waterclocks with the same position but different velocities (the "same position" is easy to arrange by having them be affected by the same zeroing triggers, and the velocities can be set in any arbitrary repeating cycle), and they both affect the same waterclock, then the waterclock with the smaller velocity will normally set the position of the affected waterclock (because it zeroes first). However, if another waterclock in the same cluster zeroes earlier and adds to the smaller-velocity waterclock, then the waterclock with the larger velocity will set the position of the affected waterclock instead. This effectively lets you write code that does the calculation <code>if (w &lt; x) { y = x + b; } else { y = x + a; }</code>, which is sufficient computational power to implement The Waterfall Model.
</p><p>Although this construction needs velocities and positions to be set carefully in order to work, and doesn't "naturally" start in a state where all waterclocks have the same position (which is how Flooding Waterfall Model programs are required to start up), this is easy to work around using "startup waterclocks" which start at a given value, zero once, and are never incremented by anything; a counter can then be initialised to arbitrary position and velocity (as long as the position is less than half the velocity) by using two startup waterclocks, a smaller one to set the position and a larger one to top up the velocity once the position has been set. (The easy case is when the position is greater than one third of the velocity, in which case you can use a 1 in both zeroing triggers and the second startup waterclock will top up the counter before the water it gained from the first startup waterclock runs out. If the desired position is smaller, it is still possible to make startup work, via increasing the number in the first zeroing trigger, but this situation is more complex and avoided by the compiler linked below.)
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Variant:_Staggered_Flooding_Waterfall_Model">Variant: Staggered Flooding Waterfall Model</span></h2>
<p>The following variant can be considered:
Each waterclock additionally has a "stagger constant" K, and a "stagger flag". K is chosen as part of the program input, and must be at least equal to the sum of that waterclock's zeroing triggers.
</p>
<ul><li>When a waterclock becomes zero, its stagger flag is cleared</li>
<li>When a waterclock that was zero becomes nonzero, its value is increased by K, and its age is decreased by K (this has no impact on its "velocity", but it will zero K steps later than it otherwise would; effectively increasing its "position" by K)</li>
<li>When a waterclock is added to via a zeroing trigger, if its current value is nonzero but less than its stagger constant K, its stagger flag is set. If the flag was already set, the result is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a>.</li>
<li>If a waterclock with its stagger flag set becomes zero, and its flooding trigger adds to a waterclock whose value was zero, the result is undefined behaviour.</li></ul>
<p>This variant is still Turing complete; and the construction described above (and listed in the external resources) still works.
The K value  for each waterclock (besides startup waterclocks that just assist in startup) is chosen to be the same. (it can be chosen before constants that are used to determine the initial values of startup clocks, to help uphold initial invariants; as by that point all flood triggers are determined)
</p><p>As during the construction only the relative positions of waterclocks within each cluster matter, adding an additional offset of K to all positions between each cycle doesn't matter. 
There are a few cases where a clock in cluster A is added to by another clock in cluster A, meaning the effect on positions of those clocks are potentially counted multiple times; however those clocks never impact the positions of anything in cluster B; so their precise timing doesn't matter; and the initial constants can be chosen to account for the stagger constant K to ensure invariants are upheld.
</p><p>There are a few cases where the stagger flag of a waterclock could potentially be set; when clocks in cluster A add to another clock in cluster A. This simply impacts the position by an additional +K, which as above doesn't matter. The latter waterclock will not be added to again before it zeroes, and will not update the position of anything, so the potential UB will not arise. 
</p><p>This variant is considered due to a detail in its construction in <i>Magic: The Gathering</i>. The card "Coat of Arms" that is used in the construction increases the toughness of creatures by the number of creatures that share a type with it. If there are no other creatures of the same type of the one that implements the waterclock, this implements the standard FWM; and this can be assured if the card "Bishop of Wings" is used. However, if the similar card "Xathid Necromancer" is used (which has benefits for the purposes of the "largest non-infinite combo in <i>Magic</i>" challenges), each necromancer is required to share a type with the creature it triggers on the death of (i.e. the flood triggers of the waterclock it implements), which amounts to the stagger constant K. (which can be increased by using additional creatures that share a the type). 
The stagger flag semantics and the name arise from the fact that there are situations where, the next time a waterclock should zero, not all of the creatures in it die at the same time, so the effects of its flood trigger are "staggered"; with some of it happening K ticks later instead. These are exactly the cases where the stagger flag is set. The second UB cases arise when a staggered clock is used to set the position of something. The first UB case arises when a staggered clock has already started to flood, but has not yet finished; but is added to before it has finished. The precise results of these situations in the MTG construction are difficult to predict, so we define them as UB and construct programs such that they won't arise.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/The_Waterfall_Model" title="The Waterfall Model">The Waterfall Model</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="http://nethack4.org/esolangs/waterfall-to-flooding-waterfall.pl" rel="nofollow">Compiler from The Waterfall Model to Flooding Waterfall Model</a> (in Perl)
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://www.mtgsalvation.com/forums/magic-fundamentals/magic-general/615089-most-turn-1-damage-in-a-deck-with-no-infinite?page=203#c5093" rel="nofollow">A correctness proof for the algorithm that the compiler uses, by Jfb</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://nethack4.org/esolangs/floodfall.tar.gz" rel="nofollow">Interpreter for Flooding Waterfall Model</a> (Rust tarball); attempts to efficiently handle the exponential growth of the language via using an optimized number representation (and is capable of running programs generated using the above compiler with only an O(n log n) slowdown compared to a naïve interpreter for The Waterfall Model)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://www.mtgsalvation.com/forums/magic-fundamentals/magic-general/615089-most-turn-1-damage-in-a-deck-with-no-infinite?page=99#c2501" rel="nofollow">The origin of Flooding Waterfall Model</a></li></ul>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Forte</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> created by <a href="/wiki/User:Ais523" title="User:Ais523">User:ais523</a> in <a href="/wiki/Category:2006" title="Category:2006">2006</a>, based around redefinition of constants. Its syntax is similar to BASIC (a non-esoteric language). It is called Forte due to the mess it makes of the Peano postulates. It was created after considering the following pseudocode for the <a href="/wiki/99_bottles_of_beer" title="99 bottles of beer">99 bottles of beer</a> program:
</p>
<pre>Start loop
  Output 99 " bottles of beer on the wall,"
  Output 99 " bottles of beer."
  Output "Take one down, pass it around,"
  Decrement 99
  Output 99 " bottles of beer on the wall."
Loop until 99 becomes 2
Output the last 99 verses
</pre>
<p>Clearly, this is absurd.<br/>
<br/>
</p><p>Forte does not have an explicit looping construct. In fact, it resembles <a href="/wiki/SMITH" title="SMITH">SMITH</a>, in that it does not allow any sort of jump, and loops by moving commands forwards (<a href="/wiki/SMITH" title="SMITH">SMITH</a> copies commands forwards).
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Syntax"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Syntax</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Expressions"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Expressions</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Commands"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Commands</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Control_structures"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Control structures</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7"><a href="#An_example"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">An example</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Quine"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Quine</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax">Syntax</span></h2>
<p>The following commands exist in Forte (items in square brackets are optional):
</p>
<ul><li>LET expression = expression</li>
<li>PRINT expression [;]</li>
<li>PRINT "string" [;]</li>
<li>INPUT expression</li>
<li>GET expression</li>
<li>PUT expression</li>
<li>REM comment</li>
<li>END</li></ul>
<p>REM is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NOP" title="NOP">NOP</a>, regardless of what follows it on the line (even a colon). Multiple commands can be written as one command by separating them with colons; if the last character on a line is a colon, the colon is respected but the line break is ignored. All commands must be preceded by a number (their line number); all numbers must be nonnegative integers (an implementation should allow unbounded integers). All whitespace, apart from newlines and whitespace inside strings, is ignored. For descriptions of the commands, see below.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Expressions">Expressions</span></h2>
<p>Expressions take one of the following forms:
</p>
<table>
<tbody><tr>
<th align="left">Constant
</th>
<td>number
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th align="left">Addition
</th>
<td>(expression + expression)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th align="left">Subtraction
</th>
<td>(expression - expression)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th align="left">Multiplication
</th>
<td>(expression * expression)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th align="left">Division
</th>
<td>(expression / expression)
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Division is truncated downwards to the maximum integer not exceeding the result. A subtraction where the second number exceeds the first is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined</a>. The outermost pair of brackets in an expression may be omitted; all other brackets are compulsory (for instance, 1+(2+3) is allowed, but 1+2+3 isn't (and (1+2)+3 might have a substantially different value!)).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commands">Commands</span></h2>
<ul><li>LET. This command is the heart of the language, and is the only command that affects <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-completeness</a>. It redefines the number given by the expression on the left of the = sign to have the value of the expression on the right. (The expression's value at that moment is calculated; if it changes later, the number is still redefined to the expression's original value). Note that this permanently renders an integer unusable; see the examples below. (There are many cases left ambiguous by this description; the examples show what happens in each case.)</li>
<li>PRINT. This outputs the value of the expression (as a number with no surrounding whitespace), or the given string. If the command does not end with a semicolon, a newline is output immediately afterwards.</li>
<li>INPUT. This works like LET, except that the redefinition of the number is taken from the input, not from an expression. The expression gives the number to redefine.</li>
<li>GET. This works like INPUT, except that it inputs a character and redefines the number given by the expression to its ASCII code. It inputs 256 on end-of-file.</li>
<li>PUT. This outputs the character whose ASCII code is given by the expression, without a newline following. (Of course, if the expression evaluates to 10 (newline), a newline is output.)</li>
<li>REM. This never does anything; it is provided as a way to write comments.</li>
<li>END. This causes the program to end. If this isn't given, the program enters an infinite loop rather than ending.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Control_structures">Control structures</span></h2>
<p>The program starts at the line with the lowest line number (thus, the lines can be given in arbitrary order at the start of the program). Whenever a command finishes, the command with the next lowest number is run, even if that command has run earlier. (Due to the fact that the values of the line numbers can be redefined, this can happen quite easily.) If a command's line number is redefined while the command is executing, even indirectly, this leads to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a>; if two lines' line numbers have the same value, the behaviour is also undefined. Again, the examples below should make things clearer.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<p>All the examples here are part of one long program.
</p>
<pre>10 REM This is an example program:
       it is written for the Esolang wiki.
</pre>
<p>This does nothing (the colon negates the newline, but is ignored in turn by the REM; the 'it' is not taken as the start of a command).
</p>
<pre>20 PRINT 6*9
</pre>
<p>This outputs 54.
</p>
<pre>30 LET 9=7
40 PRINT 6*9
</pre>
<p>This now outputs 42, as 9 has the value 7.
</p>
<pre>50 LET 42=20
60 PRINT 6*9
</pre>
<p>This outputs 20 (the value of 42).
</p>
<pre>70 LET 20=75
</pre>
<p>After this command is complete, and before command 80 runs, 75 is printed. This is because the next command to run is the command labeled 20 (which has the value 75).
</p>
<pre>80 LET 42=9
</pre>
<p>This assigns 7 to 20 (42 and 9 have both been redefined). Both 42 and 20 now have the value 7 (as does the number 7); there is no way to use the integers 42 or 20 for anything; even something like
</p>
<pre>90 PRINT 4*5 : PRINT 6*9
</pre>
<p>outputs 7 twice. (This is what is meant by redefinition permanently rendering an integer unusable; it makes input to a Forte program incredibly difficult).
</p>
<pre>100PRINT (6*9)*11         :PRINT6*  (9*11)
</pre>
<p>This outputs 77, followed by 462. This sort of thing is why bracketing is compulsory in Forte. The line shows that non-newline whitespace is ignored (for technical reasons, there are no form feeds, tabs, or vertical tabs in the above line, but there could be and the line would still work).
</p>
<pre>100110 LET 110=110+3
109 LET 100110=108
110 PRINT "Looping...": LET 108=108+3
</pre>
<p>This prints the output
</p>
<pre>Looping...
</pre>
<p>many times; after all, lines 110, 113, 116, 119, etc., all say PRINT "Looping..."... The colon, although it cancels the line break, is not cancelled itself. Line 109 is used to start the loop off, and is not copied; line 108 (numbered 100110 at the start of the program to prevent it being run prematurely) is used to copy line 110. There have to be two renumbering lines like this because a line cannot renumber itself.
</p>
<pre>172 LET 114=95
</pre>
<p>This exits the loop (line 173 will output "Looping..." one last time), and 174 is substantially lower than 173 at this point.
</p>
<pre>180 PRINT "42";
190 PRINT 42
</pre>
<p>This outputs "427". (The 42 inside the string literal is not a number, so is not redefined, and the semicolon omits the newline after the PRINT statement on line 180).
</p>
<pre>195 INPUT 60
</pre>
<p>This line could cause all sorts of havoc. In fact, the INPUT statement is probably best avoided. Who knows what values the user might enter?
</p>
<pre>199 END
</pre>
<p>Something needs to cause the program to end.
</p><p>Some errors:
</p>
<pre>200 LET 200=201
</pre>
<p>The behaviour of this is undefined, as it redefines 200.
</p>
<pre>210 PRINT "210"
220 PRINT "220"
230 LET 210=220:LET 210=240
</pre>
<p>This leaves both 210 and 220 with the value 240 (220 is assigned to 210, then 240 is assigned to 220 (the value of 210)). When this line is actually reached, there is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a>.
</p>
<pre>250 LET 99 = 4
           + 5
</pre>
<p>Commands cannot be split across lines, so this is a syntax error.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Here is a method for showing Forte's <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-completeness</a>, by <a href="/wiki/User:Keymaker" title="User:Keymaker">Keymaker</a> in <a href="/wiki/Category:2014" title="Category:2014">2014</a>, by introducing a simple language <b>Ectoforte</b> and providing the means to translate it to Forte. Ectoforte is shown Turing-complete by providing a way to translate <a href="/wiki/Minsky_machine" title="Minsky machine">Minsky machine</a> to it.
</p><p>The design principles of Ectoforte were simple: to make a small Turing-complete language that would be as easy as possible to translate to Forte. Originally the language had more features that no doubt made programming easier, but these were removed in favour of simplicity. This is the simplest way the author came up with. It should be noted that there was no intention to make Ectoforte particularly unique or interesting in its own right; the name already tells much, it is a parasite language built upon Forte, taking all the advantage of the host it can.
</p><p>A vital role in Ectoforte programming (and program execution) is the idea of <i>cycles</i>. A <i>line</i> in Ectoforte is a line of data that begins with the label, then ':', and then at least one instruction (and there is no upper limit to them). A line may be ON or OFF. During a cycle, each line that is ON will be executed (sequentially, from first to last). Likewise the instructions within a line are executed sequentially. On the very first cycle, all lines are ON.
</p><p>The memory model of Ectoforte is counters/registers that can only be increased. They can be compared only in the context of setting lines ON or OFF, see below.
</p><p>The instructions are:
</p>
<ul><li><b>abc+++</b> increases register <i>abc</i> as many times as there are succeeding '+' characters (there needs to be at least one)</li>
<li><b>xyz.ON</b> sets line <i>xyz</i> on for the <i>next</i> cycle. It does not matter what state the line is, or on which cycle (unlike with OFF, see below). But setting the same line ON twice during the same cycle is forbidden.</li>
<li><b>line3.OFF</b> sets <i>line3</i> OFF for the <i>current</i> cycle. A line must first be ON during the current cycle for it to be set OFF. Setting OFF a line that is currently OFF in the current cycle (or ON or OFF in some past cycle) or has been set ON for the next cycle during the current cycle is forbidden.</li>
<li><b>line1.zz\a1</b> sets the line <i>line1</i> (which first must be ON during the current cycle, and same restrictions as above to ON and OFF setting apply) to either OFF or ON. Which one, it depends on what the "equalizer" (\) returns, after comparing two registers (<i>zz</i> and <i>a1</i> here). The first register (<i>zz</i>) must be smaller than the second or equal to it. It is an error if during the "equalizer" comparison the first register has a larger value than the second. If registers are equal, the line is set ON (for the next cycle), if they are not, the line is set to OFF (for the current cycle).</li>
<li><b>"hello";</b> and <b>"hello"</b> would print "<i>hello</i>" with a new-line and without, respectively.</li>
<li><b>exit</b> halts/ends the program.</li></ul>
<p>An Ectoforte-to-Forte translator written in Python can be found here: <a class="external text" href="http://yiap.nfshost.com/esoteric/forte/ectoforte.py" rel="nofollow">http://yiap.nfshost.com/esoteric/forte/ectoforte.py</a>
</p><p>A MM-to-Ectoforte translator written in Python can be found here: <a class="external text" href="http://yiap.nfshost.com/esoteric/forte/mmecto.py" rel="nofollow">http://yiap.nfshost.com/esoteric/forte/mmecto.py</a>
</p><p>Note that running the final MM-to-Ectoforte-to-Forte program can take hours even for a relatively simple program!
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="An_example">An example</span></h3>
<p>A simple MM program to increase counter A to 3 and then decrease it till it is zero.
</p>
<pre>1 INC A 2
2 INC A 3
3 INC A 4
4 DEC A 4 5
5 HALT
</pre>
<p>The MM-to-Ectoforte translator provides the following:
</p>
<pre>1: 1next.ON 2next.OFF 3next.OFF 4next.OFF 5next.OFF inst1.OFF inst2.OFF inst3.OFF inst4.OFF inst4x.OFF inst4y.OFF inst5.OFF
1next: inst1.ON
2next: inst2.ON
3next: inst3.ON
4next: inst4.ON inst4x.ON
5next: inst5.ON
inst1: regA+ 2next.ON
inst2: regA+ 3next.ON
inst3: regA+ 4next.ON
inst4: inst4x.regAzero\regA inst4y.ON
inst4x: inst4y.OFF 5next.ON
inst4y: regAzero+ 4next.ON
inst5: exit
</pre>
<p>There is line "1" that sets "1next" active for the next cycle (and therefore inactive for the current cycle) and all others OFF for the current cycle, one Xnext line for every MM instruction, and one (INC, HALT) or three (DEC) instX lines for every MM instruction.
</p><p>Running the previous data through Ectoforte-to-Forte translator, the resulting Forte program is:
</p>
<pre>39 LET 40 = (39 + 18) + 1
40 LET 39 = 40 + 17
41 LET 42 = (40 + 18) + 2 : LET 43 = 43 - 18 : LET 44 = 44 - 18 : LET 45 = 45 - 18 : LET 46 = 46 - 18 : LET 47 = 47 - 18 : LET 48 = 48 - 18 : LET 49 = 49 - 18 : LET 50 = 50 - 18 : LET 51 = 51 - 18 : LET 52 = 52 - 18 : LET 53 = 53 - 18
42 LET 47 = (40 + 18) + 7
43 LET 48 = (40 + 18) + 8
44 LET 49 = (40 + 18) + 9
45 LET 50 = (40 + 18) + 10 : LET 51 = (40 + 18) + 11
46 LET 53 = (40 + 18) + 13
47 LET 19 = 19 + 18 : LET 43 = (40 + 18) + 3
48 LET 19 = 19 + 18 : LET 44 = (40 + 18) + 4
49 LET 19 = 19 + 18 : LET 45 = (40 + 18) + 5
50 LET 51 = (51 - 18) + (((20 - 2) / (19 - 1)) * 54) : LET 52 = (40 + 18) + 12
51 LET 52 = 52 - 18 : LET 46 = (40 + 18) + 6
52 LET 20 = 20 + 18 : LET 45 = (40 + 18) + 5
53 END
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Quine">Quine</span></h2>
<p>A Quine was discovered by Stack Exchange user <a class="external text" href="http://codegolf.stackexchange.com/users/58375/ataco" rel="nofollow">ATaco</a>, which, in retrospect is actually fairly simple.
</p>
<pre>20 LET 10=40
30 PUT 34
50 PUT 34
60 PUT 59
10 PRINT "20 LET 10=40
30 PUT 34
50 PUT 34
60 PUT 59
10 PRINT ";
</pre>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><i>See also <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FRACTRAN" title="wikipedia:FRACTRAN">wikipedia:FRACTRAN</a>.</i>
</p>
<table style="float:right;border:1px solid silver;background-color:rgb(249, 249, 249);max-width:256px;padding:5px;">
<caption><b>FRACTRAN</b></caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Designed by</th>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Conway" title="John Conway">John Conway</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;"><a href="/wiki/Category:Years" title="Category:Years">Appeared in</a></th>
<td>1986</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;"><a href="/wiki/Computational_class" title="Computational class">Computational class</a></th>
<td>Turing-complete</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Reference implementation</th>
<td><a href="/wiki/Category:Unimplemented" title="Category:Unimplemented">Unimplemented</a></td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p><b>Fractran</b> is a language and associated computational model introduced by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Conway" title="John Conway">John Conway</a> in their 1986 article, "FRACTRAN: A Simple Universal Programming Language for Arithmetic."
</p><p>In Fractran, a program consists of a finite list of positive, rational numbers.  The input to a program is a positive integer n.  The list is then searched in order, for a rational number p/q such that np/q is an integer.  Then n is replaced by np/q and the search is restarted from the beginning of the list.  The program halts when no such number p/q can be found, and the final n becomes the output from the program.
</p><p>The power of this formalism comes from viewing numbers as products of prime powers.  For example, if the input is 2<sup>x</sup> 3<sup>y</sup>, the following list gives output 5<sup>xy</sup>, essentially multiplying x by y:
</p>
<pre>13/21, 385/13, 1/7, 3/11, 7/2, 1/3
  or, after prime factorization,
13/(3*7), (5*7*11)/13, 1/7, 3/11, 7/2, 1/3
</pre>
<p>John Conway made the following program for producing prime numbers:
</p>
<pre>17/91, 78/85, 19/51, 23/38, 29/33, 77/29, 95/23, 77/19, 1/17, 11/13, 13/11, 15/14, 15/2, 55/1
</pre>
<p>If you start with n=2, it will go through exactly those powers of 2 whose exponents are prime numbers.
</p><p>In 1999, this was shortened by Devin Kilminster (then a Ph.D student at the University of Western Australia, now a scientist at the Meteorological Service of New Zealand) to the following:
</p>
<pre>7/3 99/98 13/49 39/35 36/91 10/143 49/13 7/11 1/2 91/1
</pre>
<p>When started with n=10, this produces a sequence of powers of 10 whose exponents are successive primes.
</p><p>Kilminster has since shortened the above program to produce a prime program using only <i>nine</i> fractions:
</p>
<pre>3/11 847/45 143/6 7/3 10/91 3/7 36/325 1/2 36/5
</pre>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Squeezing_fraction_size"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Squeezing fraction size</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Interpreter"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Interpreter</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Squeezing_fraction_size">Squeezing fraction size</span></h2>
<p>It is possible to modify any Fractran program so that its fractions are arbitrarily close to 1 in size but it can still perform the same computations.
</p><p>Let <i>f</i><sub>0</sub>,…,<i>f</i><sub><i>n</i></sub> be the fractions of the program.
</p><p>Given any <i>ε</i>&gt;0, choose primes <i>p</i>,<i>q</i>,<i>r</i>; <i>p</i>&lt;<i>q</i>&lt;<i>r</i>&lt;<i>p</i>(1+<i>ε</i>), that are not already factors in the program. (Possible by the <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number_theorem" title="wikipedia:Prime number theorem">Wikipedia:Prime number theorem</a>.)
</p><p>Then a new list of fractions <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> is given by
</p>
<dl><dd><i>g</i><sub>0</sub> = <i>q</i>/<i>p</i></dd>
<dd><i>g</i><sub>1</sub> = <i>q</i>/<i>r</i></dd>
<dd><i>g</i><sub><i>i</i>+2</sub> = <i>a</i>(<i>f</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>)</dd></dl>
<dl><dd><i>a(x)</i> = <i>x</i> * (<i>p</i>/<i>q</i>)<sup>round(-log <i>x</i>/log(<i>p</i>/<i>q</i>))</sup>, <i>x</i>≥1</dd>
<dd><i>a(x)</i> = <i>x</i> * (<i>r</i>/<i>q</i>)<sup>round(-log <i>x</i>/log(<i>r</i>/<i>q</i>))</sup>, <i>x</i>≤1</dd></dl>
<p>All the new fractions so defined are within the range (1/(1+<i>ε</i>), 1+<i>ε</i>).
</p><p>The input to the new program is the input to the old program multiplied by <i>q</i><sup><i>k</i></sup>, where <i>k</i> is the maximal number of <i>q</i> factors in the <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>.
</p><p>All fractions <i>g</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> preserve the sum of the exponents of <i>p</i>, <i>q</i> and <i>r</i>, and the first two shuffle these back to <i>q</i>, to ensure that the number always contains <i>q</i><sup><i>k</i></sup> for the remaining fractions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Interpreter">Interpreter</span></h2>
<pre>   frac=: ({~ 1 i.~(=&lt;.))@:* NB. this is a small interpreter for fractran in J.
   cp  =: 17r91 78r85 19r51 23r38 29r33 77r29 95r23 77r19 1r17 11r13 13r11 15r14 15r2 55r1 NB. Conway Primer, example program.
   cp frac 2
15
   cp frac 15
825
   cp frac 825
725
   cp frac^:(i.10) 2                        NB. iterating.
2 15 825 725 1925 2275 425 390 330 290
   (#~ (=&lt;.))@:(2&amp;^.) cp frac^:(i.1e4) 2    NB. generating primes.
1 2 3 5 7 11 13 17
   genp=: 4 : '(#~ (=&lt;.))@:(a&amp;^.) x frac^:(i.b) a[#''a b''=.y' NB. genearlized.
   cp genp 2;1e4
1 2 3 5 7 11 13 17
   kilm=: 3r11 847r45 143r6 7r3 10r91 3r7 36r325 1r2 36r5 NB. Kilminster's program.
   kilm genp 10;1e4
1 2 3 5 7 11 13 17 19
</pre>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Fueue</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Queue" title="Queue">queue</a>-based <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> created by <a href="/wiki/Nathan_van_Doorn" title="Nathan van Doorn">Nathan van Doorn</a> in 2012. Everything is stored in a single queue. The source of the program is converted to this queue on execution.
</p><p>Evaluation proceeds as follows:
</p>
<ul><li>Look at the front element of the queue.</li>
<li>If it is a numeric value, convert it to a character and print.</li>
<li>If it is a function, and there are enough values of the appropriate type directly behind it in the queue, the function and those values are popped, and the result is pushed back to the end of the queue.</li>
<li>Otherwise, it is simply sent to the back of the queue.</li>
<li>If the queue reaches this last stage many times and so does a full rotation without changing at all, a character is taken from input and its unicode value is added to the back of the queue.</li></ul>
<p>The only things allowed in a program are nonnegative integers (in base 10), the functions described below, square bracket encoded subprogram blocks (which are actually queues), and whitespace.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</ul>

</ul>
</li>
