<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Functions">Functions</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Function</th>
<th>Effect</th>
<th>Before</th>
<th>After
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code></td>
<td>Adds two numbers</td>
<td><code>+<i>ab</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...(<i>a</i>+<i>b</i>)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code></td>
<td>Negates a number</td>
<td><code>-<i>a</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...(-<i>a</i>)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>*</code></td>
<td>Multiplies two numbers</td>
<td><code>*<i>ab</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...(<i>a</i>*<i>b</i>)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>/</code></td>
<td>Integer divides two numbers</td>
<td><code>/<i>ab</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...(<i>a</i>/<i>b</i>)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>%</code></td>
<td>Logically inverts a number (0 to one, n to 0)</td>
<td><code>%<i>a</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...(!<i>a</i>)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>:</code></td>
<td>Duplicates a value</td>
<td><code>:<i>a</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...<i>aa</i></code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>~</code></td>
<td>Swaps two values</td>
<td><code>~<i>ab</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...<i>ba</i></code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>!</code></td>
<td>Pops a value</td>
<td><code>!<i>a</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>$</code></td>
<td>Pushes a number of copies</td>
<td><code>$<i>ab</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...(<i>a</i> lots of <i>b</i>)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>(</code></td>
<td>Turns a value into a block</td>
<td><code>(<i>a</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...[<i>a</i>]</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code></td>
<td>Adds another value into a block</td>
<td><code>&lt;[<i>foo</i>]<i>b</i>...</code></td>
<td><code>...[<i>foob</i>]</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>)</code></td>
<td>Deblocks a block</td>
<td><code>)[<i>foo</i>]...</code></td>
<td><code>...<i>foo</i></code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>H</code></td>
<td>Halts immediately</td>
<td><code>H...</code></td>
<td>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Cat_program.2FNull_program"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat_program/Null_program"><a href="/wiki/Cat_program" title="Cat program">Cat program</a>/<a href="/wiki/Null_program" title="Null program">Null program</a></span></h3>
<pre>

</pre>
<p>In Fueue, the null program is a cat, although it doesn't handle end of file.
</p>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_world.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_world!"><a href="/wiki/Hello,_world!" title="Hello, world!">Hello, world!</a></span></h3>
<pre>72 101 108 108 111 44 32 119 111 114 108 100 33 10 H
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infinite_loop">Infinite loop</span></h3>
<pre>):[):]
</pre>
<p>Even shorter, but less generalizable:
</p>
<pre>::
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="A_finite_loop_printing_the_alphabet">A finite loop printing the alphabet</span></h3>
<pre>)$2[)$--------2~)~~[)[)~(~[~[$~H~]~)%+~91-):]~1+:])]]~[$~H~])%+-91)[65][65]
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Thue-Morse_sequence">Thue-Morse sequence</span></h3>
<p>Original version:
</p>
<pre>48 ~!~)): [[48 [)):] [~!~)):] ~~) !][49 [~!~)):] [)):] )~]]
</pre>
<p>Shorter version inspired by the Kolakoski sequence program:
</p>
<pre>)):[[48][49~]~~:))~:~:~]
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kolakoski_sequence">Kolakoski sequence</span></h3>
<pre>49)50:[[50:])~)~:~[[49]:~))~:~~]~]
</pre>
<p>Made for <a class="external text" href="https://codegolf.stackexchange.com/a/159733/" rel="nofollow">this PPCG answer</a>, which also includes some explanation.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Truth-machine"><a href="/wiki/Truth-machine" title="Truth-machine">Truth-machine</a></span></h3>
<pre>[[)[~~~~()+1])])][[)$-----~1-[~:)~)[)[~:)~)]~:]:]~[~[$~H~~%~+])~48-):])~)~:])][)~[0]])$
</pre>
<p>The above program shows how one may, although awkwardly, in principle achieve usable input in Fueue.
</p><p>Numbers in Fueue are unstable, which means that they cannot be used as (top level) elements in a queue that needs to be unchanging for an entire cycle so that input can be triggered.  Also, unless protected by e.g. being inside a block, they must be used immediately after they are produced.  This includes the number produced as input.
</p><p>Only the functions <code>-%$</code> are capable of using a number appearing, while at the same time having both themselves and their other arguments do nothing for an entire preceding cycle.  Of these, only <code>$</code> doesn't just postpone the problem again to the next cycle.
</p><p>The method used here, which might be the only one possible, is to let a <code>$</code> function use the appearing number to duplicate a number of blocks, after which a <code>)</code> function starts executing the first one.
</p><p>Once this has been achieved, we have enough control of timing to arrange for the blocks to perform arithmetic to reconstruct the original number, but this time protected inside a block.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Deadfish_interpreter"><a href="/wiki/Deadfish" title="Deadfish">Deadfish</a> interpreter</span></h3>
<ul><li>The code for the interpreter is at <a href="/wiki/Deadfish#Fueue" title="Deadfish">Deadfish#Fueue</a>.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Brainfuck_interpreter"><a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">Brainfuck</a> interpreter</span></h3>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="http://oerjan.nvg.org/esoteric/fueue/brainfuck.fu" rel="nofollow">A nicer formatted version</a> (but still utterly unreadable to known humanity) is available.</li></ul>
<p>This interpreter simulates 8-bit cells, and makes no attempt to prepare for I/O characters larger than 255 if you should get a Fueue interpreter which takes Unicode seriously. It will treat input characters ≤0 all the same, and assumes <code>EOF</code> has this form, which I think so far only applies to the C interpreter.  However it also supports the common <code>!</code> convention for ending the code, thus allowing the brainfuck program to get input.
</p>
<pre>):[)~$)[[)[~~~~()+1])][0]$%~~1)][[)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~43[)[~:~~~)&lt;[)~~[)$--1[)~]&lt;~~&lt;)&lt;[)$$7--1]][~~~)%[~~)~:(+-
)(~)+-1*256]+-~)255:]~]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~45[)[~:~~~)&lt;[)~~[)$--1[)~]&lt;~~&lt;)&lt;[)$$6-%0]][~~~)*[)~(:+~~-)+1]-
--256%):]~]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~62[)[~:~~~)&lt;[)~~[)$--1[)~]&lt;~~&lt;)&lt;[)$--%0]][))(($3~)&lt;(]~]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~
~60[)[~:~~~)&lt;[)~~[)$--1[)~]&lt;~~&lt;)&lt;[)$--%0]][~~)&lt;~~~(]~]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~91[)[)~~[)~&lt;[&lt;&lt;&lt;~(~~~&lt;)~][)[))$
12~[:]&lt;&lt;$4~~~&lt;[)$--1[$8~)$4&lt;[)$$6-%0[)]]&lt;]~)~:~]~[!~)~~[)[)$--1[)~~~[)$4~[~):~~[~:~)~[)$$6-%0~~[$~])~]&lt;~]
&lt;~&lt;]$3~[)$~~~%~~)]&lt;~(~~&lt;]~~&lt;&lt;~[0]]&lt;&lt;&lt;:]]]&lt;&lt;[1)]])(~~)~]~~]&lt;~[[~)~~!]):]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~93[)[[85 110
109 97 116 99 104 101 100 32 93 46H][)~[))$11~&lt;&lt;~:(~:&lt;]]~)~~~]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~46[)[~:~~~)&lt;[)~~[)$--1[)
~]&lt;~~&lt;)&lt;[)$%0]][):]~]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~44[)[~:~~~)&lt;[~~~~&lt;)[)))~$([[)[~~~~()+1])][0]$%~~1)][)[)[~[0]~])]
[~!]]]~]]!]~][)~&lt;[)$%+-~)~~~33[)[[)~[)[H]]~!][85 110 109 97 116 99 104 101 100 32 91 46H]~)~~~]!]~][)~&lt;[)
$%+-~)~~~0[)[[)~[)[H]]~!][85 110 109 97 116 99 104 101 100 32 91 46H]~)~~~]!]~][)[~:)~]!]:]:]:]:]:]:]:]:]
:]:][0]~]][[0]:[[0]&lt;:[[0]&lt;:]][73 110 116 101 114 110 97 108 32 101 114 114 111 114 58 32 116 111 112 108
101 118 101 108 32 114 117 110 116 105 109 101 32 93 46H])~!][~)]
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quines"><a href="/wiki/Quine" title="Quine">Quines</a></span></h3>
<p>See <a href="/wiki/List_of_quines#Fueue" title="List of quines">List of quines#Fueue</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>The following <a href="/wiki/Computational_class#Reduction" title="Computational class">reduction</a> of a subset of <a href="/wiki/Underload" title="Underload">Underload</a> to Fueue should show that Fueue is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>.  A <a class="external text" href="http://oerjan.nvg.org/esoteric/fueue/Ul2Fueue.hs" rel="nofollow">Haskell program</a> to perform this conversion is available.  (It makes programs quite a bit larger.  You may have to increase some size limits in the C Fueue interpreter to test the results.)
</p><p>The only restriction on the Underload programs is that <code>S</code> can only be translated as a command when it literally follows a parenthesized element in the program.  Some other programs that never use the same element as runnable program and printable text can be converted into this form by replacing lone <code>S</code> by <code>^</code> and printable text elements <code>(...)</code> by <code>((...)S)</code>. (This is compatible with combining printable strings with <code>*</code>, but alas not with <code>a</code>.) The <code>-S</code> option of the above linked conversion program can add this extra step automatically for Underload programs that never print an Underload command character except with a literal <code>(...)S</code> command sequence. However, expect strange errors if they do.
</p><p>The Fueue representation of an Underload program <code>A</code> is written as <code>{A}</code> in the translation below.  To run an Underload program <code>A</code> on an empty stack, you run the Fueue program
</p>
<pre>{A} [[] 46 46 46 111 117 116 32 111 102 32 115 116 97 99 107 33 10 H] [H]
</pre>
<p>The translation is continuation passing style: When run, the Fueue representation of a running Underload subprogram is followed by blocks representing the Underload stack and the Underload continuation.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Underload</th>
<th>Fueue translation</th>
<th>Remarks
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>~</code></td>
<td><code>~[)~~[~[:~)&lt;(]~)~)]&lt;[&lt;(]])~)~)</code>
</td>
<td rowspan="4"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>:</code></td>
<td><code>)~)[)~([~~)&lt;]~!]:</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>!</code></td>
<td><code>:~~!))</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>*</code></td>
<td><code style="white-space:nowrap">):~[):~[)~&lt;~[:~~&lt;)(]:~&lt;]~[)~~]&lt;~&lt;][):~~&lt;]~)~)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>(A)</code></td>
<td><code>~~)&lt;[[{A}]]</code>
</td>
<td><code>A</code> is an Underload subprogram
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>a</code></td>
<td><code>)~&lt;~[:~~&lt;)(]~([~~)&lt;])</code>
</td>
<td rowspan="2"> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>^</code></td>
<td><code>))</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> </td>
<td><code>)~</code></td>
<td>The null program
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>AB</code>
</td>
<td><code>):~~&lt;[{A}][)[{B}]~]~</code> or <code style="white-space:nowrap">):~~&lt;[{A}][)~~[{B}]]~</code>
</td>
<td><code>A</code> and <code>B</code> are Underload subprograms, preferably nonempty
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>(xy)S</code></td>
<td><code>120 121 )~</code>
</td>
<td>Printing strings other than <code>"xy"</code> is left as an exercise
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Turing-completeness_of_queue_sections">Turing-completeness of queue sections</span></h3>
<p>The latest version of this translation has been modified so that no command ever "wraps around" from the end of the encoding to the beginning. (Ironically, while such wrapping was originally used, in the belief that it was an "obvious" shortcut, no part of the translation got longer after the change.)
</p><p>This proves that it is not necessary for a computation to have access to the entire queue to be Turing-complete, only to its own section of it.
</p><p>As an amusing consequence, it is now possible to convert two different Underload programs, concatenate the results, and see the programs running "in parallel", with interspersed output.
</p><p>This technique does have some obvious limits: <code>H</code> remains global, and adding input handling seems impossible to combine with non-communicating queue sections.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Fueue_tips">Fueue tips</span></h2>
<p>To a very first approximation, programming in Fueue is similar to programming in a functional stack language like <a href="/wiki/Underload" title="Underload">Underload</a>.  You move data around on the queue to get it in position for applying functions, and for more complicated stuff you construct subprogram blocks out of data to run later.  A minor twist is that in Fueue it is often easier to move the function you want to apply to the data rather than the other way around.
</p><p>But the major issue that gives Fueue a quite different feeling to Underload is that you cannot just immediately apply the next function you want to the result you have just calculated; you have to go around the queue, and this will evaluate everything on the queue.  Moreover Fueue elements differ quite a lot in how easy it is <i>not</i> to evaluate them when you don't want to.  As a result you need to keep track of all elements as time passes, and constantly synchronize evaluation across the whole queue, to make sure elements don't evaluate before the time is right.
</p><p>As a result it is vital to have methods to <i>delay</i> evaluating parts of the queue.  Perhaps the cleanest way of delaying evaluation for a single cycle is to encapsulate elements in a block:
</p>
<pre>)[<i>delayed contents</i>]
</pre>
<p>If you only need to delay an element or two, it is often shorter to use <code>~</code> as a trick - whenever this function swaps two following elements, they will not be evaluated in this cycle.  However this method tends to blow up exponentially in length if you use it to delay for more than a couple of cycles, as the <code>~</code> itself is a very unstable element that needs to be delayed.  Also, redoing the placements of <code>~</code>'s and substantial elements across several cycles because of a minor bug correction near the final steps of your evaluation wears a little thin after a while.
</p><p>If you cannot afford swapping it with a neighbor, a single element can also be delayed for a cycle by putting <code>$1</code> in front of it.
</p><p>If you need to delay evaluation for <i>many</i> cycles, you can use the following trick, where each cycle removes one <code>-</code>. (Note that the number of <code>-</code>'s needs to be even, although a <code>~</code> can get around that.)
</p>
<pre>)$------1[<i>delayed contents for 8 cycles</i>]
)$$97--1[<i>delayed contents for 100 cycles</i>]
</pre>
<p>Lastly, if a subcomputation takes an unpredictable amount of time, then the part of the queue corresponding to the next subcomputation cannot be synchronized all by itself.  Instead you may let the first computation, when it is finishing, put a <code>)</code> in front of the block containing the delayed computation to run next.  This can work essentially like continuation passing style.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>

<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.vandoorn.talktalk.net/esoteric/fueue.hs" rel="nofollow">Implementation</a> in Haskell by Nathan van Doorn

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Funge-98</b> is the successor to, and a generalization of, <a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a>. It supports 1- and 3- dimensional funges, and includes many new commands.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>It started with a typo in 1993. Chatting at 4am, Curtis Coleman typed the word "before" as "befunge".  Chris Pressey immediately knew that the typo needed to be made more famous and started pondering on an esoteric programming language (before esoteric was actually the common name for the field) deserving of the name.  Some few weeks later, <a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a> was born; an attempt to create a language that could be interpreted but would defy compilation.  Get and Put commands allowed the program space to be modified at runtime and the instruction pointer is free to travel in multiple directions.  Befunge was one of the first 2D programming languages.  Chris didn't know at the time of invention, but Ward Cunningham, famous for conceptualizing the first Wiki (wiki wiki), had developed a 2 dimensional programming system, called <a href="/wiki/Biota" title="Biota">Biota</a>, a few years prior in 1991 as an experiment in cellular automata theory.  Just after the early Befunge code was being written, <a href="/wiki/Orthagonal" title="Orthagonal">Orthagonal</a> was being independently developed by Jeff Epler (announced in September 1994) as another early multi dimensional programming system.
</p><p>Befunge was revisited by Chris through the 1990s and specifications for an extended version went through a few iterations.  Befunge-97 was not quite right, but Befunge-98 seemed to hit the sweet spot of esoteric yet practical.  Funge-98 was born.  Unefunge (1D programming), Befunge (2D programming - the most common case), Trefunge (3D programming - many Funge-98 implementations support 3D) and a spec that allowed for Nefunge higher dimensions. Since the release of the Funge-98 specification, original Befunge is now sometimes referred to as Befunge-93.
</p><p>The first implementation of Befunge-98 was <a class="external text" href="https://catseye.tc/node/FBBI" rel="nofollow">FBBI</a>, the Flaming Bovine Befunge-98 Interpreter, written by Chris Pressey of Cat's Eye Technologies.  It does not claim to be a reference implementation (as the language is defined by the Funge-98 Specification rather than any implementation) and was buggy and unmaintained for many years (FBBI version 1.0 was not released until 2011).  Since the Funge-98 Specification's inception, many other implementations of the Funge-98 languages (Unefunge-98, Befunge-98, Trefunge-98) have been written by many people.
</p><p>Interest in Befunge has been fairly steady over the last 20+ years, and quite a few Befunge-93 implementations are available. Befunge enjoys a respectable number of solutions to programming tasks on Rosetta Code, the language comparison site.  <a class="external free" href="https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Category:Befunge" rel="nofollow">https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Category:Befunge</a>
</p><p>In 2006 Matti Niemenmaa started working on a Befunge-98 interpreter (<a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Deewiant/CCBI" rel="nofollow">CCBI</a>) in the D programming language and developed a test suite that he called <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Deewiant/Mycology" rel="nofollow">Mycology</a>, to verify compliance with the Funge-98 spec.  This test suite has been used for Funge-98 compliance validation for most of the Funge implementations ever since.  While working with Mycology and CCBI, Matti worked with Arvid Norlander, the developer of <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/cfunge" rel="nofollow">cfunge</a> and <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/efunge" rel="nofollow">efunge</a>, to iron out some of the kinks in the edge cases that are part and parcel of esoteric programming.
</p><p>The existence of Mycology has helped create a very robust Funge-98 implementation environment, and practitioners of the fungal arts get to enjoy an arguably higher level of compatibility than is common in esoteric programming circles. Especially given that Funge-98 and the Fingerprint extensions can be somewhat complicated.  Implementations have been developed in C, D, Erlang, ECMAScript, Clojure, to name a few of the available environments, and they are all closely compatible when executing complex Funge code.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="OS_Integration">OS Integration</span></h2>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Concurrency">Concurrency</span></h2>
<p>There is a "t" command that splits an IP and allows concurrent operations using an <i>IP list</i>. Each IP in the list has a separate Position, Delta and Offset.  Command sequences are defined by a <i>tick</i> concept, each IP in the list executing a <i>tick</i> for each step in a sequential circular loop (which is always in the same order until "threads" are created via the Split "t" command or end via the Stop "@" command.
</p><p>When a Split occurs, the original IP continues along its delta and the new IP reflects.
</p><p>"@" removes an IP from the list when stopping, further entries shuffled up to keep the same order.  When there are no remaining IPs, a Funge program will end.  The "q" quit command ends a Funge program regardless of how many active IPs are in the list.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Stack_Stack">Stack Stack</span></h2>
<p>Along with the normal stack, Funge-98 defines Block Start/Block End "{" "}" operations that can manage a stack of stacks.  TOSS is the Top of stack stack and SOSS becomes a Second to top of stack stack.  The "u" under command provides a facility for moving SOS stack items up to the TOS stack.  The block operators allow Funge routines to work on a stack without disturbing existing contents, and provides a method of digging down into a stack by copying parts of the TOSS to a SOSS (which effectively becomes TOSS as soon as the block command completes) and then manipulating items with judicious use of Under.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="FungeSpace">FungeSpace</span></h2>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Schematics">Schematics</span></h2>
<p>Cats eye, RC Funge
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Instructions">Instructions</span></h2>
<p>Funge-98 includes and expands on the original <a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a> instruction set.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Fingerprints">Fingerprints</span></h2>
<p>The <a class="external text" href="http://catseye.tc/view/funge-98/doc/funge98.markdown" rel="nofollow">Funge-98 specification</a> allows for extensions to the Funge instruction set via loadable Fingerprints. Capital A through Z instructions can be overloaded using the "(" Load Semantics/98 op-code and unloaded using ")".  The specification allows arbitrary mixing of the redefinitions.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Some_well_known_fingerprints">Some well known fingerprints</span></h3>
<p>The FBBI (Flaming Bovine Befunge-98 Interpreter) supports some initial extensions that are defined along with the Funge-98 specification.
</p><p>The Rc/Funge-98 and cfunge interpreters supports a wide range of overload semantics, many designed by the Rc/Funge-98 project.
</p><p>gnirts form and character count is usually used to feed the Load Semantics op-code, "TOYS" being "SYOT"4.  The "(" command reflects on load failure, or leaves two items on the stack on success. This pair can be used to ")" unload the fingerprint. The pair is an ID and a count of 1 that matches the fingerprint loader/unloader needs. <i>This pair is often discarded, and the gnirts form used to feed the unload operation.</i>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Common name
</th>
<th>Fingerprint
</th>
<th>New semantics
</th>
<th>Description
</th>
<th>More info
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>"3DSP"
</td>
<td>0x33445350
</td>
<td>A,B,C,D,L,M,N,P,R,S,T,U,V,X,Y,Z
</td>
<td>3D space matrix manipulation.
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#3DSP" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#3DSP</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"ARRY"
</td>
<td>0x41525259
</td>
<td>A,B,C,D,E,F,G
</td>
<td>Arrays. 1 to 3 dimensions; stored in funge-space.
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#ARRY" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#ARRY</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"BASE"
</td>
<td>0x42415345
</td>
<td>B,H,I,N,O
</td>
<td>I/O for numbers in other bases
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#BASE" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#BASE</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"BOOL"
</td>
<td>0x424F4F4C
</td>
<td>A,N,O,X
</td>

<td>0x5354434b
</td>
<td>B,C,D,G,K,N,P,R,S,T,U,W,Z
</td>
<td>Stack manipulation
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#STCK" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#STCK</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"STRN"
</td>
<td>0x5354524E
</td>
<td>A,C,D,F,G,I,L,M,N,P,R,S,V
</td>
<td>String (0gnirts) functions
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#STRN" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#STRN</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"SUBR"
</td>
<td>0x53554252
</td>
<td>A,C,J,O,R
</td>
<td>Subroutines
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#SUBR" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#SUBR</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"TERM"
</td>
<td>0x5445524D
</td>
<td>C,D,G,H,L,S,U
</td>
<td>Terminal extension
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TERM" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TERM</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"TIME"
</td>
<td>0x54494D45
</td>
<td>D,F,G,H,L,M,O,S,W,Y
</td>
<td>Time and Date functions
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TIME" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TIME</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"TOYS"
</td>
<td>0x544F5953
</td>
<td>A,C,D,E,I,H,K,L,M,N,P,Q,R,S,U,V,X,Y,Z
</td>
<td>Standard Toys
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="http://catseye.tc/view/funge-98/library/TOYS.markdown" rel="nofollow">http://catseye.tc/view/funge-98/library/TOYS.markdown</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"TRDS"
</td>
<td>0x54524453
</td>
<td>C,D,E,G,I,J,P,R,S,T,U,V
</td>
<td>IP travel in time and space
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TRDS" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TRDS</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"TRGR"
</td>
<td>0x54524752
</td>
<td>A-Y, Z
</td>
<td>Triggers (Z sets trigger table location)
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TRGR" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#TRGR</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"TURT"
</td>
<td>0x54555254
</td>
<td>A,B,C,D,E,F,H,I,L,N,P,Q,R,T,U
</td>
<td>Turtle Graphics
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="http://catseye.tc/view/funge-98/library/TURT.markdown" rel="nofollow">http://catseye.tc/view/funge-98/library/TURT.markdown</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"UNIX"
</td>
<td>0x554e4958
</td>
<td>A,B,C,D,E,G,H,K,M,N,P,R,S,T,U
</td>
<td>Some Unix access functions
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#UNIX" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#UNIX</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"WIND"
</td>
<td>0x57494E44
</td>
<td>B,C,D,E,I,K,L,M,O,P,R,S,T,W
</td>
<td>Windows extensions
</td>
<td><a class="external free" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#WIND" rel="nofollow">https://web.archive.org/web/20230617133910/http://rcfunge98.com/rcsfingers.html#WIND</a>
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p><i>rcfunge supports a -ux run option that opens an X11 window for on screen Turtle graphics display.</i>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Example_of_fingerprint_loading">Example of fingerprint loading</span></h4>
<pre>v ;Overlapping fingerprint;

  ;Load BOOL and N takes on a Not semantic;
         &gt;0a"detroppus ton LOOB"&gt;:#,_$@
             &gt;0a"detcelfer N :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@
&gt;"LOOB"4#^(7#^N7." toN"3k," si"2k,.a,    v

v ;Load TOYS and now N is Negate;        &lt;
         &gt;0a"detroppus ton SYOT"&gt;:#,_$@
             &gt;0a"detcelfer N :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@
&gt;"SYOT"4#^(7#^N7." detageN"7k," si"2k,.a,v

v ;Load NULL and N now reflects;         &lt;
         &gt;0a"detroppus ton LLUN"&gt;:#,_$@
                  &gt;0a"LLUN edisni detcelfer N :DOOG"&gt;:#,_$ v
&gt;"LLUN"4#^(:.\:.\#^N0"tcelfer t'ndid O :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@ 

  ;Fingerprints still on stack; 
v ;Unload NULL and restore N as Negate.;                   &lt;
  &gt;0"detcelfer daolnu LLUN :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@
&gt;#^)                                     v
v                                        &lt;
   &gt;0a"detcelfer N :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@
&gt;7#^N7." detageN"7k," si"2k,.a,          v

v ;Unload TOYS and restore N as Not;     &lt;
  &gt;0"detcelfer daolnu SYOT :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@
&gt;#^)                                     v
v                                        &lt;
   &gt;0"detcelfer N :DAB"&gt;:#,_$@
&gt;7#^N7." toN"3k," si"2k,.a,0a"gnixim tnirpregnif"&gt;:#,_$@
</pre>
<p>Sample run:
</p>
<pre>prompt$ cfunge fingerprint.b98 
7 Not is -8 
7 Negated is -7 
1 1314212940 GOOD: N reflected inside NULL
7 Negated is -7 
7 Not is -8 
fingerprint mixing
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello_World">Hello World</span></h3>
<pre>&lt;v"Hello World!"
 &gt;:v
 ^,_@
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="alt">alt</span></h4>
<p>By <a href="/wiki/User:Hammy" title="User:Hammy">User:Hammy</a>. He made this while thinking "hmm, what if the <a href="/wiki/Fish#Hello,_world!" title="Fish">hello world program in &gt;&lt;&gt;</a> was recreated in funge-98?".
</p>
<pre>v&gt;,vzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz
&lt;|:&lt;"Hello, world!"0
@&lt;zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Display_y_sysinfo">Display y sysinfo</span></h3>
<p>Works with Befunge and Trefunge, but not Unefunge. Requires BOOL fingerprint support.
</p>
<pre>v                                   &gt;'t,v   &gt;'i,v   &gt;'o,v   &gt;'=,v
&gt;"LOOB"4#v($$0y0" stroppus"&gt;:#,_$:1A|   &gt;:2A|   &gt;:4A|   &gt;:8A|   &gt;$a,v
         &gt;0a"LOOB on"&gt;:#,_1y.@      &gt;   ^   &gt;   ^   &gt;   ^   &gt;   ^
v           ,a.,k7"version ",a.,k9"handprint ",a,kd"bytes per cell".&lt;
&gt;" cexe"4k,:3-#v_"llehs emas"9k,          v
               &gt;:2-#v_"llehs emos"9k,     v
                    &gt;:1-#v_"metsys"5k,    v
                         &gt;"elbaliavanu"ak,v
v               ,a,,ke"path separator ",a$&lt;
&gt;" )snoisnemid( ezis rotcev"55*1-k,.a,                  v
v,a.k-1y7,kb"IP location ",a.,k7"team id ",a.,k5"IP id "&lt;
&gt;" atled"5k,7y1-k.a," tesffo"6k,7y1-k.a,  v
v,a.k-1y7,k7"largest ",a.k-1y7,k6"origin "&lt;
&gt;" raey"4k,:82*82**82*82***/a9+aa**+.   v
v./**28*28A*-1**28*28**28*28:,k5"month "&lt;
&gt;" yad"3k,82*82**1-A.        v
v./***28*28**28*28:,k4"hour "&lt;
&gt;" etunim"6k,:82*82**82*82**1-*A82*82**/.vv                 &lt;
v               ,a.A-1**28*28,k6"second "&lt;  &gt;'",&gt;:#,_$'",' ,^
v              v-1.\_$a," enil-dnammoc"ck,&gt;:|  &gt;          #v^#               &lt;
&gt;" skcats"6k,:.&gt;   :^                       &gt;$:|             &gt;'",&gt;:#,_$'",' ,^
                                               &gt;a," vne"3k,&gt;:|   &gt;           ^
                                                             &gt;$:#^_a,@
;display Funge-98 y sysinfo; BOOL fingerprint required;
</pre>
<p>Sample outputs (environment space display elided):
</p>
<h4><span id="cfunge_.28sandbox.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="cfunge_(sandbox)">cfunge (sandbox)</span></h4>
<pre>prompt$ cfunge -S sysinfo.b98  'a b c' a b c
supports t
8 bytes per cell
handprint 1128682830
version 90
exec unavailable
path separator /
vector size (dimensions) 2
IP id 0
team id 0
IP location 1 14
delta 0 1
offset 0 0
origin 0 0
largest 23 77
year 2017 month 7 day 31 hour 20 minute 22 second 49
stacks 1 0
command-line "sysinfo.b98" "a b c" "a" "b" "c"
env "COLORTERM=truecolor" "LC_TIME=en_CA.utf8" ... "SHELL=/bin/bash"
</pre>
<h4><span id="rcfunge_.28in_Trefunge_mode.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="rcfunge_(in_Trefunge_mode)">rcfunge (in Trefunge mode)</span></h4>
<pre>prompt$ rcfunge -3 sysinfo.b98  'a b c' a b c
supports tio=
4 bytes per cell
handprint 1380143957
version 20300
exec same shell
path separator /
vector size (dimensions) 3
IP id 0
team id 0
IP location 0 5 14
delta 0 0 1
offset 0 0 0
origin 0 0 0
largest 0 23 77    
year 2017 month 7 day 31 hour 16 minute 35 second 1
stacks 1 0
command-line "sysinfo.b98" "a b c" "a" "b" "c"
env "COLORTERM=truecolor" ... "MANPATH=/usr/local/share/man:" "XDG_VTNR=1"

VM sysinfo.b98 ended
  Instructions Executed: 35148 in 35174 cycles
        Execution time : 0.04   seconds
Instructions per second: 799654.19 
Exiting with return code = 0
</pre>
<h3><span id="Rock_Scissors_Paper.2C_on_3"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Rock_Scissors_Paper,_on_3">Rock Scissors Paper, on 3</span></h3>
<pre>v                       &gt;  v
&gt;a"3 no"4k,1.0"1 peels"#^=$&gt;2.0"1 peels"#v=$v
          v                              &lt;  &lt;
v,k3"rock"?"srossics"7k,v
          "
          r
          e
          p
          a
          p
          "
          4
          k
          ,                                             @
          v             &lt;                          &gt;'y-#^_a,0by-8-0ay-x
&gt;         &gt;0"2 peels"#v=$&gt;a," ?niaga yalp"ack,&gt;~:a-|
                      &gt;  ^                    ^ $  &lt;
Rock Scissors Paper, on 3
</pre>
<p>Plays a game of Rock Scissors Paper with delay count (if system exec "=" is supported, if not, computer player displays choice immediately).
Any response to play again? other than 'y' will terminate game.  Any buffered newlines are eaten.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<p>The <a class="external text" href="http://catseye.tc/node/Befunge-98" rel="nofollow">Funge-98</a> specification was written by Chris Pressey of Cat's Eye Technologies.  Chris invented the original <a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a> back in 1993.
</p><p><i>Incomplete list</i>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Name
</th>
<th>Author(s)
</th>
<td>Source
</td>
<td>License
</td>
<th>Commentary
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="http://catseye.tc/node/FBBI" rel="nofollow">FBBI</a>, Flaming Bovine Befunge-98 Interpreter
</td>
<td>Chris Pressey, inventor of Befunge
</td>
<td>C
</td>
<td><a class="external text" href="http://catseye.tc/node/BSD_license" rel="nofollow">BSD license</a>
</td>
<td>First implementation of Befunge-98. Not a reference implementation, but probably mistakenly used as a reference on at least one occasion.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Deewiant/CCBI" rel="nofollow">CCBI</a>, Conforming Concurrent Befunge-98 Interpreter
</td>
<td>Matti Niemenmaa (Deewiant)
</td>
<td>D 1.0
</td>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Deewiant/CCBI/blob/master/license.txt" rel="nofollow">BSD (with Tango)</a>
</td>
<td>Deewiant is also the author of the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Deewiant/Mycology" rel="nofollow">Mycology</a> Funge-98 verification suite.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/cfunge" rel="nofollow">cfunge</a>
</td>
<td>Arvid Norlander, (VorpalBlade)
</td>
<td>C
</td>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/cfunge/blob/master/COPYING" rel="nofollow">GPL v3</a>
</td>
<td>A complete Funge-98 interpreter, many fingerprints supported.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220426161352/http://rcfunge98.com/index.html" rel="nofollow">rcfunge</a>
</td>
<td>Michael Riley, Susan now listed as maintainer
</td>
<td>C
</td>
<td>Free for non commercial use
</td>
<td>Rc/Funge-98 is the source of many of the known Funge fingerprints.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://bitbucket.org/Pietu1998/jsfunge-98" rel="nofollow">jsfunge</a>
</td>
<td>Pietu1998
</td>
<td>ECMAScript, HTML, CSS
</td>
<td><i>Unknown</i>
</td>
<td>In browser Funge-98 interpreter.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/efunge" rel="nofollow">efunge</a>
</td>
<td>Arvid Norlander, (VorpalBlade)
</td>
<td>Erlang
</td>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/efunge/blob/master/COPYING" rel="nofollow">GPL v3</a>
</td>
<td>An Erlang based interpreter by the author of <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/cfunge" rel="nofollow">cfunge</a>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://bitbucket.org/lifthrasiir/pyfunge/" rel="nofollow">pyfunge</a>
</td>
<td>Kang Seonghoon
</td>
<td>Python
</td>
<td>permissive MIT/X11
</td>
<td>Documentation hosted at <a class="external free" href="https://pythonhosted.org/PyFunge/" rel="nofollow">https://pythonhosted.org/PyFunge/</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/palfrey/clostridium" rel="nofollow">Clostridium</a>
</td>
<td>Tom Parker
</td>
<td>Clojure
</td>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/palfrey/Clostridium/blob/master/LICENSE" rel="nofollow">AGPLv3</a>
</td>
<td>Development <a class="external text" href="http://tech.labs.oliverwyman.com/blog/2012/08/25/tdd-for-esoteric-programming-languages-using-clojure-and-befunge/" rel="nofollow">article</a>.
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fungewars" title="Fungewars">Fungewars</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fungeoid" title="Fungeoid">Fungeoid</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://catseye.tc/node/Funge-98" rel="nofollow">Funge-98 entry at Cat's Eye Technologies</a></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://codeberg.org/catseye/Funge-98/src/branch/master/doc/funge98.markdown" rel="nofollow">Funge-98 specification</a></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://quadium.net/funge/" rel="nofollow">vsync's Funge stuff.</a></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.iki.fi/deewiant/" rel="nofollow">Mycology and CCBI</a> A complete Befunge-98 test suite based on the specification, and an interpreter which passes all the tests.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.lshift.net/blog/2012/08/25/tdd-for-esoteric-programming-languages-using-clojure-and-befunge" rel="nofollow">Closidrium</a> - Author retrospective of creating a Befunge-98 Interpreter in Clojure.</li></ul>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/tngreene/BefungeSharp" rel="nofollow">BefungeSharp</a> A Funge-98 IDE being written in C#. Designed to have a strong editor and a complaint interpreter. Currently in development and well supported by its author.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070322234225/http://www.teepop.net/fungus/" rel="nofollow">Fungus</a> <i>(from the <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="wikipedia:Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>; retrieved on 22 March 2007)</i> - a nice Befunge-98 IDE for Win32.  Warning: its interperter is not fully standards compliant.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060925154455/http://kotisivu.mtv3.fi/quux/befunge.html" rel="nofollow">mooz' Befunge page</a> <i>(from the <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="wikipedia:Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>; retrieved on 25 September 2006)</i> - contains a Javascript interpreter and several interesting Befunge programs.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.purplehatstands.com/bequnge" rel="nofollow">BeQunge</a> A cross-platform Funge-98 interpreter, code editor, and debugger. Works in any number of dimensions.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.quote-egnufeb-quote-greaterthan-colon-hash-comma-underscore-at.info/befunge/" rel="nofollow">J^4: Befunge</a> Jeffrey Lee's Befunge site, features plenty of interesting programs.</li></ul>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/cfunge" rel="nofollow">cfunge</a> - Small fast Befunge-98 interpreter in C, standard compliant.  Updated from <a class="external text" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/cfunge" rel="nofollow">SourceForge</a></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/VorpalBlade/efunge" rel="nofollow">efunge</a> - Erlang implementation of Befunge-98, standard compliant. Has an experimental branch with a fingerprint for asynchronous threading.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220426161352/http://rcfunge98.com/index.html" rel="nofollow">Rc/Funge-98</a> - rcfunge, implementation in C, diagnostics, tutorials and documentation. Very complete; Une, Be, Tre, including the Time Travel fingerprint.
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/kronosta/rcfunge/tree/main" rel="nofollow">Archive</a> of the above hosted on Github</li></ul></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://cubonegro.orgfree.com/sponge/sponge.html" rel="nofollow">Sponge</a> - a compiler (in Common Lisp) from a tiny subset of Scheme to Befunge 98.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://mearie.org/projects/pyfunge/" rel="nofollow">PyFunge</a> - A Befunge-93/Funge-98 interpreter in Python. Its goal is a fully functional, compliant and optimizing implementation of Funge-98.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://hackage.haskell.org/package/Fungi" rel="nofollow">Fungi</a> - A standards compliant Funge-98 interpreter and debugger written in Haskell.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/TieSoul/Multilang" rel="nofollow">Multilang</a> - A shell supporting multiple languages, including Befunge-98.</li></ul>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/electrodude/fungewars" rel="nofollow">Fungewars</a> - A programming game in Funge-98.</li></ul>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://purkka.codes/jsfunge-98/befunge98.html" rel="nofollow">purkka.codes interpreter</a></li></ul>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><dl><dd></dd>
<dd><span class="dablink"><i>Not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">&gt;&lt;&gt;</a>.</i></span></dd></dl>
<p><b>Fysh</b> is an esoteric programming language that embraces creativity and a playful aquatic theme. It uses fish-related symbols and terms to represent programming concepts, making coding a fun and engaging experience. It was invented by <a href="/wiki/User:Pointless" title="User:Pointless">User:Pointless</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/User:PinesLover69" title="User:PinesLover69">User:PinesLover69</a> in 2024.
</p><p>For a cleaner documentation check out the <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Fysh-Fyve/fysh/tree/master/pkg/go-fysh#readme" rel="nofollow">GitHub README</a>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<h2><span id=".F0.9F.91.A9.E2.80.8D.F0.9F.92.BB_How_to_Compile_and_Run_Fysh"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="👩‍💻_How_to_Compile_and_Run_Fysh">👩‍💻 How to Compile and Run Fysh</span></h2>
<h3><span id=".E2.9A.99.EF.B8.8F_Option_1:_Using_The_Online_Interpreter"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="⚙️_Option_1:_Using_The_Online_Interpreter">⚙️ Option 1: Using The Online Interpreter</span></h3>
<p>1. <b>Visit The Official Webpage</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Visit Fysh's official webpage at: <a class="external free" href="https://fysh-fyve.github.io/" rel="nofollow">https://fysh-fyve.github.io/</a></li></ul>
<p>2. <b>Press Play</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Write your code and press the swim button</li></ul>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".E2.9A.99.EF.B8.8F_Option_2:_Using_VSCode"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="⚙️_Option_2:_Using_VSCode">⚙️ Option 2: Using VSCode</span></h3>
<p>1. <b>Download the Fysh VSCode Extension</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Install the Fysh extension from the VSCode marketplace.</li></ul>
<p>2. <b>Create a <code>.fysh</code> File</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Open VSCode and create a new file with the extension <code>.fysh</code>.</li></ul>
<p>3. <b>Write Your Code</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Start coding in Fysh!</li></ul>
<p>4. <b>Run Your Code</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Press the run button provided by the extension to execute your program.</li></ul>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".E2.9A.99.EF.B8.8F_Option_3:_Using_Command_Line"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="⚙️_Option_3:_Using_Command_Line">⚙️ Option 3: Using Command Line</span></h3>
<p>1. <b>Install the Latest Version of Fysh</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Use the Go command to install Fysh:</li></ul>
<pre>go install github.com/Fysh-Fyve/fysh/pkg/go-fysh/cmd@latest</pre>
<p>2. <b>Execute Your Fysh Program</b>
</p>
<ul><li>Run your program using the generated Fysh interpreter:</li></ul>
<pre>fysh &lt;filename&gt;.fysh</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h2><span id=".F0.9F.90.99_Fyshing_Manual"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🐙_Fyshing_Manual">🐙 Fyshing Manual</span></h2>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.92.AC_Chapter_1:_Comments"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="💬_Chapter_1:_Comments">💬 Chapter 1: Comments</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.94.89_Single-line_Comments"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔉_Single-line_Comments">🔉 Single-line Comments</span></h4>
<p>Single-line comments start with navigator fish <code>&gt;&lt;//&gt;</code>.
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;//&gt; What's cookin' good lookin'?
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.94.8A_Multi-line_Comments"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔊_Multi-line_Comments">🔊 Multi-line Comments</span></h4>
<p>For longer explanations, multiline comments are used. They are enclosed with
<code>&gt;&lt;/*&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;*\&gt;&lt;</code>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;/*&gt;
How to grill a Fysh:
1. Catch a Fysh
2. Grill the Fysh
3. Eat the Fysh
&lt;*/&gt;&lt;
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.90.A0_Chapter_2:_Fysh_Syntax"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🐠_Chapter_2:_Fysh_Syntax">🐠 Chapter 2: Fysh Syntax</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.90.9F_Variables"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🐟_Variables">🐟 Variables</span></h4>
<p>In Fysh, variables are declared using the syntax <code>&gt;&lt;variableName&gt;</code>. Every line of Fysh code ends with a tilde <code>~</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;Steven&gt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.91.89.F0.9F.8F.BB_Assigning_Values"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="👉🏻_Assigning_Values">👉🏻 Assigning Values</span></h4>
<p>Variables can be assigned values using either the <code>≈</code> or <code>=</code> operator.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
<code>Steven</code> is assigned the value of <code>CoolFysh</code>:
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;Steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;CoolFysh&gt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.94.9F_Binary_Scales"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔟_Binary_Scales">🔟 Binary Scales</span></h4>
<p>A fysh's scales represents it's binary value <code>&gt;&lt;})}&gt;</code>:
</p>
<ul><li><b>Scales Representing Binary 1:</b> <code>{</code> and <code>}</code></li>
<li><b>Scales Representing Binary 0:</b> <code>(</code> and <code>)</code></li></ul>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> The direction of the scales does not matter. <code>{</code> and <code>}</code> both represent binary <code>1</code>, and <code>(</code> and <code>)</code> both represent binary <code>0</code>.</dd></dl>
<p><b>Example:</b>
</p><p>Here we assign the binary value <code>0b101</code> (5 in decimal) to <code>Steven</code>:
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;})}&gt; ~ 
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.91.81.EF.B8.8F_Optional_Visuals"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="👁️_Optional_Visuals">👁️ Optional Visuals</span></h4>
<p><code>&gt;&lt;})}&gt;</code> is blind, but we can give it eyes... multiple eyes! 🐟👀
</p><p><b>Valid Eye Symbols:</b> <code>o</code>, <code>°</code>
</p>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> This is completely optional and purely for aesthetics.</dd></dl>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;})}°&gt;   ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt;   ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({o&gt;   ~ 
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({°°&gt;  ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({o°&gt;  ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;}({°o°&gt; ~
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".E2.9E.95_Chapter_3:_Arithmetics"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="➕_Chapter_3:_Arithmetics">➕ Chapter 3: Arithmetics</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".E2.9E.95_Addition"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="➕_Addition">➕ Addition</span></h4>
<p>To add two fyshes, place variables or values next to each other. The value of a school of Fysh is the sum of each member. 
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
steven = 4 + 1 (binary: <code>0b100</code> + <code>0b001</code>)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{((°&gt; &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~
</pre>
<p>In this example:
</p>
<ul><li><code>&gt;&lt;{((°&gt;</code> represents <code>0b100</code> (4)</li>
<li><code>&gt;&lt;(({°&gt;</code> represents <code>0b001</code> (1)</li>
<li><code>steven</code> is assigned <code>4 + 1 = 5</code></li></ul>
<h4><span id=".E2.9E.96_Subtraction"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="➖_Subtraction">➖ Subtraction</span></h4>
<p>Some fysh are negative and start to swim away. Fysh swimming to the left take away from the school's value.
</p>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> Fysh swim to the left flips the sign of the fysh. So a negative variable swimming left will become positive.</dd></dl>
<p><b>Example:</b>
steven = 7 - 2 (binary: <code>0b111</code> * <code>0b010</code>)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt; &lt;°)})&gt;&lt; ~ 
</pre>
<h4><span id=".E2.9D.A4.EF.B8.8F_Multiplication"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="❤️_Multiplication">❤️ Multiplication</span></h4>
<p>Fysh often get lonely. This loneliness causes fysh to meet new fysh and proliferate, quickly multiplying their numbers.
</p>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> Every possible representation of a heart is valid for multiplication. If there's a heart that doesn't work, please let us know.</dd></dl>
<p><b>Example:</b>
steven = 6 * 7 (binary: <code>0b110</code> * <code>0b111</code>)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; = &gt;&lt;{{(°&gt; &lt;3 &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt; ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{{(°&gt; ♡ &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt; ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{{(°&gt; 💘 &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.92.94_Division"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="💔_Division">💔 Division</span></h4>
<p>Not every fysh story is a happy one. At times, separation is inevitable, and their division breaks their hearts, causing their numbers to dwindle.
Division is represented by a broken heart <code>&lt;/3</code> or <code>💔</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
Steven = 25 / 5 (binary: <code>0b11001</code> / <code>0b101</code>)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{{(({°&gt; &lt;/3 &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{{(({°&gt; 💔 &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.8E.A3_Fysh_Bowls_.28Parentheses.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🎣_Fysh_Bowls_(Parentheses)">🎣 Fysh Bowls (Parentheses)</span></h4>
<p>Fysh are often abducted and kept in small glass fysh bowls for the amusement of land-dwellers. These bowls are represented by <code>( )</code>.
This is used to group fysh together, allowing their operations to be performed first.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
steven = 5 / (5 * 4) (binary: <code>0b101</code> / (<code>0b101</code> * <code>0b100</code>))
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; 💔 ( &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; &lt;°}))&gt;&lt; ) ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.93.88_Increment"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📈_Increment">📈 Increment</span></h4>
<p>As life goes on, we learn from our mistakes and improve.
Steven’s self help journey allowed them to grow an extra tail, incrementing
their value by 1.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
steven = steven + 1
</p>
<pre>&gt;&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.93.89_Decrement"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📉_Decrement">📉 Decrement</span></h4>
<p>Sometimes we feel like a fyshup, a failure. And that's ok, it’s
a part of being fysh. However for some fysh, this feeling is too much to
handle and is internalized. They haven’t received the emotional support they
need and have gone on a downward spiral, causing them to feel worthless. They
begin to retreat and try to swim away in the opposite direction causing their
value to decrement by 1.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
steven = steven - 1
</p>
<pre>&lt;steven&gt;&lt;&lt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.8D.A2_Random_Number_Generation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🍢_Random_Number_Generation">🍢 Random Number Generation</span></h4>
<p>The random number generator is represented with a grilled fysh. It generates a random signed 32-bit number that determines the doneness of the fysh.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;###&gt; ~
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.93.8A_Chapter_4:_Data_Types"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📊_Chapter_4:_Data_Types">📊 Chapter 4: Data Types</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.93.8F_Integers"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📏_Integers">📏 Integers</span></h4>
<p>Fysh with binary scales <code>&gt;&lt;})}&gt;</code> are integers.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
Steven = 5 (binary: <code>0b101</code>)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.A6.B4_Floats_with_One_Bone"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🦴_Floats_with_One_Bone">🦴 Floats with One Bone</span></h4>
<p>Some people like to play with their food, so they pick away at steven, leaving only a fraction of them behind. This exposes the bones (<code>-</code>) of the fysh. Bones help to separate the integer and decimal parts of the fysh.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{{{-{({°&gt; ~
</pre>
<p>Explanation:
</p>
<ul><li><code>&gt;&lt;{{{-</code> represents the integer part <code>7</code> (binary: <code>0b111</code>)</li>
<li><code>-{({°&gt;</code> represents the fractional part <code>0.5</code> (binary: <code>0b101</code>)</li>
<li>Steven's value is <code>7 + 0.5 = 7.5</code>.</li></ul>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.A6.B4.F0.9F.A6.B4.F0.9F.A6.B4_Floats_with_Multiple_Bones"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🦴🦴🦴_Floats_with_Multiple_Bones">🦴🦴🦴 Floats with Multiple Bones</span></h4>
<p>When multiple bones are present, the additonal values are added at the end of the decimal part. Steven's value is <code>2 + 0.15 + 0.005 = 15.155</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{(-{{{{-{{{°&gt; ~
</pre>
<p>Explanation:
</p>
<ul><li><code>&gt;&lt;{(-</code> represents the integer part <code>2</code> (binary: <code>0b10</code>)</li>
<li><code>-{{{{-</code> represents the fractional part <code>0.15</code> (binary: <code>0b1111</code>)</li>
<li><code>-{{{°&gt;</code> represents the additional fractional part <code>0.007</code> (binary: <code>0b111</code>)</li>
<li>steven's value is <code>2 + 0.15 + 0.007 = 2.157</code>.</li></ul>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.AB.A7_Bubbles_.28Strings.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🫧_Bubbles_(Strings)">🫧 Bubbles (Strings)</span></h4>
<p>Fysh blow bubbles, and these bubbles can be used to represent strings. 
Bubble strings are enclosed in <code>🫧</code> or <code>*</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ 🫧Hello, World!🫧 ~
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; = *Hello, World!* ~
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.93.A6_Arrays_and_Traversal"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📦_Arrays_and_Traversal">📦 Arrays and Traversal</span></h4>
<p>Arrays are represented by a fysh tank <code>[ ]</code>. Each item is separated
by fysh food <code>*</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
steven = [6,2] (binary: <code>[0b110, 0b010]</code>)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ [&gt;&lt;{{(°&gt; * &gt;&lt;({(°&gt;] ~
</pre>
<p>To access array elements, use the array variable followed by <code>[index]</code>.
</p>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> Array indexes start at 0.</dd></dl>
<p><b>Example:</b>
steven[1] (accessing the second element of steven)
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt;[&gt;&lt;(({°&gt;] ~
</pre>
<h3><span id=".E2.9A.93_Chapter_5:_Output"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="⚓_Chapter_5:_Output">⚓ Chapter 5: Output</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".E2.9B.93.EF.B8.8F_Output_Value"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="⛓️_Output_Value">⛓️ Output Value</span></h4>
<p>To output the value of a variable, use an anchor <code>(+o</code> or <code>⚓</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
Output the value of <code>Steven</code>:
</p>
<pre>(+o &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.A7.A0_Chapter_6:_Fysh_Logic_and_Operations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🧠_Chapter_6:_Fysh_Logic_and_Operations">🧠 Chapter 6: Fysh Logic and Operations</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.90.B8_Tadpoles"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🐸_Tadpoles">🐸 Tadpoles</span></h4>
<p>The greater than and less than operations are represented by tadpoles <code>~o</code> and <code>o~</code>. Tadpoles swim towards the bigger Fysh, indicating the direction of the comparison.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;//&gt; Greater/Less than
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; o~ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~    &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven &gt; 1
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~o &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt; ~    &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven &lt; 7

&gt;&lt;//&gt; Greater/Less than or equal to (replace ~ with ≈ or =)
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; o≈ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~    &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven &gt;= 1
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; =o &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt; ~    &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven &lt;= 7
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.A4.94_Logical_Operations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🤔_Logical_Operations">🤔 Logical Operations</span></h4>
<p>Fysh supports standard logical operations:
</p>
<ul><li><b>AND</b>: <code>&amp;&amp;</code></li>
<li><b>OR</b>: <code>||</code></li>
<li><b>NOT</b>: <code>!!</code></li></ul>
<p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; &amp;&amp; &gt;&lt;Alive&gt; ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven and Alive
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; || &gt;&lt;Alive&gt; ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven or Alive
!! &gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~            &gt;&lt;//&gt; Not Steven
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.94.A7_Bitwise_Operations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔧_Bitwise_Operations">🔧 Bitwise Operations</span></h4>
<p>Steven is bored and looking to have their bits rearranged. At Fysh, we're
here to help! Steven has been provided with a variety of tools and bitwise
manipulations to satisfy their bit busting needs:
</p>
<ul><li><code>AND (&amp;)</code></li>
<li><code>OR (|)</code></li>
<li><code>XOR (^)</code></li>
<li><code>NOT (!)</code></li></ul>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> Currently does not support floats</dd></dl>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; &amp; &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~  &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven and 1
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; | &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~  &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven or 1
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ^ &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~  &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven xor 1
! &gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~          &gt;&lt;//&gt; Not Steven
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.94.84_Logical_Shift_Operations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔄_Logical_Shift_Operations">🔄 Logical Shift Operations</span></h4>
<p>You can even use logical shifts! Steven shifts their
bits to the left then right by 1.
</p>
<ul><li><b>Left shift (<code>&lt;&lt;</code>):</b></li>
<li><b>Right shift (<code>&gt;&gt;</code>):</b></li></ul>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> Currently does not support floats</dd></dl>
<p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;steven&gt; &lt;&lt; &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven left shift 1
&gt;&lt;steven&gt; &gt;&gt; &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; Steven right shift 1
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.94.84_Chapter_7:_Control_Structures"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔄_Chapter_7:_Control_Structures">🔄 Chapter 7: Control Structures</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.94.81_While_Loops"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔁_While_Loops">🔁 While Loops</span></h4>
<p>While loops can be represented using whirlpools:
</p>
<ul><li><code>@</code></li>
<li><code>🌀</code></li>
<li><code>&gt;&lt;(((@&gt;</code></li></ul>
<p>The condition stored in either:
</p>
<ul><li><code>( )</code> fysh bowl</li>
<li><code>[ ]</code> fysh tank</li></ul>
<p>The loop body is enclosed between <code>&gt;&lt;&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;&gt;&lt;</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>🌀 [&gt;&lt;steven&gt; o~ &gt;&lt;{((°&gt;]            &gt;&lt;//&gt; while steven &gt; 4
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &lt;steven&gt;&lt;&lt; ~                    &gt;&lt;//&gt; steven--
&lt;&gt;&lt;

@ (&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~o &gt;&lt;{((°&gt;)            &gt;&lt;//&gt; while steven &lt; 4
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &gt;&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~                    &gt;&lt;//&gt; steven++
&lt;&gt;&lt;

&gt;&lt;(((@&gt; [&gt;&lt;steven&gt; o≈ &gt;&lt;{((°&gt;]      &gt;&lt;//&gt; while steven &gt;= 4
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &lt;steven&gt;&lt;&lt; ~                    &gt;&lt;//&gt; steven--
&lt;&gt;&lt;
</pre>
<h4><span id=".E2.9D.93_Conditional_Statements"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="❓_Conditional_Statements">❓ Conditional Statements</span></h4>
<p>Conditional statements run based on how each Fysh feels
</p>
<h5><span id=".F0.9F.98.8A_if_Statements:_The_Happy_Fysh_.3E.3C.28.28.28.5E.3E"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="😊_if_Statements:_The_Happy_Fysh_&gt;&lt;(((^&gt;">😊 <code>if</code> Statements: The Happy Fysh <code>&gt;&lt;(((^&gt;</code></span></h5>
<p>These Fysh are overjoyed because they're the center of attention—they feel wanted and loved.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;(((^&gt; [&gt;&lt;steven&gt; o~ &gt;&lt;{((°&gt;]     &gt;&lt;//&gt; if steven &gt; 4
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &lt;steven&gt;&lt;&lt; ~                   &gt;&lt;//&gt; steven--
&lt;&gt;&lt;
</pre>
<h5><span id=".F0.9F.98.B5_else_Statement:_The_Sad_.28Dead.29_Fysh_.3E.3C.28.28.28.2A.3E"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="😵_else_Statement:_The_Sad_(Dead)_Fysh_&gt;&lt;(((*&gt;">😵 <code>else</code> Statement: The Sad (Dead) Fysh <code>&gt;&lt;(((*&gt;</code></span></h5>
<p>These fysh feel like they're an afterthought and are often left behind. This makes them feel sad and dead inside.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;(((*&gt;                      &gt;&lt;//&gt; else
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &gt;&lt;steven&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;(((°&gt; ~    &gt;&lt;//&gt; steven = 0
&lt;&gt;&lt;
</pre>
<h5><span id=".F0.9F.98.90_else_if_Statement:_The_Middle_Child_.3E.3C.28.28.28.2A.3E_.3E.3C.28.28.28.5E.3E"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="😐_else_if_Statement:_The_Middle_Child_&gt;&lt;(((*&gt;_&gt;&lt;(((^&gt;">😐 <code>else if</code> Statement: The Middle Child <code>&gt;&lt;(((*&gt; &gt;&lt;(((^&gt;</code></span></h5>
<p>These fysh are a combination of a dead and a happy fish, symbolizing the middle child. Not the first choice but not the last.
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;(((*&gt; &gt;&lt;(((^&gt; [&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~o &gt;&lt;{((°&gt;]     &gt;&lt;//&gt; else if steven &lt; 4
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &gt;&gt;&lt;steven&gt; ~                           &gt;&lt;//&gt; steven++
&lt;&gt;&lt;
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.A7.91.E2.80.8D.F0.9F.94.A7_Chapter_8:_Functions"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🧑‍🔧_Chapter_8:_Functions">🧑‍🔧 Chapter 8: Functions</span></h3>
<h4><span id=".E2.9C.8F.EF.B8.8F_Defining_Functions"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="✏️_Defining_Functions">✏️ Defining Functions</span></h4>
<p>Functions (subroutines) are defined using a submarine <code>&gt;(functionName)</code>, with parameters <code>&gt;&lt;param&gt;</code>. The function body is enclosed between <code>&gt;&lt;&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;&gt;&lt;</code>. To return a value, use a squid <code>&lt;~</code> or <code>🦑</code>.
</p><p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>&gt;(add) &gt;&lt;param1&gt; &gt;&lt;param2&gt;       &gt;&lt;//&gt; def add(param1, param2)
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &lt;~ &gt;&lt;param1&gt; ♡ &gt;&lt;param2&gt; ~  &gt;&lt;//&gt; Return the product of param1 and param2
&lt;&gt;&lt;
</pre>
<h4><span id=".F0.9F.93.9E_Calling_Functions"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📞_Calling_Functions">📞 Calling Functions</span></h4>
<p>To call a function, place the submarine in a fish tank <code>[ ]</code>, along with its arguments, separated by fish food <code>-</code>.
</p>
<dl><dd><b>Note:</b> The submarine can be placed anywhere in the fish tank as long as the arguments are in the correct order.</dd></dl>
<p><b>Example:</b>
</p>
<pre>[&gt;(submarine) &gt;&lt;fysh1&gt; * &gt;&lt;fysh2&gt;] ~     &gt;&lt;//&gt; submarine(fysh1, fysh2)
</pre>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h2><span id=".F0.9F.93.88_Examples"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="📈_Examples">📈 Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span id=".E2.9D.97Factorial_Example"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="❗Factorial_Example">❗Factorial Example</span></h3>
<p>This program calculates the factorial of a number, in this case, 5. The factorial of 5 is 120.
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;//&gt; Factorial Example

&gt;&lt;number&gt;    ≈ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~                        &gt;&lt;//&gt; number = 5
&gt;&lt;factorial&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~                        &gt;&lt;//&gt; factorial = 1

🌀 [&gt;&lt;number&gt; o~ &gt;&lt;(({°&gt;]
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &gt;&lt;factorial&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;factorial&gt; ♡ &gt;&lt;number&gt; ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; factorial = factorial * number
    &lt;number&gt;&lt;&lt; ~                                &gt;&lt;//&gt; number--
&lt;&gt;&lt;

⚓ &gt;&lt;factorial&gt; ~                               &gt;&lt;//&gt; print(factorial)
</pre>
<p><b>Explanation:</b>
</p><p>1. <b>Variable Declarations:</b>
</p>
<ul><li><code>&gt;&lt;number&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;{({°&gt; ~</code> assigns 5 to <code>number</code>.</li>
<li><code>&gt;&lt;factorial&gt; ≈ &gt;&lt;(({°&gt; ~</code> assigns 1 to <code>factorial</code>.</li></ul>
<p>2. <b>While Loop:</b>
</p>
<ul><li><code>🌀 [&gt;&lt;number&gt; o~ &gt;&lt;(({°&gt;]</code> loops while <code>number</code> &gt; 1.</li>
<li>Inside the loop:
<ul><li>Multiply <code>factorial</code> by <code>number</code>.</li>
<li>Decrement <code>number</code>.</li></ul></li></ul>
<p>3. <b>Output:</b>
</p>
<ul><li><code>⚓ &gt;&lt;factorial&gt; ~</code> outputs the calculated factorial.</li></ul>
<h3><span id=".F0.9F.94.81Fibonacci_Example"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="🔁Fibonacci_Example">🔁Fibonacci Example</span></h3>
<p>This program calculates the nth Fibonacci number, in this case, the 7th. The 7th Fibonacci number is equal to 13.
</p>
<pre>&gt;&lt;//&gt; Fibonacci Example

&gt;(fib) &gt;&lt;n&gt;                            &gt;&lt;//&gt; def fib(n)
&gt;&lt;&gt;
    &gt;&lt;(((^&gt; [&gt;&lt;n&gt; ~o &gt;&lt;({(°&gt;]          &gt;&lt;//&gt; if n &lt; 2
    &gt;&lt;&gt;
        🦑 &gt;&lt;n&gt; ~                      &gt;&lt;//&gt; Return 'n' if 'n' &lt; 2
    &lt;&gt;&lt;
    &gt;&lt;(((*&gt;                            &gt;&lt;//&gt; else
    &gt;&lt;&gt;
        &gt;&lt;a&gt; ≈ [&gt;(fib) &gt;&lt;n&gt; &lt;({&gt;&lt;] ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; a = fib(n * 1)
        &gt;&lt;b&gt; ≈ [&gt;(fib) &gt;&lt;n&gt; &lt;{(&gt;&lt;] ~   &gt;&lt;//&gt; b = fib(n * 2)
        🦑 &gt;&lt;a&gt; &gt;&lt;b&gt; ~                 &gt;&lt;//&gt; Return a + b
    &lt;&gt;&lt;
&lt;&gt;&lt;

&gt;&lt;result&gt; ≈ [&gt;(fib) &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt;] ~         &gt;&lt;//&gt; result = fib(7)
⚓ &gt;&lt;result&gt; ~                         &gt;&lt;//&gt; print(result)
</pre>
<p><b>Explanation:</b>
</p><p>1. <b>Function Definition:</b>
</p>
<ul><li><code>&gt;(fib) &gt;&lt;n&gt;</code> defines the function <code>fib</code> with parameter <code>n</code>.</li>
<li>If <code>n</code> is less than 2:
<ul><li>Return <code>n</code>.</li></ul></li>
<li>Else:
<ul><li>Compute <code>a = fib(n * 1)</code>.</li>
<li>Compute <code>b = fib(n * 2)</code>.</li>
<li>Return <code>a + b</code>.</li></ul></li></ul>
<p>2. <b>Function Call:</b>
</p>
<ul><li><code>&gt;&lt;result&gt; ≈ [&gt;(fib) &gt;&lt;{{{°&gt;] ~</code> calls <code>fib(7)</code> and assigns the result to <code>result</code>. result = fib(7)</li></ul>
<p>3. <b>Output:</b>
</p>
<ul><li><code>⚓ &gt;&lt;result&gt; ~</code> outputs the 7th Fibonacci number (13).</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_Resources">External Resources</span></h2>

<hr/>
<p>Happy Fyshing! 🐟
</p>
