</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><table style="float:right;border:1px solid silver;background-color:rgb(249, 249, 249);max-width:256px;padding:5px;">
<caption><b>Game of Life</b></caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Designed by</th>
<td>Conway et al.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;"><a href="/wiki/Category:Years" title="Category:Years">Appeared in</a></th>
<td>1970</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;"><a href="/wiki/Computational_class" title="Computational class">Computational class</a></th>
<td>Turing-complete, universal</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Reference implementation</th>
<td>Unpublished code by <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_R._Bourne" title="wikipedia:Stephen R. Bourne">Steve Bourne</a> and <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Guy" title="wikipedia:Michael Guy">Michael J. T. Guy</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">File extension(s)</th>
<td><code>.cells</code>, <code>.lif</code>, <code>.life</code>, <code>.rle</code>, <code>.mc</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Game of Life</b>, also called <b>Conway's Game of Life</b> or simply <b>Life</b>, is a <a href="/wiki/Cellular_automaton" title="Cellular automaton">cellular automaton</a> first described by <a href="/wiki/John_Horton_Conway" title="John Horton Conway">John Horton Conway</a> sometime between 1968 and 1970, first documented by <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Gardner" title="wikipedia:Martin Gardner">Martin Gardner</a> in <i>Scientific American</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> and by Conway, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elwyn_Berlekamp" title="wikipedia:Elwyn Berlekamp">Elwyn Berlekamp</a>, and <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_K._Guy" title="wikipedia:Richard K. Guy">Richard K. Guy</a> in <i>Winning Ways for Your Mathematical Plays</i>. It is notable for its complex and diverse emergent behavior compared to other cellular automata, despite the simplicity of its definition, and the relative ease in which powerful artificial constructions (such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_machines" title="Turing machines">Turing machines</a>) can be constructed within it.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Description"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Description</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Complexity_class"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Complexity class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>Conway originally discovered the precise rules of Life while searching for universal cellular automata over low-dimensional grids. At the time, Conway was following the research programme established by <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislaw_Ulam" title="wikipedia:Stanislaw Ulam">Stanislaw Ulam</a> and <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="wikipedia:John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a> in the late 1940s concerning self-replicating machines; a <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Universal_constructor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Universal constructor (page does not exist)">universal constructor</a> would allow arbitrary constructions including constructing copies of itself, and Von Neumann had already shown the theoretical feasibility of the approach by proposing the <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Neumann_universal_constructor" title="wikipedia:Von Neumann universal constructor">Von Neumann universal constructor</a>.
</p><p>In an informal sense, the idea of studying the Game of Life is to show that self-sustaining patterns, indefinite growth, and other substrate-agnostic definitions of <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/life" title="wikipedia:life">wikipedia:life</a> could arise from relatively easy-to-describe systems. In support of that line of thinking, there has been a stream of theorems showing that Life is — depending on definitions — alive:
</p><p><b>Construction (glider).</b> There is a <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/spaceship" title="life:spaceship">spaceship</a>: a pattern which <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/translation_(geometry)" title="wikipedia:translation (geometry)">translates</a> across the grid. Moreover, its rate of travel is one cell per four generations, or <i>c</i>/4, and its slope is 1. (R. K. Guy, 1969)
</p><p>Conway would name Guy's spaceship the <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/glider" title="life:glider">"glider"</a> and it would become a symbol for Life. In 1970, Conway asked whether there were any patterns that grew without bound, and Gosper responded in November 1970 that there is a pattern which is endlessly productive and can't be contained in any finite bounding box:
</p><p><b>Construction (<a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/Gosper_glider_gun" title="life:Gosper glider gun">Gosper glider gun</a>).</b> There is a <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/gun" title="life:gun">gun</a> of gliders. (<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gosper" title="wikipedia:Bill Gosper">Gosper</a>, 1970)
</p><p><b>Theorem.</b> There exist spaceships of every rational slope. (Berlekamp, 1982, <i>Winning Ways</i>)
</p><p><b>Theorem (<a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing completeness</a>).</b> There is a universal computer with finitely many alive cells. (Conway, 1982, <i>Winning Ways</i>)
</p><p><b>Theorem.</b> There is a universal constructor with finitely many alive cells. (Conway, 1982, <i>Winning Ways</i>)
</p><p><b>Construction (Gemini).</b> There is an <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/oblique_spaceship" title="life:oblique spaceship">oblique spaceship</a>: a spaceship which neither moves in a straight line nor has a slope of 1. Moreover, its slope is 1/5. (A. J. Wade, 2010)
</p><p>The details of Gemini's construction offer a potential way to fulfill Berlekamp's theorem, as discussed <a class="external text" href="https://conwaylife.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=2&amp;t=399" rel="nofollow">here</a>.
</p><p><b>Construction (<a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/reverse_caber-tosser" title="life:reverse caber-tosser">reverse caber-tosser (RCT)</a>).</b> There is a universal constructor parameterized solely by the positions of a fixed number <i>N</i> of gliders. (Goucher &amp; Greene, 2018)
</p><p><b>Theorem.</b> Reverse caber-tossers are universal for <i>N</i>=329 gliders. (<a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/Goldtiger997" title="life:Goldtiger997">Goldtiger997</a>, 2018)
</p><p>As of 2022, reverse caber-tossers have been shown universal for <i>N</i>=15 by a collaborative effort.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Description">Description</span></h2>
<p>The cells of Life are a standard two-dimensional grid of squares with Boolean values, traditionally called "dead" and "alive". Each cell has a <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore_neighborhood" title="wikipedia:Moore neighborhood">Moore neighborhood</a> of eight neighboring cells. The automaton acts on all cells at once based on the number of alive cells in its Moore neighborhood and its current state: if a cell's neighborhood has three alive cells, or if it is alive and its neighborhood has two alive cells, then the automaton marks it alive; otherwise it is marked dead. As with other cellular automata, the automata's action is known as the <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/generation" title="life:generation">"generation"</a>.
</p><p>It is common to consider only states in which a finite number of cells are alive, due to the following theorems which make them easy to simulate on computers:
</p><p><b>Theorem.</b> Every generation of a starting configuration with finitely many alive cells also has finitely many alive cells. (Folklore)
</p><p><b>Theorem.</b> Every finite starting configuration has a minimal bounding box containing all alive cells. (Folklore)
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Complexity_class">Complexity class</span></h2>
<p>Conway proved that their 1982 constructions are universal computers. Several other models of computation have been directly embedded into Life since then:
</p><p><b>Construction (<a href="/wiki/Turing_machine" title="Turing machine">Turing machine</a>).</b> There are simulations of Turing machines with 3-16 symbols and 3-8 states. (<a class="external text" href="http://rendell-attic.org/gol/tm.htm" rel="nofollow">Rendell, 2000</a>)
</p><p><b>Construction (<a href="/wiki/Minsky_machine" title="Minsky machine">Minsky machine</a>).</b> There is a simulation of a Minsky machine. (<a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230115210026/http://www.igblan.free-online.co.uk/igblan/ca/" rel="nofollow">Chapman, 2002</a>)
</p><p>As such, whether certain families of starting configurations ever reach generations with certain properties is Turing-complete. In particular, any Halting problem or property subject to <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rice%27s_theorem" title="wikipedia:Rice's theorem">Rice's theorem</a> can be lifted to a property of configurations.
</p><p>However, it is not the case that any finite pattern can be constructed. There are patterns which are not a generation of any starting configuration, called <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/Garden_of_Eden" title="life:Garden of Eden">Gardens of Eden</a>:
</p><p><b>Theorem (Moore–Myhill Gardens of Eden).</b> For cellular automata like Life, Gardens of Eden exist if and only if at least two finite patterns evolve to the same configuration. (Moore, 1963; Myhill, 1963)
</p><p>Moore and Myhill were not publishing together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p><b>Theorem.</b> Life has Gardens of Eden. (<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alvy_Ray_Smith" title="wikipedia:Alvy Ray Smith">A. R. Smith</a>, 1970)
</p><p><b>Construction (Garden of Eden 1).</b> There is a Garden of Eden with bounding box 33 × 9 cells. (<a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/Edwin_Roger_Banks" title="life:Edwin Roger Banks">Banks</a> et al., 1971)
</p><p>Following this, Conway asked whether there were any configurations which could only be generated from themselves (Conway, 1972, <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/Lifeline_Volume_6" title="life:Lifeline Volume 6"><i>Lifeline Volume 6</i></a>) or still-lifes which can only be present in a generation if they were present in the initial configuration (Conway, 1992). The answer to both is yes:
</p><p><b>Construction (<a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/unique_father_problem" title="life:unique father problem">unique father problem</a>).</b> There is a pattern with bounding box 22 × 28 which must appear in any of its fathers. (Salo &amp; Törmä, 2022)
</p><p><b>Construction (<a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/unsynthesizable_oscillator_1" title="life:unsynthesizable oscillator 1">Unsynthesizable oscillator 1</a>).</b> There is a pattern with bounding box 60 × 53 which must appear in any of its ancestors. (Cunningham, 2022)
</p><p>So, while Life is capable of embedding universal computation, and many patterns are glider-constructible, there are patterns that cannot be constructed.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/1quad" title="1quad">1quad</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/APGsembly" title="APGsembly">APGsembly</a>, an assembly language created by <a class="extiw" href="https://conwaylife.com/wiki/Adam_P._Goucher" title="life:Adam P. Goucher">Adam P. Goucher</a> that can be compiled to CGoL pattern.</li></ul>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Gammaplex</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> designed by <a href="/wiki/Lode_Vandevenne" title="Lode Vandevenne">Lode Vandevenne</a>.  It is similar to <a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a> in some respects; what makes it especially remarkable is the support for mouse input and graphical output.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Hue_coloration_Mandelbrot_renderer"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Hue coloration Mandelbrot renderer</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Simple_quine"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Simple quine</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#XOR_Texture"><span class="tocnumber">1.3</span> <span class="toctext">XOR Texture</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Plasma_Effect"><span class="tocnumber">1.4</span> <span class="toctext">Plasma Effect</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Digital_Root_Calculator"><span class="tocnumber">1.5</span> <span class="toctext">Digital Root Calculator</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hue_coloration_Mandelbrot_renderer">Hue coloration Mandelbrot renderer</span></h3>
<pre>@   200)u150)l1a0#0}&gt;1a{"}4#0XG  v
Mandelbrot by       ^   v?,y(]0  &lt;
Lode Vandevenne         &gt;1a{s"sN}v
v0.1                ^    E?,h(]1R&lt;
0](y2:-1.5*0.5y*:0.5-30])        \
1](h2:-0.5h*:31])                \
32]0)u0)u0)u0)u0)                \
&gt;36](")34](32])35](33])32](w*33](\
w*-30](+34])2#32](*33](*31](+35])\
34](w*35](w*+4,?v36](16,?v7#0G   \
           G0#11&lt;        &gt;12#0G  \
&gt;255#255#36](16*H3a}PXg           
&gt;128#128#128#3a}PXg               
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Simple_quine">Simple quine</span></h3>
<p>Using the q command(By poiuy_qwert):
</p>
<pre>25)0(q0#19(?GDDXrRE(')0#3G
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="XOR_Texture">XOR Texture</span></h3>
<pre>3a&gt;(u(xww}PRd(n,?v(")         v
   By poiuy_qwert&gt;0)u(n,?E(")dv
  ^                           &lt;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Plasma_Effect">Plasma Effect</span></h3>
<pre>3a&gt;(128-w*u(128-w*+V1XT128*128+ww}PRd(n,?v(")         v
   By poiuy_qwert                        &gt;0)u(n,?E(")dv
  ^                                                   &lt;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Digital_Root_Calculator">Digital Root Calculator</span></h3>
<pre>\@X"Enter Number: "XXSXrRXIcR
\sw?;\s48-w9,?\+        ;/1wG
              \10s%48+49#/   
     \w1a}48-iRED poiuy_qwert
</pre>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>GolfScript</b> is a concatenative programming language embedded on top of Ruby, designed to allow very short programs to be written, in order to win code-<a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a> contests. It supports a range of datatypes including arbitrary precision integers, and a wider range of standard operations than many other esoteric programming languages.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Overview"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Overview</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Syntax_and_Execution"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Syntax and Execution</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Input_and_Output"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Input and Output</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Built-ins"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Built-ins</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Coercion"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Coercion</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#List_of_built-ins"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">List of built-ins</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">Overview</span></h2>
<p>A GolfScript program is a list of items: integers, lists, strings, blocks, variables, and variable assignments.
Integers, when encountered, are simply pushed onto the stack.
Lists, strings, and blocks behave similarly. Variables are also pushed onto the stack, except when the variable contains a block. If that happens, the block is executed.
When a variable assignment is encountered, the top item on the stack is assigned to the variable, but not popped off the stack.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax_and_Execution">Syntax and Execution</span></h2>
<p>Lists and blocks are delimited by square brackets and curly brackets, respectively.
A block is actually just a string that has special behavior.
Variable assignment is done by placing a colon before the variable name.
Comments begin with a hash and end at the end of the line.
Strings are first evaluated by Ruby, allowing an escape to Ruby expressions and frameworks for those functions not provided by GolfScript, such as floating point and math libraries.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Input_and_Output">Input and Output</span></h2>
<p>Before a GolfScript program is executed, the input is pushed onto the stack as one long string, and therefore interactive input is impossible. When the program finishes execution, the stack's contents are printed, (apparently) starting from the bottom. There are also some explicit built-in methods of printing.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Built-ins">Built-ins</span></h2>
<p>Most of the golfing power of GolfScript comes from its extensive library of operators. These are actually just variables specially initialized. You can assign values to them if you want. Also, most of the operators are overloaded to provide different results if supplied with different arguments. For example, the asterisk * can mean any of:
</p>
<ul><li>Multiplication, when supplied with two integers</li>
<li>To execute a block a number of times, when supplied with an integer and a block</li>
<li>To repeat a string or list a number of times, when supplied with an integer and a string/list</li>
<li>To join the elements of a string/list together with another string/list, when supplied with two string/lists</li>
<li>To reduce the elements of a string/list to one element, when supplied with a string/list and a block</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coercion">Coercion</span></h3>
<p>When needed, integers are coerced to arrays/strings/blocks, arrays are coerced to strings/blocks (each element is converted to a string and the results are concatenated together), and strings are coerced to blocks.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="List_of_built-ins">List of built-ins</span></h3>
<p>Here is a list of built-ins (<b>currently incomplete</b>), in roughly increasing order of complexity. The arguments describe what types of objects should be on the stack, written bottom to top. A slash means that the arguments are interchangeable. 'List' means arrays or strings; 'sequence' means lists or blocks. This terminology is largely arbitrary.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Name
</th>
<th>Arguments
</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>;</code>
</td>
<td>any
</td>
<td>Pop, discard
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.</code>
</td>
<td>any
</td>
<td>Duplicate on stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>\</code>
</td>
<td>any, any
</td>
<td>Swap top two elements
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>@</code>
</td>
<td>any, any, any
</td>
<td>Move third element on bottom to top
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>!</code>
</td>
<td>any
</td>
<td>Negation: pushes 1 if argument is 0 or empty string/array/block, 0 otherwise.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>`</code>
</td>
<td>any
</td>
<td>Converts the element to a string that, if evaluated, returns the original
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="3"><code>~</code>
</td>
<td>int
</td>
<td>Bitwise not
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>string or block
</td>
<td>Evaluate
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>array
</td>
<td>Dump the elements onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="3"><code>,</code>
</td>
<td>int
</td>
<td>Construct an array with elements [0, 1, ..., int - 1]
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list
</td>
<td>Find the length
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, block
</td>
<td>Filter: select elements that return true when the block is applied to them.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>&amp;</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Bitwise and
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq, seq (coerce)
</td>
<td>Setwise and
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>|</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Bitwise or
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq, seq (coerce)
</td>
<td>Setwise or
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>^</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Bitwise xor
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq, seq (coerce)
</td>
<td>Setwise xor
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="3"><code>$</code>
</td>
<td>int
</td>
<td>Copy stack: copy the nth element of the stack (after popping the argument) to the top.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list
</td>
<td>Sort
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, block
</td>
<td>Sort, according to a mapping
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>(</code>
</td>
<td>int
</td>
<td>Decrement
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq
</td>
<td>Uncons: push sequence without first item, push first item
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>)</code>
</td>
<td>int
</td>
<td>Increment
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq
</td>
<td>Uncons from right: push sequence without last item, push last item
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>+</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Add two integers
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq, seq (coerce)
</td>
<td>Concatenate two sequences
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2"><code>-</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Subtract
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>seq, seq (coerce)
</td>
<td>Setwise difference
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="5"><code>*</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Multiply
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>int/list
</td>
<td>Copy the sequence (int) times and concatenate them together.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>int/block
</td>
<td>Execute it (int) times.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, list
</td>
<td>Join. Put the elements of the second sequence in between each element of the first sequence and concatenate.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, block
</td>
<td>Fold. Reduce. Whatever.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="4"><code>/</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Integer division
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, list
</td>
<td>Split around matches with a second array
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>block, block
</td>
<td>Unfold: a while loop where the condition test is applied to the top of stack, and if the check passes the element on top of stack is collected into an array.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, block
</td>
<td>Each: execute a block over each element, and push the results.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="4"><code>%</code>
</td>
<td>int, int
</td>
<td>Integer modulus
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, list
</td>
<td>Split around matches like /, but omit empty results
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, int
</td>
<td>Select elements with index 0 mod int. If the int is negative the result is reversed, so [1 2 3]-1% reverses the array.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>list, block
</td>
<td>Map. Somewhat like Each except the results go in a list.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<p>99 bottles of beer (considerably golfed)
</p>
<pre>[296,{3/)}%-1%["No more"]+[" bottles":b]294*[b-1&lt;]2*+[b]+[" of beer on the wall\n".8&lt;"\nTake one down, pass it around\n"+1$n+]99*]zip
</pre>
<p>Quines: Note that since the stack is output at termination, a program like
</p>
<pre>5
</pre>
<p>is a quine (as long as no input is given to it). A more non-cheating example could be
</p>
<pre>{".~"}.~
</pre>
<p>How it works: block {".~"} pushes the .~ string when evaluated. It's duplicated (blocks are printed with parentheses) and evaluated.
</p><p>Random example of the golfing that can be done with this code:
</p>
<pre>~{..{(h{3^3%}%2,@h{2\-}%\;++}{,}if}:h~2/zip{{"ACB"=}%}%n*\;
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>GolfScript is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>, as it can be shown to be computationally equivalent to <a href="/wiki/Underload" title="Underload">Underload</a>: the GolfScript built-ins <code>\.;+{}~</code> correspond to the TC subset of Underload commands <code>~:!*()^</code>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="http://www.golfscript.com/golfscript/tutorial.html" rel="nofollow">GolfScript homepage</a></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://golf.shinh.org/l.rb?gs" rel="nofollow">Examples of golfscript programs</a> submitted with the intent of minimizing program length. (Scroll down to 'right time' or lower for ones you can view.)</li></ul>

100.00%    0.000      1 -total
-->

 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Half-Broken Car in Heavy Traffic</b> is a 2D-grid language with operators also acting
as direction signs, making programming very difficult. It was created by Niels
Serup (<a href="/wiki/User:Nqpz" title="User:Nqpz">User:Nqpz</a>).
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Language_overview"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Language overview</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Increment"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Increment</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Decrement"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Decrement</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Hello,_World!"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Hello, World!</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Move_cell_value"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Move cell value</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7"><a href="#Ignore_the_random_direction"><span class="tocnumber">2.5</span> <span class="toctext">Ignore the random direction</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8"><a href="#Random"><span class="tocnumber">2.6</span> <span class="toctext">Random</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_overview">Language overview</span></h2>
<p>(<a class="external text" href="https://github.com/nqpz/hbcht" rel="nofollow">Source</a>)
</p><p>HBCHT is a 2D grid-based programming language. You are a car fighting to get to
the exit of a very chaotic highway. You have to follow the signs, but whenever
you do that, you also change your memory. The value of your current memory cell
can be incremented or decremented and your memory cell index can change. You
can also find signs that tell you to turn either right or not turn at all,
depending on your memory.
</p><p>The car can drive in four directions: up, right, down, and left. Because of the
chaos, you never know which direction the car is headed when the program
starts. This makes it easy to randomize the output.
</p><p>To make things worse (actually, it's to make programming in HBCHT possible),
you cannot turn left (relative to your current direction) because your car is half-broken. You can drive straight
ahead, you can turn right, and you can reverse.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command/marker
</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code>
</td>
<td>go right, next memory cell
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code>
</td>
<td>go left, previous memory cell
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>^</code>
</td>
<td>go up, increment memory cell value
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>v</code>
</td>
<td>go down, decrement memory cell value
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>/</code>
</td>
<td>turn right if the current memory cell has the same value as the previous cell, else continue
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>o</code>
</td>
<td>the car
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>#</code>
</td>
<td>the exit
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul><li>There can be only one car and only one exit</li>
<li>The car cannot turn left; any relative left turns will be ignored along with their memory effects</li>
<li>The program always starts at memory cell #0</li>
<li>All memory cells have the value 0 by default</li>
<li>Input values cannot be negative, but values returned by a program can</li>
<li>The car cannot go out of bound; if it exits to the right, it reenters to the left, etc.</li>
<li>Values cannot be input to memory cells below memory cell #0, but the program can set values in these</li>
<li>Values can be arbitrarily large. An interpreter or compiler without this feature is valid, but not perfect (note that hbcht's C translator uses 32-bit ints and is thereby not perfect).</li></ul>
<p>A semicolon denotes a comment. Anything from the semicolon to the end of the
line is ignored.
</p><p>If a program file contains a line that starts with <code>@intext</code>, it will see
input as text and convert the text to ordinals before running the core
function.
</p><p>If a program file contains a line that starts with <code>@outtext</code>, it will show
output as a text string instead of a list of numbers.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Increment">Increment</span></h3>
<pre>; Increment the first memory cell once without changing the other cells.

    &gt;   ^ &lt;
      &gt;   v   &lt;
        #
        ^&lt; &gt;
           ^
    ^      ^&lt;&gt;
             ^
          &gt;  ^&lt;
          ^  
  &gt; v &lt; o v
          v
          v
          &lt; &gt; v
    v   v
    v   v
    v   v
    v   v
        &gt;  ^ &lt;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Decrement">Decrement</span></h3>
<pre>; Decrement the first memory cell once without changing the other cells.

   v   v
 v &lt;   &lt;&gt;
   ^
   ^ &gt;&gt;^&lt;
&gt;v&lt;o&gt;^&lt;
 v 
 v  v
 &gt; v&lt;
   #
 &gt; ^&lt;
 ^ 
</pre>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_World.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_World!"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hello,_World!" title="Hello, World!">Hello, World!</a></span></h3>
<pre>; Prints "Hello, world!\n".
@outtext

     v                           &gt;v       ^
&gt; v  &lt;                            v     &gt;&gt;^&lt;
  v  ^  v                         v     ^
     ^  &lt;                         v     ^
        ^                         v     ^
  &gt;   /&gt;^&lt;v                       v     ^
  ^  &gt;v&lt;  &lt;                       v     ^
          ^                       v     ^
  ^   &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v                     v     ^   #
  ^   ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;                     v     ^   ^
  ^         ^                     v     ^   ^
  ^     &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v                   v     ^   ^
  ^     ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;                   v     ^   ^
  ^           ^                   v     ^   ^
  ^       &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v                 v     ^   ^
  ^       ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;                 v     ^   ^
  ^             ^                 v     ^   ^
  ^         &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v               v     ^   ^
  ^         ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;           &gt;v  v     ^ &gt;&gt;^&lt;
  ^               ^           ^v  v     ^ ^
  ^           &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v         ^v  v     ^ ^
  ^           ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;         ^v  v   &gt;&gt;^&lt;^
  ^                 ^         ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^             &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v       ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^             ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;       ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                   ^       ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^               &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v     ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^               ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;     ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                     ^     ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                 &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v   ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                 ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt;   ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                       ^   ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                   &gt; /&gt;^&lt;v ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                   ^&gt;v&lt;  &lt; ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                         ^ ^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                     &gt; /&gt;^&lt;^v  v   ^   ^
  ^                &gt;&gt;   ^     ^ &lt; v   ^   ^
  ^          &gt;v&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;    v  v   ^   ^
  ^           v   &gt;^&lt;          v  v &gt;&gt;^&lt;  ^
  ^           v  &gt; &gt;v          v  v ^     ^
&gt; ^   v       v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^     ^
^ ^           v  ^^            v  v ^   &gt;&gt;^&lt;
^ ^           v  ^^ &lt;          v  v ^   ^
^ ^           v&gt;&gt;^&lt;            v  v ^   ^
^ ^                            v  v ^   ^
^ ^           v^               v  v ^   ^
^ ^           v^               v  v ^   ^
^ ^           v^               v  v ^     v
^ ^           v^               v  v ^&gt;v   &lt;
^ ^           v^               v  v ^ &gt;&gt;^&lt;^
^ ^        &gt;v &lt;^               v  v ^ ^   ^
^ ^         &gt;&gt;^^&lt;              v  v ^     ^
^ ^         ^                  v  v ^     ^
^ ^                            v  &gt;&gt;^&lt;    ^
^ ^                            v  ^       ^
^ ^                            v          ^
^ ^                            v          ^
^ ^    v                       v          ^
^ ^    &lt;                       v          ^
^     &gt;^&lt;                      v          ^
^     ^                        v          ^
^     v                        &gt; ^&lt;       ^
^     &lt;                        ^
    &gt;&gt;^&lt;
 &gt;  ^&lt;v
 ^ &gt;v&lt;&lt;
  v
&gt;v&lt;
  ^
 &gt;^&lt;
 o&gt;v
 v &gt;  ^&lt;
 v ^
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Move_cell_value">Move cell value</span></h3>
<pre>; Move the value of memory cell #0 to memory cell #1.

; Making sure the car ends up going in the same direction with the same
; variables.
  
   &gt;v &lt;
      ^
      ^&lt;&gt;
v
&lt;  &gt;v
^
^&lt;&gt;    
  ^
    &gt;   ^&lt;
 &gt;v&lt;o&gt;^ &lt;
      v   
    &gt;     ^&lt;
    ^     v
  &gt; v     &lt;
          ^

            v   ; The actual moving.
   &gt;v      &lt;&lt;
   #/
    v       ^
    &gt;      &gt;^&lt;
    ^
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ignore_the_random_direction">Ignore the random direction</span></h3>
<p>This is an extension to the increment program so that the input is unaffected and you start on the first cell like normal. The car will be at the hashtag moving downwards. From there you can write whatever program you want deterministically. If you use this, don't put code in columns 5, 9, or 16 (1-based) and don't do wraparounds in any of the rows or columns where this code appears.
</p>
<pre>                    v
    &gt;   ^ &lt;       &gt;v&lt;   
      &gt;   v   &lt;    v^ 
        &gt;           ^  &lt;
        ^&lt; &gt;       
           ^
    ^      ^&lt;&gt;  
             ^
          &gt;  ^&lt;
          ^  
  &gt; v &lt; o v
          v
          v
          &lt; &gt; v
    v   v
    v   v
    v   v    
    v   v             
        &gt;  ^ &lt;     
                     
                   #   
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Random">Random</span></h3>
<pre>; Returns either 1 in #0 or -1 in #1
&gt; #
^
o&gt;v
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/nqpz/hbcht" rel="nofollow">hbcht</a> is a combined compiler/interpreter written in Python 3.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Eckankar/bf2hbcht" rel="nofollow">bf2hbcht</a> is a transpiler from Brainfuck to HBCHT (disregarding input and output instructions), showing that HBCHT is Turing complete.</li></ul>
<!-- 
NewPP limit report
Cached time: 20250724010949
Cache expiry: 86400
Reduced expiry: false
Complications: [show‐toc]
CPU time usage: 0.010 seconds
Real time usage: 0.023 seconds

Template argument size: 0/2097152 bytes
Highest expansion depth: 2/100
Expensive parser function count: 0/100
Unstrip recursion depth: 0/20
Unstrip post‐expand size: 4628/5000000 bytes
-->
<!--
Transclusion expansion time report (%,ms,calls,template)
100.00%    0.000      1 -total
-->
<!-- Saved in parser cache with key esolang_wiki:pcache:idhash:4182-0!canonical and timestamp 20250724010949 and revision id 146126. Rendering was triggered because: page-view
 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Home Row</b> is a language by <a href="/wiki/User:PuzzleHunter84" title="User:PuzzleHunter84">User:PuzzleHunter84</a> that uses only the non-shifted symbols on the home row of a US PC keyboard:
a,s,d,f,j,k,l, and ; to make programs incredibly quick and easy to type.  The symbols perform
functions similar but not identical to bf:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<td><code>a</code></td>
<td>"Add" 1 to the selected memory spot.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>s</code></td>
<td>"Subtract" 1 from the selected memory spot.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>d</code></td>
<td>move the memory pointer "Down" one memory spot.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>f</code></td>
<td>move the memory pointer "Forward" one memory spot.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>j</code></td>
<td>"Jump" over the next instruction if the current memory spot is zero.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>k</code></td>
<td>"Kill and print" the current memory spot reseting it to 0 and printing the value as an ASCII character.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>l</code></td>
<td>begin and end a "Loop" that runs if the current memory spot is nonzero and reruns after the second l each time if the current memory spot is nonzero.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>;</code></td>
<td>end the program.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The memory values are stored in a 5x5 grid of memory spots that all initialize at 0 and the current
memory spot is designated by a memory pointer that initializes in the top-left spot.  If the memory
pointer moves off the end of a row it goes to the beginning of that row and the same with
columns, so essentially the memory grid is a 5x5 torus where the memory counter can potentially
initialize anywhere.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Hello_World_Program"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Hello World Program</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Extension_to_22_registers"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Extension to 22 registers</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#One-dimensional_construction"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">One-dimensional construction</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Implementations"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Implementations</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello_World_Program">Hello World Program</span></h2>
<p>could be optimized
</p>
<pre>aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaak
aaaaaaaaaak;
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Home Row is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Minsky_machine" title="Minsky machine">Minsky machine</a> with at least 8 registers (2 are enough) can be compiled into it.
</p><p>This construction uses the following grid layout:
</p>
<pre>S  t  t  0  ?
R0 t  R1 t  ?
R2 t  R3 t  ?
R4 t  R5 t  ?
R6 t  R7 t  ?
</pre>
<ul><li><code>S</code> is the skip counter, which counts down command blocks to skip. When it is nonzero, other commands become rerouted to only affect the trash spots.</li>
<li><code>t</code> are trash spots, which become munged by rerouted commands.</li>
<li><code>Rn</code> are registers of the Minsky machine.</li>
<li>The lone <code>0</code> spot is used to reset position to a known spot, with the help of the trash spots to its left, which will be kept nonzero.</li>
<li><code>?</code> are spots whose contents are not used, although they may still be passed over.</li></ul>
<p>The emulated Minsky machine program is represented as a sequence of assembly-like commands. This sequence is implicitly divided into command blocks by splitting after unconditional <code>SKIP</code> or <code>HALT</code> commands.
</p><p>Overall encoded program structure:
</p>
<pre>afafafff l s &lt;cmd&gt;... s &lt;cmd&gt;... ... l
</pre>
<p>The first part of the program by default initializes <code>S</code> and the trash spots to its right to the value 1. This makes all the MM registers 0 and starts execution with the first command block.
</p><p>The rest of the program consists of the encoding of each command block between the <code>l</code>s of the main program loop.
</p><p>Each command block is encoded as <code>s</code> (to decrement the skip counter) followed by the encodings of each of its commands.
</p><p>Execution of a command starts with the memory pointer at <code>S</code>, with the intent that it should have no effect on non-trash spots if <code>S</code> is nonzero.
</p>
<pre>SKIP n: jf a<sup>n</sup> ffjfff
</pre>
<p>Skips ahead <i>n</i> command blocks, with the end of the program considered to wrap around back to the start.
</p>
<pre>HALT: jf ffj; ff
HALT (last command in program only): 
</pre>
<p>Halts the MM program. Normally this immediately halts Home Row as well. The second encoding (as nothing) instead causes the Home Row program to fall through the end of the main loop, which may be useful if you want to add something to the end of it.
</p>
<pre>ADD R0,k: jf d a<sup>k</sup> dddd ffjfff
SUB R0,k: jf d s<sup>k</sup> dddd ffjfff
</pre>
<p>Adds or subtracts a constant from a register. We use the upper left register as example, for others adjust the movement commands back and forth from <code>S</code>.
</p>
<pre>SKIP n IF R0==0: jf d jf dddd a<sup>k</sup> fjfjfff
</pre>
<p>Skips ahead <i>n</i> command blocks if register is zero.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Extension_to_22_registers">Extension to 22 registers</span></h3>
<p>It is possible to adjust the construction to fit as many as 22 Minsky machine registers.
</p>
<pre>S   T   0   R0  R1
R2  R3  R4  R5  R6
R7  R8  R9  R10 R11
R12 R13 R14 R15 R16
R17 R18 R19 R20 R21
</pre>
<p>However, this requires a more complicated construction and navigation.
For example, with the register at the center:
</p>
<pre>SUB R9,1: faffff jff jdjdjfjf ffff s f jfjfjfjfjdjdjd fff
SKIP 2 IF R9==0: ddff s dddfff jf ddff jf ddd jd ddddfff jfjd ffff aa fjf dd a dddfff
</pre>
<p>In particular:
</p>
<ul><li>Register spots normally store a value one higher than the emulated MM register.</li>
<li>The exception to this is any register that is currently being branched on.</li>
<li>Decrementing a MM register below zero is undefined behavior (the simpler construction above doesn't care about this).</li>
<li>This ensures that all but a few of the spots in the grid are known to be nonzero at any given time, which keeps navigation manageable.</li></ul>
<p>To describe the construction we need some notation:
</p>
<ul><li><code>A+d</code> and <code>A+f</code> are the spots below and to the right of the spot <code>A</code>, respectively.</li>
<li><code>p(A,B)</code> is a sequence of <code>df</code> commands moving from spot <code>A</code> to spot <code>B</code>.
<ul><li>When applied at an arbitrary starting spot, this works as a (wrapping) translation parallel to the <code>AB</code> one.</li></ul></li>
<li><code>q(A,B)</code> is a sequence of conditional <code>jd</code> and <code>jf</code> commands moving from spot <code>A</code> to spot <code>B</code>, without ever starting at spots <code>S</code> or <code>0</code> (all other spots are assumed nonzero).
<ul><li>This is used when we know that the memory pointer is either at <code>0</code> or <code>A</code>, and we want to change it from <code>A</code> to <code>B</code> without moving the <code>0</code> case.</li></ul></li></ul>
<p>We can now describe the overall program structure and command encodings:
</p>
<pre>afaffafa d afafafafa d afafafafa d afafafafa d afafafafa l s &lt;cmd&gt;... s &lt;cmd&gt;... ... l
</pre>
<p>All spots except for <code>0</code> are initialized to 1.
</p>
<pre>SKIP n: jf a<sup>n</sup> fjffff
HALT: jff j; jffff (or nothing for the last block)
</pre>
<pre>ADD R,k: jff q(T,R+f) ffff a<sup>k</sup> f q(R+f,0) fff
SUB R,k: f a<sup>k</sup> ffff jff q(T,R+f) ffff s<sup>k</sup> f q(R+f,0) fff
</pre>
<p>For the upper right register <code>R1</code>, <code>R1+f = S</code>, so <code>q(R1+f,0)</code> does not exist. It can be replaced by <code>ff q(R1,0)</code>.
</p>
<pre>SKIP n IF R==0:
 p(S,R) s p(R,S) jf p(S,R) jf p(R,0) jd p(R6,0) jfjd ffff a<sup>n</sup> fjf p(0,R) a p(R,S)
 or
 p(S,R) s p(R,S) jd p(S,R) jd p(R,R14) jddjfjdjdjdjd ff a<sup>n</sup> fjf p(0,R) a p(R,S)
</pre>
<p>The first option does testing with horizontal branching, the second with vertical branching. Each works for a different subset of the registers:
</p>
<pre>Horizontal         Vertical
S  T  0  +         S  T  0  *  *
*  *  *  *  *      *  *        *
*  *  *  *  *      *  *  +     *
*  *  *  *  *      *  *        *
      *  *  *      *  *  +     *
</pre>
<p>As the three cases <code>S==0, R==0; S==0, R&gt;0; S&gt;0</code> are separated (into consecutive positions) by the initial branching, each of the above can be simply modified to reverse the test (this only breaks for the registers marked <code>+</code> in the above tables):
</p>
<pre>SKIP n IF R&gt;0:
 p(S,R) s p(R,S) jf p(S,R) jf p(R,0) jfjfff jd p(R6,0) jfjd ffff a<sup>n</sup> fjf p(0,R) a p(R,S)
 or
 p(S,R) s p(R,S) jd p(S,R) jd p(R,0) jdjd jddjfjdjdjdjd ff a<sup>n</sup> fjf p(0,R) a p(R,S)
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="One-dimensional_construction">One-dimensional construction</span></h3>
<p>Home Row may be useful for proving other languages Turing complete, especially
ones with limited nesting of loops. The following construction tries to
facilitate this:
</p>
<ul><li>Only one row of the grid is used.</li>
<li>The construction can be used with a non-wrapping grid, if backwards movement can be supported, at the cost of an extra zero spot.</li>
<li>The width of the grid can be increased to fit more MM registers, which can avoid an extra level of exponential time blowup from using only 2 registers.</li>
<li>Only non-negative values are used (as long as the Minsky machine has the same property).</li>
<li>The only commands used are <code>a</code>, <code>s</code>, <code>f</code>, a backwards movement command "<code>b</code>" if the grid is non-wrapping, two <code>l</code>s, and the combination <code>jf</code>.</li></ul>
<p>A similar notation as in the previous section will be used, with some adjustment:
</p>
<ul><li><code>p(A,B)</code> is a sequence of <code>f</code> and possibly "<code>b</code>" commands to move from spot <code>A</code> to <code>B</code>, or the same distance and direction from any other spot.</li>
<li><code>q(A,B)</code> is a sequence of <code>jf</code> commands that will move from <code>A</code> to <code>B</code> (always to the right of <code>A</code>) assuming all spots started from are nonzero.</li>
<li><code>@{A}</code> or <code>@{A,B}</code>: Because the usage of <code>p</code> and <code>q</code> got even more confusing than in previous sections, I have annotated on lines below what are the possible positions for the memory pointer at certain execution points.</li></ul>
<p>The grid row's layout is:
</p>
<pre>Z0 S R0 ... Rn T (Z1)
</pre>
<p><code>Z0</code> and <code>Z1</code> are permanently zero spots, which can be identified with each other if on a wrapping grid. The other spots are as in the previous sections.
</p><p>Overall program structure:
</p>
<pre>f af af ... af a p(T,S) l s &lt;cmd&gt;... s &lt;cmd&gt;... ... l
</pre>
<p>Similar to the 22 register construction, all spots other than <code>Z0</code> and <code>Z1</code> are initialized to 1.
</p>
<pre>SKIP n: q(S,T) a<sup>n</sup> p(T,Z1) q(R0,Z1) p(Z1,S)
     @{S}    @{S,T}  @{R0,Z1}   @{Z1}   @{S}
HALT: only by running off the final block
</pre>
<pre>ADD R,k: q(R,T) p(S,R) a<sup>k</sup> p(T,Z1) q(R,T) p(Z1,S)
      @{S}           @{R,T}          @{Z1}    @{S}
SUB R,k: p(S,T) a<sup>k</sup> p(T,S) q(R,T) p(S,R) s<sup>k</sup> p(T,Z1) q(R,T) p(Z1,S)
      @{S}     @{T}    @{S}           @{R,T}           @{Z1}   @{S}
</pre>
<p>For conditional branching, we need the following subcommand:
</p>
<pre>r(R,C): a p(S,R) s q(R,T) a p(R,Z0) q(S,R) p(Z0,S) C p(T,Z1) q(S,R) p(Z1,T) s p(T,Z1) q(R,T) p(Z1,R) a p(R,S) s
      @{S}      @{R}    @{R,T}                  @{S,T}                   @{R,T}           @{Z1}    @{R}     @{S}
</pre>
<p><code>r(R,a)</code> and <code>r(R,s)</code> add or subtract 1 from <code>S</code>, respectively, if MM register <code>R</code> is zero (i.e. the spot value is 1). This happens regardless of the (non-negative) value of <code>S</code>, i.e. even if the current command block isn't "running".
</p>
<pre>SKIP n IF R==0: r(R,a) (SKIP n) r(R,s)
SKIP n IF R&gt;0: a r(R,s) (SKIP n) r(R,a) s
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<ul><li>An <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/bangyen/esolangs" rel="nofollow">x86 assembly compiler</a> by <a href="/wiki/User:Bangyen" title="User:Bangyen">User:Bangyen</a>.</li>
<li>A <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/kronosta/esolangs/blob/main/HomeRow/homerow.py" rel="nofollow">Python interpreter</a> by <a href="/wiki/User:BoundedBeans" title="User:BoundedBeans">User:BoundedBeans</a>
<ul><li>It also has an input command (g) and the ability to use sizes other than 5x5 with simple commandline arguments.</li></ul></li></ul>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p>The <b>I/D machine</b> is a Turing-complete <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Category:Computational_models" title="Category:Computational models">computational model</a> created by <a href="/wiki/User:Ais523" title="User:Ais523">User:ais523</a> in <a href="/wiki/Category:2018" title="Category:2018">2018</a>, inspired by <a href="/wiki/RAM0" title="RAM0">RAM0</a> and <a href="/wiki/Three_Star_Programmer" title="Three Star Programmer">Three Star Programmer</a>. It can be viewed as either a <a href="/wiki/Turing_tarpit" title="Turing tarpit">Turing tarpit</a> with just two commands (neither of which takes arguments), thus being simpler than all known <a href="/wiki/BF_instruction_minimalization" title="BF instruction minimalization">BF instruction minimalizations</a> (although it does not support I/O); or as a particular <a href="/wiki/OISC" title="OISC">OISC</a>, with one command that takes an argument.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<ul>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#One-command_view"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">One-command view</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Implementations"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Implementations</span></a>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-8"><a href="#RAM0"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">RAM0</span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Data_storage">Data storage</span></h2>
<p>The I/D machine consists of an unbounded random-access memory; both addresses, and cell values, are unbounded nonnegative integers. Initially, these are all zero. Additionally, the machine has a single register, the "data pointer"; this initially has value 0 (i.e. it's a pointer to the first element of the RAM).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax_and_semantics">Syntax and semantics</span></h2>
<p>The language can be interpreted in two different, equivalent, ways, which each have their own syntax:
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Two-command_view">Two-command view</span></h3>
<p>The two-command view of the language, unsurprisingly, has two commands:
</p>
<ul><li><code>I</code>: Increments the cell the data pointer points to (i.e. <code>++*p</code>).</li>
<li><code>D</code>: Dereferences the data pointer, and assigns the resulting value back to the data pointer (i.e. <code>p=*p</code>).</li></ul>
<p>That's it. Any commands other than <code>I</code> and <code>D</code> (and numbers, if the implementation also supports the one-command view) are ignored. In order to do control flow, the program is run forever in an implicit loop.
</p><p>The two-command view of the I/D machine can be seen as a brainfuck derivative.  I is the traditional <code>+</code> command, and D is a command that doesn't look strange in one.  In fact, <a href="/wiki/Symbolic_Brainfuck" title="Symbolic Brainfuck">Symbolic Brainfuck</a> has both commands, named <code>+</code> and <code>⌂</code> (actually represented as the byte \x7F in code).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="One-command_view">One-command view</span></h3>
<p>In the one-command view, the language has only one command, which takes a nonnegative integer <i>n</i> as argument. Syntactically, this is just done by writing the integers in the normal decimal notation in question; any number but <code>0</code> must be separated from the subsequent number via a non-digit character (such as whitespace). (0 may be separated from the subsequent number via filler characters, but need not be; due to this rule, numbers may not be given with leading zeros.) Anything but integers is ignored (other than <code>D</code> and <code>I</code> if the implementation also supports the two-command view).
</p><p>The command itself is a run-length-encoded version of the two-command view; it runs <code>I</code> <i>n</i> times, followed by running <code>D</code> once. This can either be implemented via expanding the run-length encoding, or more efficiently via combining the effects of the commands: <code>*p += n; p = *p;</code> (which can be further abbreviated to <code>p=*p+=n;</code> if you like obfuscated code). Just as with the two-command view, the program runs forever in an implicit loop.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>The I/D machine is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>, as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyclic_tag" title="Cyclic tag">cyclic tag</a> can be compiled into it. See <a href="/wiki/I/D_machine_Turing-completeness_proof" title="I/D machine Turing-completeness proof">I/D machine Turing-completeness proof</a> for more information.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Perl">Perl</span></h3>
<p>Here's a golfed implementation of the OISC variant in Perl (requires the <code>-a</code> command line option, and you may want to consider <code>-Mbigint</code> even though numbers that won't fit in a Perl integer will point to cells that won't fit in your address space anyway):
</p>
<pre>$p=$a[$p]+=$_ for@F;redo
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="RAM0"><a href="/wiki/RAM0" title="RAM0">RAM0</a></span></h3>
<p>It's possible to compile the I/D machine to RAM0 via setting up the RAM0 registers so that <b>n</b> always contains the address that the pointer is pointing to, and <b>z</b> always contains the value stored in that address (i.e. the value that is read via dereferencing the pointer); the RAM0 and I/D memory spaces are identical. This invariant is trivially true at the start of the program (with everything being zeros). Here are implementations of the I/D commands in RAM0 that maintain the invariants:
</p>
<ul><li><code>I</code> becomes <code>AS</code> (i.e. increment <b>z</b> and store the result in *<b>n</b>)</li>
<li><code>D</code> becomes <code>NL</code> (i.e. set <b>n</b> to <b>z</b> and <b>z</b> to *<b>z</b>)</li></ul>
<p>This therefore gives an alternative proof that RAM0 is Turing-complete using only the <code>ASNL</code> commands.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Zig">Zig</span></h3>
<p>A <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/DivergentClouds/id-machine" rel="nofollow">Zig implementation</a> made by DivergentClouds.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Scratch">Scratch</span></h3>
<p><a class="external text" href="https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/710474801/" rel="nofollow">Interpreter in Scratch</a> made by <a href="/wiki/User:ChuckEsoteric08" title="User:ChuckEsoteric08">User:ChuckEsoteric08</a> with limited storage
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Python">Python</span></h3>
<p>an two-command view interpreter written in Python 3 with only one big expression
</p>
<pre>(
  __builtins__.__setattr__('DP',0),addrs:={},
  get:=lambda:addrs.get(DP,0),
  do:=lambda i:{'I':lambda:addrs.__setitem__(DP,get()+1),
                'D':lambda:__builtins__.__setattr__('DP',get())}[i](),
  program:=list(filter(lambda x:x in'ID',r'''
   IIID
  ''')),
  [
    [
      (do(i),print(addrs,DP),__import__('time').sleep(0.5))
    for i in program]
  for _ in iter(lambda:1,0)]
)
</pre>

<li><a href="/wiki/Three_Star_Programmer" title="Three Star Programmer">Three Star Programmer</a></li></ul>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Imprecision</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> created by <a href="/wiki/User:Ais523" title="User:Ais523">User:ais523</a> in <a href="/wiki/Category:2024" title="Category:2024">2024</a>, inspired by <a href="/wiki/Blindfolded_Arithmetic" title="Blindfolded Arithmetic">Blindfolded Arithmetic</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Specification"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Specification</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Special_variables"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Special variables</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Interpreters"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Interpreters</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Specification">Specification</span></h2>
<p>Imprecision programs store data in a number of variables, each of which has a name consisting of ASCII letters. (There is no limit on how many variables can be used, but any given program will use only the variables mentioned in the program and thus can only access finitely many.) Each variable stores a rational number, initially 0.
</p><p>A program consists of a list of statements, each of which assigns the result of an expression to a variable (overwriting the variable's old value). The grammar of expressions is as follows, matching the grammar used for the same expressions in typical practical programming languages:
</p>
<pre>expr ::= expr '+' expr  /* addition */
       | expr '-' expr  /* subtraction */
       | expr '*' expr  /* multiplication */
       | expr '/' expr  /* division of rationals: produces an exact rational result */
       | '(' expr ')'   /* grouping/precedence override: returns the result of the expression inside */
       | variablename   /* returns the value of the named variable */
       | integer        /* returns the integer (integers are written in decimal) */
</pre>
<p>Operator precedence is the usual for programming languages, i.e. first do multiplications and divisions left-to-right, then additions and subtractions left-to-right. The quotes in the grammar are not present in actual programs (e.g. a sample expression is <code>4 + x * x</code>, which is equivalent to <code>4 + (x * x)</code> and different from <code>(4 + x) * x</code>). Division by zero is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a> (unlike in Blindfolded Arithmetic, where it is a halt signal).
</p><p>A statement itself is written by giving the variable name, an <code>=</code>, and an expression, e.g. <code>a = b + 5</code>.
</p><p>There is no control flow, with the statements executing from the start to the end of the program in order. However, after the last statement is executed, the first statement is executed again, forming an infinite loop.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Special_variables">Special variables</span></h3>
<p>If a program contains the <code>halt</code> variable, it will halt if it ever assigns a positive value to that variable. (If a negative or zero value is assigned, this does not cause the program to halt.)
</p><p>If a program contains the <code>input</code> variable, it will be initialized to an integer taken from user input, rather than 0.
</p><p>If a program contains the <code>output</code> variable, then if the program halts, the value of <code>output</code> will be output to the user, rounded to the nearest integer.
</p><p>Implementations should take and produce output in integer form by default, but may support command-line options to encode strings as integers, then decode the integer to string as output. The way in which this is done depends on the implementation.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Imprecision without I/O can easily implement a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Finite_state_machine" title="Finite state machine">finite state machine</a> via using a polynomial as though it were a lookup table, in order to change the value of a state variable (because it is possible to fit a polynomial with rational coefficients to produce any given finite input-output mapping among integers). However, the language finds it very difficult to read data that might be arbitrarily large, because there is no way to map (e.g.) all positive values to 0 but 0 to 1 using only the <code>+ - * /</code> operations. This makes it difficult to write a program that runs reliably after reading input, and also makes it difficult to retrieve arbitrarily large amounts of data, with the latter being one of the requirements for <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-completeness</a>.
</p><p>ais523 suspects (but has not proven) that the language is Turing-complete anyway, via writing a program that uses <i>approximate</i> state variables and counter values, in the style of <a href="/wiki/Analogia" title="Analogia">Analogia</a>. Unfortunately, unlike in Analogia, there is no easy way to quantize the value of a state variable that could potentially be arbitrarily large; instead, a TCness proof would probably need to ensure that the sequence of extra error added to the counter values forms a convergent series, and thus never gets large enough to leave a counter value unreadable.
</p>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Incident</b> is a language created by <a href="/wiki/User:Ais523" title="User:Ais523">User:ais523</a> for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CALESYTA_2016" title="CALESYTA 2016">CALESYTA 2016</a> contest. The goals of the language were to make an interesting puzzle for programmers (trying to figure out how to write anything at all in the language is decidedly nontrivial, although once you know the tricks the language is viably possible to write by hand); and to create a language which would allow programs to obey almost arbitrary restrictions on what can appear in the source (e.g. bans on certain characters, polyglotting with some other language, valid as an image / executable / save file for some other program, and the like).
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax">Syntax</span></h2>
<p>Incident's syntax is fairly unusual, specifically the lexical analyser; what counts as a valid token in the language is determined via analysis of the source code, rather than being predetermined. The basic rule is that <i>the tokens for a particular program are the substrings that appear exactly three times in it</i>. (The input program is interpreted as a string via converting it to a sequence of octets, if it isn't already in that form.) There are some restrictions:
</p>
<ul><li>A token cannot be a substring of a longer token; in this case, the shorter token is disregarded entirely.</li>
<li>Two tokens cannot overlap within the source; if they would, neither is treated as a token.</li></ul>
<p>Anything that isn't part of a token is treated as a comment and discarded.
</p><p>These syntax rules mean that an Incident interpreter can be fairly hard to write efficiently, given that changing any part of the program can affect how the entire rest of the program is parsed. They also mean that a syntax highlighter is a fairly essential tool when writing programs by hand.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Semantics">Semantics</span></h2>
<p>Obviously, Incident can't specify its commands via an explicit list. Instead, each token is treated as a command of its own (which also has an associated stack of bits, initially empty), but the behaviour of a command depends on where it appears in the program:
</p>
<ul><li>Running the <i>first copy</i> of a command pushes a 0 bit onto the stack associated with that command, then jumps to just after the second copy.</li>
<li>Running the <i>third copy</i> of a command pushes a 1 bit onto the stack associated with that command, then jumps to just after the second copy.</li>
<li>Running the <i>second copy</i> of a command pops a bit from the stack associated with that command, then jumps to just after the first copy if it was a 0 bit, or just after the third copy if it was a 1 bit.</li></ul>
<p>There are a few exceptions. Two minor ones are to do with I/O, and have no effect on otherwise valid programs (thus, they act like backward-compatible extensions to a hypothetical version of the language with no I/O):
</p>
<ul><li>When pushing a bit onto the stack associated with the centremost token in the program (breaking ties towards the start of the program), the bit is also output to standard output (in a little-endian way).</li>
<li>When attempting to pop an empty stack, the bit is taken from standard input instead (again, in a little-endian way); this applies to all commands, not just the one associated with the centremost token. At EOF, the command simply fails to run (it's just skipped, and doesn't jump anywhere).</li></ul>
<p>There's also an exception that changes the meaning of an otherwise valid program:
</p>
<ul><li>If a command would trivially cause an infinite loop, it is skipped and has no effect. A command is defined as causing a trivial infinite loop if it pushes a value to a stack, it has pushed that value to that stack before, and no stack has been popped since then.</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat_program"><a href="/wiki/Cat_program" title="Cat program">Cat program</a></span></h3>
<pre>    |\ /|
    /"^"\
    (0 0)
    \_*_/_________
      (          _^^,
      (_________) ( )
cat    |||   |||   "
       ||^   ||^
       ^^    ^^
</pre>

k7,l3.l3.K7;L3;l3.l6;l6,L3;L6,l6;l7,l7,L6;L7.l7,m1.m1,L7;M1;m1,m6;m6,
M1;M6,m6;n2;n2;M6,N2,n2;n4.n4,N2;N4,n4.N8.N4,Z4,Z4
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Incident's original documentation (in <code>examples/triangle.md</code>) noted that Minsky machines could be compiled into Incident parses "so long as no counter is the subject of more than one decrement instruction that's capable of failing", explaining how. This restriction turns out not to matter: <a href="/wiki/The_Amnesiac_From_Minsk" title="The Amnesiac From Minsk">The Amnesiac From Minsk</a> level 1 is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a>, and as it has a more stringent restriction (TAFMl1 requires all decrements of a particular counter to return to the same place, which can be implemented in Incident via jumping all decrements to a common location and then running the decrement from there), there must therefore be an Incident parse corresponding to any Turing machine.
</p><p>To prove Incident Turing complete, all that remains is to show that for any Incident parse, there's some program that parses to that parse. It turns out that this is indeed true; see the <a href="/wiki/Talk:Incident" title="Talk:Incident">talk page</a> for discussion of this subject.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li>The CALESYTA submission (including documentation, programming advice / spoilers on how to program in it, the motivation behind the language design, examples, and an implementation) can be obtained via running the command <code>darcs clone http://nethack4.org/esolangs/calesyta-2016</code>.
<ul><li>Note: the URL in question will not work in a web browser; you will need to use darcs to retrieve the submission. Alternatively, a sporadically updated tarball is available <a class="external text" href="http://nethack4.org/esolangs/calesyta-2016.tar.gz" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</li></ul></li></ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/Apraxia" title="Apraxia">Apraxia</a>, another language with similar syntax</li></ul>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>INTERCAL</b>, an abbreviation for <i>Compiler Language With No Pronounceable Acronym</i>, was created in 1972, thus probably making it the first ever <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a>. (See <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Esoteric_Languages" title="Prehistory of Esoteric Languages">Prehistory of Esoteric Languages</a> for an alternate view.)  <a href="/wiki/Donald_R._Woods" title="Donald R. Woods">Donald R. Woods</a> and <a href="/wiki/James_M._Lyon" title="James M. Lyon">James M. Lyon</a> invented it with the goal of creating a language with no similarities whatsoever to any existing programming languages. The language largely succeeds in this goal, apart from its use of an assignment statement. It also suffers from being one-dimensional, and the original version uses binary (but <a href="/wiki/TriINTERCAL" title="TriINTERCAL">TriINTERCAL</a> was created as a modern ternary version).
</p><p>INTERCAL was also the first language to have a <a href="/wiki/Wimpmode" title="Wimpmode">wimpmode</a> devised for it, due to its unusual I/O requirements.
</p><p>It has new operators, Mingle and Select operators, and unary XOR operators. Also, the symbols are called by different names: . is a spot, : a two-spot, , is a tail and ; is a hybrid. Newer INTERCAL compilers/interpreters have some new commands, such as COME FROM, and <a href="/wiki/Quantum_INTERCAL" title="Quantum INTERCAL">Quantum INTERCAL</a>, etc.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
