</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The language is named after <i>Malebolge</i> [sic], the eighth level of hell in Dante's <i>Inferno</i>, which is reserved for perpetrators of fraud. The actual spelling <i>Malbolge</i> is also used for the sixth hell in the Dungeons and Dragons roleplaying game.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Memory_initialization">Memory initialization</span></h2>
<p>The program is fed directly into the virtual machine's memory starting at position 0. Any whitespace is skipped, including newlines. Only valid instructions and whitespace are allowed in the source, but a bug in the reference implementation makes it possible to enter instructions with a code greater than 126, which hang that interpreter if executed. There's only one officially allowed NOP code that can be entered, even if many possible NOPs are possible at run time (each non-instruction that is a printable character is a NOP).
</p><p>Each word in the remainder of the memory is initialized as the result of applying the crazy operation (see below) to the contents of the previous and the second previous word (in that order).
</p><p>Note that the official specification does not cover the edge case of 1-instruction programs (for instance <code>Q</code>, which halts immediately), where trying to access the second previous word to fill up memory position 1 using the crazy operation would result in a read outside the program's memory space. The reference implementation (<a class="external text" href="https://www.lscheffer.com/malbolge_interp.html" rel="nofollow">link</a>) does not explicitly consider this case either and incurs in <a href="/wiki/Undefined_behavior" title="Undefined behavior">undefined behavior</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Virtual_machine_description">Virtual machine description</span></h2>
<p>The virtual machine is based on <i>trits</i> (<b>tri</b>nary, i.e. ternary or base 3, digi<b>ts</b>). Each machine word is ten trits wide, making it range from 0 to 2222222222 ternary = 59048 decimal. Each memory position holds a machine word; the addresses are one machine word wide too. Both data and code share the same memory space.
</p><p>(At this place it may be interesting to know that in the 1960s and 1970s trit-based computers were developed in the "eastern bloc" and still some engineers think about trit-based computers when talking about new non-silicon-based technologies.)
</p><p>There are three registers, each of which holds one machine word, initially 0: the code register <code>C</code> which is a pointer to the instruction that is about to be executed, the data register <code>D</code> used for data manipulation and the accumulator <code>A</code> also used by several instructions to manipulate data.
</p><p>If the instruction to execute is not in the range 33-126, execution stops (the reference interpreter hangs in this case due to a bug). Otherwise, in order to determine the actual instruction to execute, the value pointed to by the <code>C</code> register is added to the <code>C</code> register itself and the result divided by 94, taking the remainder. Depending on the result, the following instructions are executed:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th><code>(C+[C])%94</code>
</th>
<th>Description
</th>
<th>Pseudocode
</th>
<th>Op
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>4
</td>
<td>Set code pointer to the value pointed to by the current data pointer.
</td>
<td><code>C = [D]</code>
</td>
<td><b>i</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>5
</td>
<td>Output the character in <code>A</code>, modulo 256, to standard output.
</td>
<td><code>PRINT(A%256)</code>
</td>
<td><b>&lt;</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>23
</td>
<td>Input a character from standard input and store it in <code>A</code>.
</td>
<td><code>A = INPUT</code>
</td>
<td><b>/</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>39
</td>
<td>Tritwise rotate right.
</td>
<td><code>A = [D] = ROTATE_RIGHT([D])</code>
</td>
<td><b>*</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>40
</td>
<td>Set data pointer to the value pointed to by the current data pointer.
</td>
<td><code>D = [D]</code>
</td>
<td><b>j</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>62
</td>
<td>Tritwise "crazy" operation (see table below).
</td>
<td><code>A = [D] = CRAZY_OP(A, [D])</code>
</td>
<td><b>p</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>68
</td>
<td>No operation.
</td>
<td><code>NOP</code>
</td>
<td><b>o</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>81
</td>
<td>Stop execution of the current program.
</td>
<td><code>STOP</code>
</td>
<td><b>v</b>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(The <i>Op</i> column specifies the operation letter according to the original specification.)
</p><p><i>Note: The table above uses a criterion for input and output instruction codes that matches the reference interpreter instead of the one from the specification, which are reversed with respect to each other.</i>
</p><p>If the result is not any of the values in the table, a NOP (no operation) is executed. However no NOP instructions are allowed in the source code except those for which (C+[C])%94 = 68.
</p><p>As an example, in the first memory position (as well as in positions which are multiple of 94) the following instructions are allowed in the source code: <code>' ( &gt; D Q b c u</code>; in the second memory position the list is: <code>&amp; ' = C P a b t</code>, and so on, decreasing the code at each step and wrapping from <code>!</code> to <code>~</code>.
</p><p>The "crazy" operation is defined according to the following table. It operates on corresponding trits of each machine word (it's a "tritwise" operation).
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="2" rowspan="2">
</th>
<th colspan="3" style="text-align:center"><b><code>A</code></b>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th><b><code>0</code></b>
</th>
<th><b><code>1</code></b>
</th>
<th><b><code>2</code></b>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3"><b><code>[D]</code></b>
</th>
<th><b><code>0</code></b>
</th>
<td><code>1</code>
</td>
<td><code>0</code>
</td>
<td><code>0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><code>1</code>
</th>
<td><code>1</code>
</td>
<td><code>0</code>
</td>
<td><code>2</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><code>2</code>
</th>
<td><code>2</code>
</td>
<td><code>2</code>
</td>
<td><code>1</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>After each instruction is executed, if the memory position pointed to by <code>C</code> is in the range 33–126 then it is enciphered using the following translation table:
</p>
<pre>ORIGINAL:    !"#$%&amp;'()*+,-./0123456789:;&lt;=&gt;?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~
TRANSLATED:  5z]&amp;gqtyfr$(we4{WP)H-Zn,[%\3dL+Q;&gt;U!pJS72FhOA1CB6v^=I_0/8|jsb9m&lt;.TVac`uY*MK'X~xDl}REokN:#?G"i@
</pre>
<p>(that is, ! becomes 5, " becomes z, and so on). If it is not in the range 33–126 then the result is undefined (the reference interpreter has a bug in this case that can potentially cause a crash).
</p><p>After the ciphering step is performed, both <code>C</code> and <code>D</code> are incremented modulo 3<sup>10</sup> (59049 decimal) and the execution cycle is repeated.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Malbolge is in the class of <a href="/wiki/Bounded-storage_machine" title="Bounded-storage machine">bounded-storage machines</a>. It is superior to any <a href="/wiki/Linear_bounded_automaton" title="Linear bounded automaton">linear bounded automaton</a> due to its ability to perform arbitrary loops, as can be seen in <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hisashi_Iizawa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hisashi Iizawa (page does not exist)">Hisashi Iizawa's</a> Malbolge program which implements <a href="/wiki/99_bottles_of_beer" title="99 bottles of beer">99 bottles of beer</a> (<a class="external text" href="http://www.99-bottles-of-beer.net/language-malbolge-995.html" rel="nofollow">link</a>). It cannot be <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> due to its limited memory.
</p><p>Lou Scheffer <a class="external text" href="http://www.lscheffer.com/malbolge.shtml" rel="nofollow">defines a variant "Malbolge-T" (see section "Proving formal Turing completeness")</a> which provides access to unlimited memory via allowing the program to read its own output, and believes this variant to be Turing complete (although it has not yet been demonstrated that a program space of 59049 words is large enough).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Malbolge_Unshackled" title="Malbolge Unshackled">Malbolge Unshackled</a> is a language based on Malbolge, which eliminates the memory restrictions by extending the commands to be able to address arbitrarily many addresses. Malbolge Unshackled is Turing complete, with a Lisp interpreter available.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sample_programs">Sample programs</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat">Cat</span></h3>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Cat_program" title="Cat program">cat program</a> in Malbolge (this one does not stop on EOF; one which does is several orders of magnitude more complex):
</p>
<pre>(=BA#9"=&lt;;:3y7x54-21q/p-,+*)"!h%B0/.
~P&lt;
&lt;:(8&amp;
66#"!~}|{zyxwvu
gJ%</pre>
<p>The same program translated to <i>normalized Malbolge</i> for clarity:
</p>
<pre>jpoo*pjoooop*ojoopoo*ojoooooppjoivvv
o/i
&lt;iviv
i&lt;vvvvvvvvvvvvv
oji
</pre>
<p>(<i>Normalized Malbolge</i> means with the instructions decrypted to match the original specification, but in this variant every instruction has a different value when interpreted as data, depending on the address modulo 94. The term <i>normalized Malbolge</i> was coined by Andrew Cooke as can be seen in the <i>External resources</i> section below.)
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Truth-machine">Truth-machine</span></h3>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Truth-machine" title="Truth-machine">truth-machine</a> in Malbolge can be found here: <a href="/wiki/Truth-machine#Malbolge" title="Truth-machine">Truth-machine#Malbolge</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dis" title="Dis">Dis</a>, a slightly less evil version (or <a href="/wiki/Wimpmode" title="Wimpmode">Wimpmode</a>) of Malbolge</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Malbolge20" title="Malbolge20">Malbolge20</a>, an extension of Malbolge to 20 trits</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Malbolge_Unshackled" title="Malbolge Unshackled">Malbolge Unshackled</a>, an attempt to make a Turing complete dialect of Malbolge</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Malbolge_programming" title="Malbolge programming">How to write Malbolge programs</a></li></ul>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p>match is an esoteric programming language created by <a href="/wiki/User:Japi" title="User:Japi">User:Japi</a>. It follows a functional programming paradigm.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Basic_Features"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Basic Features</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Functions"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Functions</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Expressions_and_Patterns"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Expressions and Patterns</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Pairs"><span class="tocnumber">1.3</span> <span class="toctext">Pairs</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Command_line_arguments"><span class="tocnumber">1.4</span> <span class="toctext">Command line arguments</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Guards"><span class="tocnumber">1.5</span> <span class="toctext">Guards</span></a></li>

</ul>

<ul>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10"><a href="#truth-machine"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">truth-machine</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11"><a href="#Sum_of_list"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Sum of list</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Basic_Features">Basic Features</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Functions">Functions</span></h3>
<p>Every program is made up of functions. They are defined by their name, pattern branches, and expressions to evaluate. Each branch is terminated by a semicolon, and the whole function is terminated by another semicolon.
</p>
<pre>name:
    pattern1 -&gt; expr1;
    pattern2 -&gt; expr2;
    ...
    patternN -&gt; exprN;;
</pre>
<p>For example, here is a function that adds one to the argument.
</p>
<pre>add_one:
    number -&gt; number + 1;;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Expressions_and_Patterns">Expressions and Patterns</span></h3>
<p>Parentheses can be used in both patterns and expressions.
There are only a few literals:
</p>
<pre> 'a'   | character literal
 "Hi"  | string literal
 1.3   | number literal
 false | boolean literal
 nil   | nil literal, marks the end of a cons list
</pre>
<p>String literals can only be used in expressions, everything else can be used in both patterns and expressions.
There are some basic binary operators:
</p>
<pre> +    | Adds two numbers
 -    | Subtract two numbers
 *    | Multiplies two numbers
 /    | Divides two numbers
 ,    | Makes a pair, usually called <i>cons</i> (right-assoc)
 %    | Modulus operator
 &lt;    | Less than operator
 &gt;    | Greater than operator
 =    | Equality check
 then | Returns the result of the right hand side
</pre>
<p>In patterns, you can match on literals, deconstruct pairs, and bind results to values. To call a function, you can use the C-style syntax.
</p>
<pre>print("Hello, world!")
</pre>
<p>Although, commas will be treated as part of the expression and not separation between arguments because every function takes one argument.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pairs">Pairs</span></h3>
<p>Because there is no easy way to curry functions, multiple arguments are usually passed via a cons list, or just a pair. String literals are actually just a cons list of characters. Both of these expressions evaluate to the same thing.
</p>
<pre>'h', 'i', nil
"hi"
</pre>
<p>This is also the reason why they can't be used in patterns, you'll have to use the character literals directly for matching on strings.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Command_line_arguments">Command line arguments</span></h3>
<p>The main function accepts an argument, that argument is usually thrown away with a wildcard pattern but it represents the command line arguments for the program. They are given via a cons list, where if there were no arguments given it would be nil.
</p>
<pre>main: args -&gt; println(args);;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Guards">Guards</span></h3>
<p>Guards can be added to patterns after a colon. The guard's value must be a boolean, and only one guard can be supplied to a pattern. The filter function is a good example of this, it takes a list and a predicate, and filters the list to a list only containing the values that follow that predicate.
</p>
<pre>filter:
    nil, _ -&gt; nil;
    (x, xs), pred: pred(x) -&gt; x, filter(xs, pred);
    (x, xs), pred -&gt; filter(xs, pred);;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Includes">Includes</span></h3>
<p>You can also include a specific file in your code like this:
</p>
<pre>include "other_file.match"
</pre>
<p>It'll import all the definitions of the functions in that file and the includes int that file, and allow you to use it in your code. You can do multiple includes from anywhere in the program, and any include from a specific file will only be included once. So if a file <i>predicates.match</i> looked like this:
</p>
<pre>even: n -&gt; n % 2 = 0;;
</pre>
<p>Then a file <i>main.match</i> could look like this:
</p>
<pre>include "predicates.match"

main: _ -&gt; println(even(2));;
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_world.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_world!">Hello, world!</span></h3>
<pre>main: _ -&gt; println("Hello, world!");;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="truth-machine">truth-machine</span></h3>
<pre>truth:
    '0', nil -&gt; println(0);
    '1', nil -&gt; print(1) then truth("1");
    _ -&gt; error("Please type a '0' or '1'.");;
main:
    _ -&gt; print("Type a '0' or '1': ") then truth(readln(nil));;
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sum_of_list">Sum of list</span></h3>
<pre>sum:
    nil -&gt; 0;
    x, xs -&gt; x + sum(xs);;
main:
   _ -&gt; println(sum(1, 2, 3, 4, nil));;
</pre>
<p>This should output 10.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Moed</b> (pronounced /mid/) is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> by <a href="/wiki/User:Dhzb" title="User:Dhzb">User:Dhzb</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<ul>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Execution"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Execution</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Data_storage"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Data storage</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Imperae"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Imperae</span></a>
<ul>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Whitespace">Whitespace</span></h2>
<p>Whitespace is <i>sometimes</i> significant.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Newlines">Newlines</span></h3>
<p>Newlines can be scoped inside of <code>{...}</code> groups which can be targeted by newline-imperae.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Execution">Execution</span></h2>
<p>Moed executes in a given direction which is initialized to 1 (right), the direction can be changed to other values by using one of three dexterimperae.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Data_storage">Data storage</span></h2>
<p>Moed primarily uses the <a href="/wiki/Stack" title="Stack">stack</a> to store short-term data but also provides a secondary medium which is the <a href="/wiki/Matrix_(data_structure)" title="Matrix (data structure)">matrix</a>.
</p><p>When an empty stack is popped, it returns 0.
</p><p>The memory matrix is infinite in all directions.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Imperae">Imperae</span></h2>
<p>Currently, Moed has 2 types of imperae: <i>Dexterimperae</i> and <i>Sinisterimperae</i>.
Each imperae has an associated symbol to represent it.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dexterimperae">Dexterimperae</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<caption>All dexterimperae
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>Symbol</th>
<th>Version</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>0-9</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Digit</td>
<td>Pushes the corresponding digit onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&gt;</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Right</td>
<td>Sets the direction of execution to 1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&lt;</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Left</td>
<td>Sets the direction of execution to -1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>|</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Mirror</td>
<td>Mirrors (by negating) the execution direction
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>_</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Newline</td>
<td>Jumps to the next character of the next newline in the current scope
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>"</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Subnewline</td>
<td>Pops n and jumps to the next character of the next newline in the scope n levels up
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>=</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Skip</td>
<td>Skips over one execution step (including groups as one execution step)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>+</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Addition</td>
<td>Pops x and y and pushes x+y onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>-</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Subtraction</td>
<td>Pops x and y and pushes x-y onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>*</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Multiplication</td>
<td>Pops x and y and pushes x×y onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>/</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Division</td>
<td>Pops x and y and pushes x÷y onto the stack (0 divisor returns 0)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>%</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Modulo</td>
<td>Pops x and y and pushes x mod y onto the stack (negative wraps around, 0 divisor returns 0)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>^</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Exponentiation</td>
<td>Pops x and y and pushes x<sup>y</sup> onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>\</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Swap</td>
<td>Swaps the top 2 values on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>$</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Discard</td>
<td>Pops a value and discards it
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>'</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Character</td>
<td>Skips one execution step and pushes the character at the execution pointer onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>:</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Duplicate</td>
<td>Duplicates the top value on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>;</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>N-duplicate</td>
<td>Pops n and duplicates the nth value from the top of the stack (starting at 0) to the top of the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&amp;</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Incharacter</td>
<td>Gets a character from input
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>?</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Auxiliary incharacter</td>
<td>Gets a character from auxiliary input
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>#</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Innumber</td>
<td>Gets a number literal from input
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>,</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Outcharacter</td>
<td>Outputs a character from the stack (pop)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>.</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Outnumber</td>
<td>Outputs a number literal from the stack (pop)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>`</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Unvalencitudinity</td>
<td>If top of stack (don't pop) is nonzero, continue forwards, otherwise mirror+skip
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>~</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Sinisterimpera toggle</td>
<td>Interpret the characters as sinisterimperae from now on
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>@</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Stop</td>
<td>Halts the program execution
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>(...)</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Special</td>
<td>Does a <a href="#special_operations">special operation</a> based on the first character in it and the rest of the string
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>J</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Jump</td>
<td>Pops n and jumps to the nth j relative to the current character
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>I</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Pause</td>
<td>Pauses execution
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>R</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Return</td>
<td>Returns to the previous location before a custom impera call
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Any other character</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Call</td>
<td>Goes to the location associated with the character
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sinisterimperae">Sinisterimperae</span></h3>
<table class="wikitable">
<caption>All sinisterimperae
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>Symbol</th>
<th>Version</th>
<th>Name</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>|</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Set</td>
<td>Pops y, x, and v and sets the value at the corresponding position x,y in the matrix to v
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>^</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Get</td>
<td>Pops y and x and pushes the value at the corresponding position x,y in the matrix onto the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>=</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Skip</td>
<td>Does the same as it is as a dexterimpera except that it doesn't skip groups
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>?</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Random</td>
<td>Pushes a random number in the range [0,1)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>.</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Floor</td>
<td>Applies a floor function on the top value on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>:</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Ceiling</td>
<td>Applies a ceiling function on the top value on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>;</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Round</td>
<td>Applies a round function on the top value on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>*</td>
<td>C1</td>
<td>Sign</td>
<td>Gets the sign of the top value on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>~</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Dexterimpera toggle</td>
<td>Interpret the characters as dexterimperae from now on
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Any other character</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td></td>
<td>Does nothing
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Special_operations">Special operations</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable">
<caption>All special operations
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>First character</th>
<th>Version</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>"</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Pushes the rest of the string onto the stack starting from the end of the string
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&amp;</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Prints the rest of the string
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>=</td>
<td>B1</td>
<td>Associates a location (after the '=') with the popped character on the stack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Any other character</td>
<td>A1</td>
<td>Does nothing
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/Moed/Examples" title="Moed/Examples">Moed/Examples</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/User:Dhzb" title="User:Dhzb">User:Dhzb</a> has created a <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a> <a href="/wiki/Moed/Examples#Brainfuck_interpreter" title="Moed/Examples">interpreter</a> with infinite cells in Moed <a class="external autonumber" href="https://abhipraya.id/moed?f=bfinterpret2.moed&amp;t=0" rel="nofollow">[1]</a>, therefore, Moed is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">turing-complete</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementation">Implementation</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="http://abhipraya.id/moed" rel="nofollow">p5js interpreter</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_additions">Future additions</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Moed-B1">Moed-B1</span></h3>
<ul><li>[✓] Custom operations (e.g. <code>'√(=21/\^)</code>) -- <i>now <code>'√(=21/\^R)</code></i></li>
<li>[✓] Pause execution</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Moed-A2">Moed-A2</span></h3>
<ul><li>[__] Additional memory slots in every other dimension</li>
<li>[__] Internet connection</li></ul>
<!-- 
NewPP limit report
Cached time: 20250816155634
Cache expiry: 86400
Reduced expiry: false
Complications: [show‐toc]
CPU time usage: 0.029 seconds
Real time usage: 0.030 seconds
Preprocessor visited node count: 62/1000000
Post‐expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes

-->
<!--
Transclusion expansion time report (%,ms,calls,template)
100.00%    0.000      1 -total
-->
<!-- Saved in parser cache with key esolang_wiki:pcache:idhash:22289-0!canonical and timestamp 20250816155634 and revision id 163488. Rendering was triggered because: page-view
 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p>Momema is a boring imperative language with memory-mapped control flow created by <a href="/wiki/User:Challenger5" title="User:Challenger5">User:Challenger5</a> in 2018. Its only real gimmick is to unify (or, more accurately, to lump) jump labels and (relative) jump statements. It was created due to a dissatisfaction with many similar languages that were in common use on PPCG, and to experiment with the creation of a very high quality interpreter (it supports a full interactive mode with a REPL, breakpoints, state debugging, etc.).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_Overview">Language Overview</span></h2>
<p>A Momema program has access to a doubly-infinite tape of unbounded integers, indexed by unbounded integers. A program consists of a list of assignment statements. An assignment statement consists of two expressions, and has the semantics of storing the result of the second expression in the tape cell given by the result of the first.
</p>
<pre>4   0
</pre>
<p>This assigns the value of the cell at index <code>4</code> to <code>0</code>, which is useless since all cells are initialized to <code>0</code> anyway.
</p>
<pre>-8  0
</pre>
<p>The cells <code>-8</code> and <code>-9</code> are memory mapped for I/O. Reading and writing numbers from the cell <code>-9</code> will output and input the corresponding Unicode character, respectively. <code>-8</code> is the same, but works with numbers rather than character codes. <code>-9</code> will return <code>-1</code> on EOF; <code>-8</code> will simply halt the program.
</p>
<pre>0   *-8
-8  *0
</pre>
<p>The <code>*</code> operator "dereferences" an integer, returning the value of the tape cell at that location. This program reads from cell <code>-8</code> to read an integer from STDIN, and then writes to <code>-8</code> to write it back out.
</p>
<pre>-8  + 5 5
</pre>
<p>The prefix <code>+</code> operator adds two numbers. This prints <code>10</code>.
</p>
<pre>0   = 0
1   = -5
</pre>
<p>The <code>=</code> operator returns <code>0</code> if its argument is <code>0</code>, and <code>1</code> otherwise.
</p>
<pre>j 0
j -1
</pre>
<p>The <code>j</code> command is both a label and a jump: it takes an argument and jumps forward (or backwards, if negative) past that many labels. It follows that an argument of <code>0</code> does nothing, and only serves as a label.
</p><p>This program is an infinite loop.
</p>
<pre>j   0
r   *5
5   1
j   1
r   0
</pre>
<p>In fact, any string of lowercase characters acts like <code>j</code>, and only pays attention to jumps with their own label.
</p><p>In this program, execution proceeds as follows: the initial <code>j</code> has an argument of <code>0</code>, and does nothing. The first <code>r</code> gets the value at cell <code>5</code>, returning <code>0</code>, so it, too, does nothing. After this, we encounter an instruction that sets cell <code>5</code> to <code>1</code>. The second <code>j</code> instruction has an argument of <code>1</code>, but since there are no further <code>j</code> jumps in the program, it wraps around and starts searching from the beginning, causing a jump to the first <code>j</code>. This time, the argument to <code>r</code> is <code>1</code>, so we jump forward to the second <code>r</code>, ending the program.
</p><p>More information about the langauge, as well as an implementation, can be found <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/Reconcyl/eso/tree/main/momema" rel="nofollow">on github</a>.
</p>
<!--

 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><table style="float:right;border:1px solid silver;background-color:rgb(249, 249, 249);max-width:256px;padding:5px;">
<caption><b>MoreMathRPN</b></caption>
<tbody><tr>
<td colspan="2"><figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:MoreMathLogo.png"><img class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="200" src="/w/images/7/77/MoreMathLogo.png" width="200"/></a><figcaption></figcaption></figure></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;"><a href="/wiki/Esolang:Categorization#Paradigm" title="Esolang:Categorization">Paradigm(s)</a></th>
<td>imperative, functional</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Designed by</th>
<td><a href="/wiki/User:Calculus_is_fun" title="User:Calculus is fun">User:Calculus is fun</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>

<td>2023</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;"><a href="/wiki/Computational_class" title="Computational class">Computational class</a></th>
<td>Turing-Complete</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Major implementations</th>
<td><a class="external text" href="https://erikhaag.github.io/More-Math-rpn/" rel="nofollow">JavaScript</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Influenced by</th>
<td><a href="/wiki/FALSE" title="FALSE">FALSE</a>, TI-BASIC</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<dl><dd><i>Unless otherwise specified, "or" is exclusive or.</i></dd></dl>
<p><b>MoreMathRPN</b> (abbreviated <b>MMRPN</b>) is a stack based imperative language created in 2023, created by <a href="/wiki/User:Calculus_is_fun" title="User:Calculus is fun">Calculus is fun</a> (<a href="/wiki/User_talk:Calculus_is_fun" title="User talk:Calculus is fun">talk</a>).<br/>
Originally for simple linear algebra, it has since grown to be turing complete. It is inspired by <a href="/wiki/FALSE" title="FALSE">FALSE</a> and its relatives, whilst also being more human friendly.
</p><p>Using relative offsets over absolute positions is the primary philosophy of MMRPN,
no labels, nor line numbers.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commands">Commands</span></h2>
<p>Each line must have only one command, breakpoint, or comment.<br/>
While not part of the standard, MMRPN reserves "!!!" to be a breakpoint, if you write an interpreter or compiler, your code should at least behave like a breakpoint and its line doesn't exist
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literals">Literals</span></h3>
<p>This language has rational and string literals,
there are 4 ways to input a Rational:
</p>
<ul><li>Integers e.g. 10</li>
<li>Ratio of 2 integers e.g. 3/5</li>
<li>Terminating decimal e.g. 3.894</li>
<li>Recurring decimal e.g. 1.1[32] -or- 0.[3]</li></ul>
<p>You can prepend a hyphen to negate the value, and periods can be substituted with commas.<br/>
<b>String literals can only be in an instruction's parameters</b>,<br/>
they are double quoted strings that allow spaces; most literal UTF-8 characters; along with \\, \", and \n escape characters.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Instructions">Instructions</span></h3>
<p>There are 2 types of input a command has, <b>Parameters</b> and <b>Arguments</b>.
Parameters are integers placed after the command and separated by spaces. Arguments are from the stack and can be rational (R) or matrices (M), if needed; variables will be denoted [top] a, b, c, ... [bottom]
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Standard_operations">Standard operations</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Operation symbol/name</th>
<th>Description / Formula</th>
<th>Parameters</th>
<th>Arguments
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>"</td>
<td>Comment (see examples below)</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>+</td>
<td>Addition</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>2 R or 2 M
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>-</td>
<td>Subtraction (b -  a)</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>2 R
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>*</td>
<td>Multiplication</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>2 R, 2 M, or 1 R and 1 M
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>/</td>
<td>Division (b / a)</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>2 R
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>%</td>
<td>Remainder (b % a)</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>2 R
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>int</td>
<td>Rounds towards 0</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>1 R
</td></tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>outer</td>
<td>Outer product</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>2 M
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Loops">Loops</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Operation symbol/name</th>
<th>Description / Formula</th>
<th>Parameters</th>
<th>Arguments
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>jmp</td>
<td>Jump to</td>
<td>Offset</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>repeat</td>
<td>Repeat loop</td>
<td>End Count</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>next</td>
<td>Next iteration</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&gt;&gt;&gt;</td>
<td>Iteration number</td>
<td>Loop Depth</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>break</td>
<td>Break out of current loop</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>leap</td>
<td>Break out of current loop, then jump</td>
<td>Offset</td>
<td>None
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Variables">Variables</span></h4>
<p>Variable names can not have spaces nor start with ".
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Operation symbol/name</th>
<th>Description / Formula</th>
<th>Parameters</th>
<th>Arguments
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>hold</td>
<td>Store top of stack as variable</td>
<td>Name</td>
<td>1 R or 1 M
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>place</td>
<td>Place copy of variable to stack</td>
<td>Name</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>lose</td>
<td>Remove a variable</td>
<td>Name</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>exists</td>
<td>Exists (does variable exist? yes → 1, no → 0)</td>
<td>Name</td>
<td>None
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span id="IO_.26_strings"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="IO_&amp;_strings">IO &amp; strings</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Operation symbol/name</th>
<th>Description / Formula</th>
<th>Parameters</th>
<th>Arguments
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>chars</td>
<td>Converts a string's UTF-8 code points in reverse order (end is at the bottom), then tops it with the string's length.</td>
<td>String</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>inputR</td>
<td>Prompts the user to input a number in a valid format as described above, if invalid, the program will ask again.<br/>The prompt message is an optional parameter, and not giving it should default to a generic message.</td>
<td>Prompt (optional)</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>inputS</td>
<td>Prompts the user to input a string, converts the response's UTF-8 code points in reverse order (end is at the bottom), then tops it with the string's length.<br/>The prompt message is an optional parameter, and not giving it should default to a generic message.</td>
<td>Prompt (optional)</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>inputSE</td>
<td>Prompts the user to input a string potentially containing escaped characters (especially \n &amp; \\), converts the response's UTF-8 code points in reverse order (end is at the bottom), then tops it with the string's length.<br/>The prompt message is an optional parameter, and not giving it should default to a generic message.</td>
<td>Prompt (optional)</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>outputC</td>
<td>Outputs a single character whose code point is the parameter</td>
<td>Code point</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>outputS</td>
<td>Outputs a string</td>
<td>String</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>outputV</td>
<td>Pops and outputs a rational or matrix, format depends on implementation</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>1 R or 1 M
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>error</td>
<td>Outputs a string as an error message, and stops execution</td>
<td>String</td>
<td>None
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Lambda_functions">Lambda functions</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Operation symbol/name</th>
<th>Description / Formula</th>
<th>Parameters</th>
<th>Arguments
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>run</td>
<td>interprets a row matrix as a string, then interprets the string</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>1 M (single row)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>end</td>
<td>Stops the current program, useful with <code>run</code> commands</td>
<td>None</td>
<td>None
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>halt</td>
<td>Halt and catch fire</td>
<td>none</td>
<td>none
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Tip</b>: I recommend you write any code normally, place <code>chars "</code> before the first instruction then use a macro that presses the End, Delete, \, n keys in that order exactly once. AutoHotKey is great for this.
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes_on_recursion">Notes on recursion</span></h5>
<p>While recursion is allowed with <code>run</code>, please avoid deep recursion, instead use a system akin to the first <a href="#Ackermann_function">#Ackermann function</a> example, with a <i>return path</i> using <code>jmp</code>.
</p><p>The <code>run</code> command should only be used if:
</p>
<ul><li>You're calling a sequence of commands multiple times, in different contexts (i.e. both inside and outside a <code>repeat...next</code> block).</li>
<li>You need to jump over a code block that can be changed by another person.</li>
<li>A function is a parameter of another function, like <a class="external text" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduce" rel="nofollow">Array.reduce()</a>.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dynamic_parameters">Dynamic parameters</span></h3>
<p>You might be thinking how if-else statements are going to happen in this language; fortunately, parameters can be controlled by the program, these get rounded towards 0 if the rational is not an integer.
</p>
<ul><li>]n grabs the nth item from the top of the stack</li>
<li>[n grabs the nth item from the bottom of the stack</li>
<li>$name uses a variable</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Behavior">Behavior</span></h2>
<p>Certain commands have specific actions given interesting conditions, here's a list of those conditions.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infinity">Infinity</span></h3>
<p>In normal mathematics, dividing by zero (0) is disallowed, due to inevitable paradoxes that occur, but guess what? This is a programming language, where having a value of greatest magnitude is useful! so infinity is here:
</p>
<pre>"Positive infinity
1/0
"Negative infinity
"-1/0
</pre>
<p>While Infinity <i>does</i> work in other situations, it gets real weird. If you subtract infinity from infinity, multiply infinity by zero, or other zany operations, you'll run into a special "Indeterminate form" error, when MMRPN can't give a good answer.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Repeat_without_next">Repeat without next</span></h3>
<p>If a <code>repeat</code> is missing a corresponding <code>next</code>, It is inferred to be at the end of the program, but the loop won't repeat. Either <code>break</code> or <code>leap</code> will end the program if run in an incomplete <code>repeat</code> statement.
</p>
<pre>repeat 10
 3
 5
 break
 5
 1
 "next statement inferred here!
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nested_loops">Nested loops</span></h3>
<p><code>repeat ... next</code> blocks can be nested, helpful for simplifying advanced patterns
</p>
<pre>repeat 10
 repeat 10
  "outer
  &gt;&gt;&gt; 1
  "inner
  &gt;&gt;&gt; 0
  +
  2
  -
 next
next
m 10 10
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Out_of_the_loop">Out of the loop</span></h3>
<p>calling <code>break</code> or <code>leap</code> outside the active loop results in an error.<br/>
It is recommend to keep looping code in the <code>repeat...next</code> block.
</p>
<pre>repeat 10
 jmp 2
next
"Error!
break
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leaping_back">Leaping back</span></h3>
<p><code>leap</code> with a negative parameter behaves like <code>break</code>, this is to dissuade the act of jumping into the repeat you just left.
</p>
<pre>"You would expect this to be an infinite loop, but it isn't.
repeat 1
 "I'm now a break!
 leap -2
next
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Zero_jmp">Zero jmp</span></h3>
<p>When <code>jmp</code> is given a parameter of 0, <code>jmp</code> does nothing, this is so you don't have to write <code>1 +</code> every time you use it. See examples below.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<p>More examples can be found <a class="external text" href="https://erikhaag.github.io/More-Math-rpn/examples.html" rel="nofollow">here</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_conditions">Creating conditions</span></h3>
<p>Conditions are often created via the <code>step</code> or <code>compare</code> instructions, then by evaluating an polynomial function and feeding that into a <code>jmp</code>, complex branching behavior can appear.
</p>
<pre>"change me to 1, 2 or 3
1
"1 → "1", 2 → "21", 3 -&gt; "31"
&gt;&gt; 0
&gt;&gt; 0
*
-2
/
-&gt; 1
2
/
4
+
+
jmp ]0
outputS "3"
jmp 2
outputS "2"
outputS "1"
</pre>
<p>You can also use <code>repeat</code> with a parameter of 1 or 0, to run or skip a block of lines.
</p>
<pre>"0 or 1
0
repeat ]0
 1
 2
 3
 4
 "dummy
 1
next
del 0
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fibonnaci">Fibonnaci</span></h3>
<p>This program repeatedly adds the previous 2 numbers forever
</p>
<pre>0
1
&gt;&gt; 1
&gt;&gt; 1
+
jmp -3
</pre>
<p>We can use the repeat instruction to limit the repetitions
</p>
<pre>0
1
"repeat 50 times...
repeat 50
 "indentation of code is optional, but preferred
 &gt;&gt; 1
 &gt;&gt; 1
 +
next
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Factorial">Factorial</span></h3>
<p>Calculating the factorial is also easy
</p>
<pre>"argument
5
1
repeat ]1
 &gt;&gt;&gt; 0
 *
next
del 1
"120 should be alone
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coefficients_of_a_cubic">Coefficients of a cubic</span></h3>
<p>Using the matrix commands, one can solve a linear system quickly.
</p>
<pre>"degree + 1
repeat 4
 1
 &gt;&gt;&gt; 0
 1
 -
 "degree
 repeat 3
  &gt;&gt; 1
  &gt;&gt; 1
  *
  -&gt; 1
 next
 del 0
 m 1 4
next
"degree
repeat 3
 aug
next
T
flip
inv
"f(0)
0
"f(1)
1
"f(2)
4
"f(3)
-13
m 1 4
*
"x^3, x^2, x^1, x^0
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat">Cat</span></h3>
<p>Takes the input and returns it; Unless you send the empty string, then it terminates. 
</p>
<pre>inputS
hold len
step
3
*
jmp ]0
del 0
jmp 7
del 0
repeat $len
 outputC ]0
 del 0
next
jmp -13
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="99_bottles_of_beer">99 bottles of beer</span></h3>
<p>Use the IO commands and get <i>very</i> hammered.
</p>
<pre>99
repeat 97
 &gt;&gt; 0
 &gt;&gt; 0
 1
 -
 &gt;&gt; 0
 &lt;- 3
 &lt;- 3
 outputV
 outputS " bottles of beer on the wall,\n"
 outputV
 outputS " bottles of beer.\nTake one down pass it around,\n"
 outputV
 outputS " bottles of beer on the wall.\n"
next
del 0
"Deal with singular bottle.
1
2
2
outputV
outputS " bottles of beer on the wall,\n"
outputV
outputS " bottles of beer.\nTake one down pass it around,\n"
outputV
outputS " bottle of beer on the wall.\n"
1
1
outputV
outputS " bottle of beer on the wall,\n"
outputV
outputS " bottle of beer.\nTake one down pass it around,\nOops, we ran out of beer!"
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Using_run">Using run</span></h3>
<p>With the assistance of other commands, you can create functions with a similar syntax to <a href="/wiki/FALSE" title="FALSE">FALSE</a>.
</p>
<pre>chars "outputS \"Hello, world!\""
hold len
del 0
m $len 1
flip
hold hello
del 0
"...
place hello
run
</pre>
<p>You can also use <code>aug</code> in various ways to create dynamic functions, such as creating unique variable names
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fractran_interpreter"><a href="/wiki/Fractran" title="Fractran">Fractran</a> interpreter</span></h3>
<p>It's fitting that a language based on rationals can run Fractran.
Here's John Conway's prime program.
</p>
<pre>"program
17/91
78/85
19/51
23/38
29/33
77/29
95/23
77/19
1/17
11/13
13/11
15/14
15/2
55/1
#
hold len
del 0
m $len 1
"input
2
"loop
-&gt; 1
&gt;&gt; 1
repeat $len
 "read fraction
 &gt;&gt;&gt; 0
 1
 -
 -&gt; 2
 ind ]1 0
 -&gt; 1
 &lt;- 3
 del 1
 "check validity
 &gt;&gt; 1
 *
 &gt;&gt; 0
 1
 %
 step
 2
 *
 jmp ]0
 "success
 leap 2
 "failure
 del 0
 del 0
next
"exit
jmp 4
"update input
del 0
del 1
"iterate again
jmp -27
</pre>
<p>Because we can run Fractran directly, this proves MMRPN is Turing-complete
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Brainfuck_interpreter"><a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">Brainfuck</a> interpreter</span></h3>
<p>It is quite monstrous, at 356 lines, I put it in it's own section:
<a href="/wiki/MoreMathRPN/Brainfuck_interpreter" title="MoreMathRPN/Brainfuck interpreter">go view it →</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quine"><a href="/wiki/Quine" title="Quine">Quine</a></span></h3>
<p>I have 2 quines available for you, again they are big, so here's another section: <a href="/wiki/MoreMathRPN/Quine" title="MoreMathRPN/Quine">go view it →</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Implicit_plotter">Implicit plotter</span></h3>
<p>Want to use the worst plotter known to man? Yes? Ok then, <a href="/wiki/MoreMathRPN/Implicit_plotter" title="MoreMathRPN/Implicit plotter"> take a look →</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ackermann_function"><a href="/wiki/Ackermann_function" title="Ackermann function">Ackermann function</a></span></h3>
<p>This function requires recursion; with a little planning however, you can use the stack as a call stack too!
</p>
<pre>"m
3
"n
3
"----
43
jmp 3
"return path
-&gt; 1
jmp ]0
"begin A(m,n) form m, n, return location
&lt;- 2
"m==0
&gt;&gt; 1
step
6
*
jmp ]0
"true
del 0
"n + 1
del 1
1
+
"return
jmp -12
"false
"n==0
del 0
&gt;&gt; 0
step
10
*
jmp ]0
"true
del 0
del 0
1
-
1
25
"A(m-1,1)
jmp -23
del 0
"return
jmp -27
"false
del 0
&gt;&gt; 1
-&gt; 1
1
-
34
"A(m, n-1)
jmp -32
del 0
-&gt; 1
1
-
-&gt; 1
41
"A(m-1,A(m,n-1))
jmp -39
del 0
"return
jmp -43
"end A(m,n)
del 0
outputV
</pre>
<p>If you want to use <code>run</code>:
</p>
<pre>3
3
outputS "A("
&gt;&gt; 1
outputV
outputS ", "
&gt;&gt; 0
outputV
outputS ")"
chars "&gt;&gt; 1\nstep\n6\n*\njmp ]0\ndel 0\ndel 1\n1\n+\nend\ndel 0\n&gt;&gt; 0\nstep\n9\n*\njmp ]0\ndel 0\ndel 0\n1\n-\n1\nplace Ackermann\nrun\nend\ndel 0\n1\n-\n&gt;&gt; 1\n1\n-\n&lt;- 2\nrepeat 2\nplace Ackermann\nrun\nnext\nend"
hold Ackermann
del 0
m $Ackermann 1
flip
hold Ackermann
run
outputS " = "
outputV
</pre>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Muriel</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> designed by <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Matthew_Westcott&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Matthew Westcott (page does not exist)">Matthew Westcott</a> in 2001.
</p>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21"><a href="#Bub_interpreter"><span class="tocnumber">7.11</span> <span class="toctext">Bub interpreter</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-22"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-23"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The name Muriel is an acronym that stands for <b>Monumentally Useless Re-Iterative Execution Language</b>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_model">Computational model</span></h2>
<p>Like <a href="/wiki/SMITH" title="SMITH">SMITH</a>, Muriel has no traditional control structures.  Instead, Muriel has a command to replace the currently running Muriel program with a given string, and run that instead.  This leads to a programming method where a program must <a href="/wiki/Quine" title="Quine">quine</a> itself in order to perform any sort of loop.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="General_syntax">General syntax</span></h2>
<p>A Muriel program consists of zero or more instructions separated by ; (semicolons).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Instructions">Instructions</span></h2>
<table>
<tbody><tr>
<td><code>a:0</code>
</td>
<td>Assign the integer variable <code>a</code> with the value <code>0</code>. Integer variables can be any lowercase letter [a-z] and value can be any integer expression.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>A:"Foo"</code>
</td>
<td>Assign the string variable <code>A</code> with the value <code>Foo</code>. String variables can be any uppercase letter [A-Z] and value can be any string expression.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>."Foo"</code>
</td>
<td>Output <code>Foo</code>. Can be any string expression.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>@".$0"</code>
</td>
<td>Execute the Muriel program <code>.$0</code>. Can be any string expression. Variables in the current program are not passed down and control does not return to the parent program on completion.
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Expressions">Expressions</span></h2>
<p>If multiple expressions are chained, they are evaluated left to right. Brackets can be used to determine the order of operation (<code>$1+1</code> is invalid but <code>$(1+1)</code> is <code>"2"</code>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Integer">Integer</span></h3>
<table>
<tbody><tr>
<td><code>123</code>
</td>
<td>Integer literal in decimal. Can be negative.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>a</code>
</td>
<td>Value of the integer variable <code>a</code>. Integer variables can be any lowercase letter [a-z].
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>1+2</code>
</td>
<td>Addition of two integer expressions.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>4-2</code>
</td>
<td>Substraction. Unary minus is allowed (<code>-x</code> means <code>0-x</code>).
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>2*2</code>
</td>
<td>Multiplication.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>2=2</code>
</td>
<td>Equality test. 1 if true, 0 if false.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>2&gt;1</code>
</td>
<td>Greater than test. 1 if true, 0 if false.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>2&lt;3</code>
</td>
<td>Less than test. 1 if true, 0 if false.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>#N</code>
</td>
<td>Number represented by string expression <code>N</code>. Causes an error if <code>N</code> does not make sense as a number.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&amp;N</code>
</td>
<td>Length of string <code>N</code>.
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="String">String</span></h3>
<table>
<tbody><tr>
<td><code>"Bar"</code>
</td>
<td>String literal. Valid escape sequences are <code>\"</code> for <code>"</code>, <code>\n</code> for new line and <code>\\</code> for <code>\</code>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>A</code>
</td>
<td>Value of the string variable <code>A</code>. String variables can be any uppercase letter [A-Z].
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>~</code>
</td>
<td>String received from user input.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>"X"+"Y"</code>
</td>
<td>Concatenation of two string expressions.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>$n</code>
</td>
<td>String representation of integer expression <code>n</code>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>%N,a,b</code>
</td>
<td>Substring of <code>N</code>, starting at character <code>a</code> included (first character is 0) up to <code>b</code> excluded. Errors if numbers are out of range or <code>a</code> &gt; <code>b</code>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>|N</code>
</td>
<td>Replaces all <code>"</code>, <code>\</code> and new lines in the string <code>N</code> by their respective escape sequences.
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>There exists an interpreter for the language <a href="/wiki/Bub" title="Bub">Bub</a> written in Muriel.  Since Bub is a small variant of <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">Brainfuck</a>, it ought to be possible to show through <a href="/wiki/Computational_class#Simulation" title="Computational class">simulation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Computational_class#Reduction" title="Computational class">reduction</a> that Muriel is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> as well.
Or by <a href="/wiki/Muriel/compile_from_minsky_machine" title="Muriel/compile from minsky machine">compiling Minsky machine program into Muriel</a>, it can also prove that Muriel is Turing complete.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_world.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_world!"><a href="/wiki/Hello,_world!" title="Hello, world!">Hello, world!</a></span></h3>
<pre>."Hello, world!"
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quine"><a href="/wiki/Quine" title="Quine">Quine</a></span></h3>
<pre>A:".\"A:\\\"\"+|A+\"\\\";\\n\"+A";
."A:\""+|A+"\";\n"+A
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infinite_loop"><a href="/wiki/Infinite_loop" title="Infinite loop">Infinite loop</a></span></h3>
<pre>A:"@\"A:\\\"\"+|A+\"\\\";\\n\"+A";
@"A:\""+|A+"\";\n"+A
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat_program"><a href="/wiki/Cat_program" title="Cat program">Cat program</a></span></h3>
<pre>S:"@\"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\nA:~;.A+%\\\"\\\\n\\\",0,&amp;A&gt;0;\\n\"+S";
A:~;.A+%"\n",0,&amp;A&gt;0;
@"S:\""+|S+"\";\nA:~;.A+%\"\\n\",0,&amp;A&gt;0;\n"+S
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fibonacci"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fibonacci" title="Fibonacci">Fibonacci</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">S:".$b+\"\\n\";\n@\"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\na:\"+$b+\";b:\"+$(a+b)+\";\\n\"+S";
a:0;b:1;
.$b+"\n";
@"S:\""+|S+"\";\na:"+$b+";b:"+$(a+b)+";\n"+S
</pre>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Unary">Unary</span></h4>
<pre class="rectwrap">S:"@\"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\nA:\\\"\"+B+\"\\\";\\nB:\\\"\"+A+B+\"\\\";\\n.B+\\\"\\\\n\\\";\\n\"+S";
A:"";
B:"1";
.B+"\n";
@"S:\""+|S+"\";\nA:\""+B+"\";\nB:\""+A+B+"\";\n.B+\"\\n\";\n"+S
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Truth_machine"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Truth_machine" title="Truth machine">Truth machine</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">S:"\"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\n.$1;\\nT:\"+S+\";\\n@T\"";
A:~;.A;
T:"S:\""+|S+"\";\n.$1;\nT:"+S+";\n@T";
@%T,0,&amp;T*(#A&gt;0);
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Looping_counter"><a href="/wiki/Looping_counter" title="Looping counter">Looping counter</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">S:"@\"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\nA:\\\"\"+A+\"*\"+\"\\\";.A+\\\"\\\\n\\\";\\n\"+S";
A:"*";.A+"\n";
@"S:\""+|S+"\";\nA:\""+A+"*"+"\";.A+\"\\n\";\n"+S
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Print_0_to_100">Print 0 to 100</span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">S:"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\na:\"+$(a+1)+\";.$a+\\\"\\\\n\\\";\\nF:\\\"\\\";\\nT:\\\"\"+S+\"\\\";\\n@(%T,0,&amp;T*(100&gt;a))+(%F,0,&amp;F*(100&gt;a=0))";
a:0;.$a+"\n";
F:"";
T:"S:\""+|S+"\";\na:"+$(a+1)+";.$a+\"\\n\";\nF:\"\";\nT:\""+S+"\";\n@(%T,0,&amp;T*(100&gt;a))+(%F,0,&amp;F*(100&gt;a=0))";
@(%T,0,&amp;T*(100&gt;a))+(%F,0,&amp;F*(100&gt;a=0))
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="FizzBuzz"><a href="/wiki/FizzBuzz" title="FizzBuzz">FizzBuzz</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">S:"\"S:\\\"\"+|S+\"\\\";\\ni:\"+$(i+(f=3))+\";a:\"+$((i*(f=0))+((a-(3*(a&gt;2)))*(f=1))+(a*((f=2)+(f=3))))+\";b:\"+$((i*(f=0))+((b-(5*(b&gt;4)))*(f=2))+(b*((f=1)+(f=3))))+\";f:\"+$((f=0)+((2-(a&gt;2))*(f=1))+((3-(b&gt;4))*(f=2)))+\";\\n.(%\\\"Fizz\\\",0,4*(f=3)*(a=0))+(%\\\"Buzz\\\",0,4*(f=3)*(b=0))+(%$i,0,#$i*(f=3)*(a=0=0)*(b=0=0))+(%\\\"\\\\n\\\",0,(f=3));\\nT:\"+S+\";\\n@%T,0,(&amp;T*(101&gt;i))\"";
i:1;a:1;b:1;f:0;
.(%"Fizz",0,4*(f=3)*(a=0))+(%"Buzz",0,4*(f=3)*(b=0))+(%$i,0,#$i*(f=3)*(a=0=0)*(b=0=0))+(%"\n",0,(f=3));
T:"S:\""+|S+"\";\ni:"+$(i+(f=3))+";a:"+$((i*(f=0))+((a-(3*(a&gt;2)))*(f=1))+(a*((f=2)+(f=3))))+";b:"+$((i*(f=0))+((b-(5*(b&gt;4)))*(f=2))+(b*((f=1)+(f=3))))+";f:"+$((f=0)+((2-(a&gt;2))*(f=1))+((3-(b&gt;4))*(f=2)))+";\n.(%\"Fizz\",0,4*(f=3)*(a=0))+(%\"Buzz\",0,4*(f=3)*(b=0))+(%$i,0,#$i*(f=3)*(a=0=0)*(b=0=0))+(%\"\\n\",0,(f=3));\nT:"+S+";\n@%T,0,(&amp;T*(101&gt;i))";
@%T,0,(&amp;T*(101&gt;i))
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="99_bottles_of_beer"><a href="/wiki/99_bottles_of_beer" title="99 bottles of beer">99 bottles of beer</a></span></h3>
<p>This program has been modified to fix an error from the one showed on the original page, which did not work in Chris Pressey's interpreter due to precedence issues.
</p>
<pre class="rectwrap">b:99;
A:$b+" bottle"+(%"s",0,1-(b=1))+" of beer";
.A+" on the wall,\n"+A+",\nTake one down, pass it around,\n";
b:b-1;
.$b+" bottle"+(%"s",0,1-(b=1))+" of beer on the wall.\n\n";
Q:";\nA:$b+\" bottle\"+(%\"s\",0,1-(b=1))+\" of beer\";\n.A+\" on the wall,\\n\"+A+\",\\nTake one down, pass it around,\\n\";\nb:b-1;\n.$b+\" bottle\"+(%\"s\",0,1-(b=1))+\" of beer on the wall.\\n\\n\";\nQ:\"";
R:"\";\nZ:\"b:\"+$b+Q+|Q+\"\\\";\\nR:\\\"\"+|R+R;\n@%Z,0,((b&gt;0)*&amp;Z)";
Z:"b:"+$b+Q+|Q+"\";\nR:\""+|R+R;
@%Z,0,((b&gt;0)*&amp;Z)
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bub_interpreter"><a href="/wiki/Bub" title="Bub">Bub</a> interpreter</span></h3>
<p>The Bub program is encoded in P, which is split into blocks with w characters. The last digit of each block is <code>012345678</code> translated from <code>&lt;&gt;+-,.[](end of program)</code> respectively, while the other digits are only used in the loop brackets as a predetermined 0-based index of the instruction to jump to.
</p><p>Note that you have to give input as three digit decimal numbers since standard Muriel has no way of converting characters to their ASCII codes or checking string equality.
</p><p>The program is currently set up to print "Hello World!" followed by a newline.
</p>
<pre class="rectwrap">P:"";
M:"0  ";
c:0;
I:" ";
d:0;
A:"??????????\n??\n?????????????????? !\"#$%&amp;'()*+,-./0123456789:;&lt;=&gt;?@ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[\\]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~";
w:4;

N:(%P,c*w,(c*w)+w);S:(%N,w-1,w);
Q:"P:\""+|P+"\";\nM:\""+M+"\";\nc:"+$c+";\nI:\""+|I+"\";\nd:"+$d+";\nA:\""+|A+"\";\nw:"+$w+";\nc:c+1;\nl:#(%M,d,d+3);\n";
G:"d:d-3;";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=0));
G:"d:d+3;M:M+(%\"0  \",0,(d=&amp;M)*3);";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=1));
G:";F:(%($(l+1)+\"   \"),0,3);M:(%M,0,d)+F+(%M,d+3,&amp;M);";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=2));
G:"F:(%($(l-1)+\"   \"),0,3);M:(%M,0,d)+F+(%M,d+3,&amp;M);";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=3));
H:"I:~;";
G:(%H,0,&amp;H*(&amp;I=0))+"M:(%M,0,d)+(%I,0,3)+(%M,d+3,&amp;M);I:(%I,3,&amp;I);";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=4));
G:".(%A,l,l+1);";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=5));
j:#(%N,0,w-1);
G:"c:(c*(1-(l=0)))+("+$j+"*(l=0));";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=6));
G:"c:(c*(l=0))+("+$j+"*(1-(l=0)));";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=7));
G:"@\" \"";
Q:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=8));
R:"N:(%P,c*w,(c*w)+w);\nS:(%N,w-1,w);\nQ:\"P:\\\"\"+|P+\"\\\";\\nM:\\\"\"+M+\"\\\";\\nc:\"+$c+\";\\nI:\\\"\"+|I+\"\\\";\\nd:\"+$d+\";\\nA:\\\"\"+|A+\"\\\";\\nw:\"+$w+\";\\nc:c+1;\\nl:#(%M,d,d+3);\\n\";\nG:\"d:d-3;\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=0));\nG:\"d:d+3;M:M+(%\\\"0  \\\",0,(d=&amp;M)*3);\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=1));\nG:\"F:(%($(l+1)+\\\"   \\\"),0,3);M:(%M,0,d)+F+(%M,d+3,&amp;M);\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=2));\nG:\"F:(%($(l-1)+\\\"   \\\"),0,3);M:(%M,0,d)+F+(%M,d+3,&amp;M);\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=3));\nH:\"I:~;\";\nG:(%H,0,&amp;H*(&amp;I=0))+\"M:(%M,0,d)+(%I,0,3)+(%M,d+3,&amp;M);I:(%I,3,&amp;I);\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=4));\nG:\".(%A,l,l+1);\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=5));\nj:#(%N,0,w-1);\nG:\"c:(c*(1-(l=0)))+(\"+$j+\"*(l=0));\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=6));\nG:\"c:(c*(l=0))+(\"+$j+\"*(1-(l=0)));\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=7));\nG:\"@\\\" \\\"\";\nQ:Q+(%G,0,&amp;G*(#S=8));\nR:\"";
Z:"\";\nX:Q+R+|R+\"\\\";Z:\\\"\"+|Z+Z;\n@X";
X:Q+R+|R+"\";Z:\""+|Z+Z;
@X
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Smurf" title="Smurf">Smurf</a> is an attempt to make a <a href="/wiki/Turing_tarpit" title="Turing tarpit">Turing tarpit</a> out of Muriel.</li></ul>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Natyre</b> is a minimal, <a href="/wiki/OISC" title="OISC">one-instruction</a> esolanguage by <a href="/wiki/User:Keymaker" title="User:Keymaker">User:Keymaker</a>. It is the author's attempt to simplify <a href="/wiki/Minsky_machine" title="Minsky machine">Minsky machines</a> further. The language was invented in 2016 but published in <a href="/wiki/Category:2017" title="Category:2017">2017</a>. The language is an <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Infinitely_Branching_Counter_Machine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Infinitely Branching Counter Machine (page does not exist)">Infinitely Branching Counter Machine</a>, a term coined by the author to describe the fundamental difference between this type of new counter machine and the other kind. The main difference here is that Natyre 1.) has an infinite amount of branching conditions whereas ordinary counter machines mostly have only one (such as Minsky Machine's DEC instruction) <i>and</i> 2.) has only one kind of instruction.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Program_and_execution">Program and execution</span></h2>
<p>A program consists of instructions (at least one required), and there is only one type of instruction.
</p>
<pre>&lt;identifier&gt; &lt;counter&gt; &lt;branch1&gt; &lt;branch2&gt;
</pre>
<p>A description of an instruction consist of a unique identifier, a counter, and two branches (which are identifiers, which of course also must exist in the program).
</p><p>Program execution begins in the first defined instruction. All counters are unbounded and initially 0. The system never halts.
</p><p>An instruction is executed thus: The counter is increased by one. If the counter's new value is an event-number (see below), execution transfers to branch 2. Otherwise, which is a far more common case, execution transfers to branch 1.
</p><p>Event-numbers (called such because they cause the other, rarer branching to happen) are numbers that appear according to a simple rule. There is an infinite supply of them, and each is larger than the previous. The first ten event-numbers are 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21, 28, 36, 45, and 55. Event-numbers can be generated easily: have integers q and n, both initially 0. Increase n by one, add n to q. Now q is the first event-number. Repeat (n=n+1, q=q+n). This sequnce can be found in OEIS: <a class="external autonumber" href="http://oeis.org/A000217" rel="nofollow">[1]</a>.
</p><p>An example program:
</p>
<pre>1 A 1 2
2 B 1 1
</pre>
<p>At 1, counter A is increased. If it becomes event-number, execution moves to 2. Otherwise, execution moves to 1 (stays in the same instruction, in other words). If execution moved to 2, there counter B is increased. Execution moves to 1 whether B became event-number or not (because both branches point to instruction 1).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computatinal_class">Computatinal class</span></h2>
<p>The language is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>. A proof via Minsky Machine translation is offered on the page (see link below).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="http://yiap.nfshost.com/esoteric/natyre/natyre.html" rel="nofollow">Natyre page</a> (thorough explanation of the language and MM translation, MM-to-Natyre translator, interpreter in Python)</li></ul>

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Needle</b> is an esolang by <a href="/wiki/User:ChuckEsoteric08" title="User:ChuckEsoteric08">User:ChuckEsoteric08</a> in 2025.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Description"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Description</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Notation"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Notation</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Infinite_Minsky_machine"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Infinite Minsky machine</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#From_IMM_to_Needle"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">From IMM to Needle</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Example"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Example</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Description">Description</span></h2>
<p>The language uses wrapping tape of 3 cells and program inside an infinite loop
</p>
<ul><li><code>_</code> - decrements current cell and moves right. Decrementing zero does nothing.</li>
<li><code>(...)</code> - increment current cell and if result is 1 then run code inside the brackets. Can be nested.</li></ul>
<p>There are optional IO commands:
</p>
<ul><li><code>;</code> - input into a current cell. Can be either number or ASCII character depending on the implementation</li>
<li><code>*</code> - output cell as either number or ASCII character depending on implementation</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p><b>Needle</b> is Turing-complete since Minsky machine can be compiled into it. For the simplicity I will use a subset called <b>Infinite Minsky machine</b> (IMM).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Notation">Notation</span></h3>
<p>Here I will use a specific notation where <code>[x;y]</code> executes code <code>x</code> <code>y</code> times. I will also define following commands:
</p>
<pre>NEXT = ()_
DEC = _ NEXT NEXT
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infinite_Minsky_machine">Infinite Minsky machine</span></h3>
<p>Language has 2 registers: A and B. Program's are, like in Needle, inside an infinite loop.
</p>
<pre>INC x y
</pre>
<p>Increment <code>x</code> and move <code>y</code> commands forward.
</p>
<pre>DEC x y
</pre>
<p>Decrement <code>x</code> (if 0 do nothing) and move <code>y</code> commands forward.
</p>
<pre>IF x y
</pre>
<p>If <code>x</code> is 0 move <code>y</code> commands forward, else execute next one.
</p>
<pre>JMP x
</pre>
<p>Jumps <code>x</code> commands forward. Halting the program can be simulated by replacing <code>x</code> with the length of a program
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="From_IMM_to_Needle">From IMM to Needle</span></h3>
<p><code>INC A y</code> becomes: 
</p>
<pre>DEC ( NEXT () NEXT NEXT [();y] ) DEC 
</pre>
<p>Becoming:
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()_()()_()_[();y])_()_()_ 
</pre>
<p><code>INC B y</code> becomes: 
</p>
<pre>DEC ( NEXT NEXT () NEXT [();y] ) DEC 
</pre>
<p>Becoming: 
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()_()_()()_[();y])_()_()_ 
</pre>
<p><code>DEC A y</code> becomes: 
</p>
<pre>DEC ( NEXT _ NEXT [();y] ) DEC 
</pre>
<p>Becoming: 
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()__()_[();y])_()_()_ 
</pre>
<p><code>DEC B y</code> becomes: 
</p>
<pre>DEC ( NEXT NEXT _ [();y] ) DEC 
</pre>
<p>Becoming: 
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()_()__[();y])_()_()_ 
</pre>
<p><code>IF A y</code> becomes: 
</p>
<pre>DEC ( () NEXT ( NEXT NEXT [();y-1] NEXT ) _ NEXT ) DEC
</pre>
<p>Becoming: 
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()()_(()_()_[();y-1]()_)_()_)_()_()_ 
</pre>
<p><code>IF B y</code> becomes: 
</p>
<pre>DEC ( () NEXT NEXT ( NEXT [();y-1] NEXT NEXT ) _ ) DEC 
</pre>
<p>Becoming: 
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()()_()_(()_[();y-1]()_()_ )_)_()_()_
</pre>
<p><code>JMP x</code> becomes:
</p>
<pre>DEC ( [();x] ) DEC
</pre>
<p>Becoming:
</p>
<pre>_()_()_([();x])_()_()_
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Example">Example</span></h3>
<p>Set Register A to 4 and then decrease it to zero, after which increment register B and halt the program:
</p>
<pre>INC A 1
INC A 1
INC A 1
INC A 1
IF A 2
DEC A 6
INC B 1
JMP 8
</pre>
<p>Becomes:
</p>
<pre>_()_()_(()_()()_()_())_()_()_
_()_()_(()_()()_()_())_()_()_
_()_()_(()_()()_()_())_()_()_
_()_()_(()_()()_()_())_()_()_
_()_()_(()()_(()_()_()()_)_()_)_()_()_
_()_()_(()__()_()()()()()())_()_()_
_()_()_(()_()_()()_())_()_()_
_()_()_(()()()()()()()())_()_()_    
</pre>
<!--

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Nine</b> (<b>N</b>ext L<b>ine</b>) is an esoteric programming language, created by <a href="/wiki/User:CMinusMinus" title="User:CMinusMinus">User:CMinusMinus</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Hello,_World!"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Hello, World!</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#FizzBuzz"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">FizzBuzz</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#cat"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">cat</span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Instructions">Instructions</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable sortable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Instruction</th>
<th>Action
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>#VAR.VAL</td>
<td>VAR = VAL ("_" is replaced with a space)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>#VAR+&lt;value&gt;</td>
<td>VAR += &lt;value&gt;
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>#VAR-&lt;value&gt;</td>
<td>VAR -= &lt;value&gt;
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>#VAR.*</td>
<td>VAR = user-input
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>$VAR$</td>
<td>Call a variable
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&gt;TEXT</td>
<td>Print Text
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&gt;TEXT*</td>
<td>Print Text without \n
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&gt;$VAR$</td>
<td>Print Variable
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>&gt;$VAR$*</td>
<td>Print Variable without \n
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>!</td>
<td>One line down
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>end</td>
<td>End program
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>(A|B)</td>
<td>if A = B, one line down
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>(A%B)</td>
<td>if A % B = 0, one line down
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>;</td>
<td>Begin of a comment, have to be at the start of a line
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>~INSTRUCTION</td>
<td>Run a command once (Then ignored in main-loop)
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>A program is running infinitely, until the "end" command.
With this, you are able to easily run a while loop.
</p><p>Every instruction got no spaces, so its possible to write those next to each other, separated with a space, for example:
</p>
<pre>&gt;Hello,_World!
end
</pre>
<p>becomes
</p>
<pre>&gt;Hello,_World! end
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_World.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_World!"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hello,_World!" title="Hello, World!">Hello, World!</a></span></h3>
<pre>&gt;Hello,_World! end
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="FizzBuzz"><a href="/wiki/FizzBuzz" title="FizzBuzz">FizzBuzz</a></span></h3>
<pre>~#num.1 #num+1 &gt;$num$
($num$%3) &gt;Fizz
($num$%5) &gt;Buzz
($num$%15) &gt;FizzBuzz
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="cat"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cat" title="Cat">cat</a></span></h3>
<pre>#i.*
&gt;$i$
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fibonacci_numbers"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fibonacci_numbers" title="Fibonacci numbers">Fibonacci numbers</a></span></h3>
<pre>~#a.0 ~#b.1
&gt;$b$
#c.$a$ #a.$b$ #b+$c$
</pre>
<h3><span id="Swapping_the_Words_.22Good.22_and_.22Bad.22"></span><span class="mw-headline" id='Swapping_the_Words_"Good"_and_"Bad"'><a class="external text" href="https://codegolf.stackexchange.com/questions/187816/swapping-good-and-bad" rel="nofollow">Swapping the Words "Good" and "Bad"</a></span></h3>
<pre>#word.*
($word$|Bad) &gt;Good end
&gt;Bad end
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/SanoHD/Nine" rel="nofollow">GitHub repository</a></li></ul>
