<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>Pxem used to be published in author's own website before, which does not exist anymore. According to their new blog<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blog_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-Blog-2">[2]</a></sup>, they used to compete in coding-golf held on <a class="external text" href="http://golf.shinh.org/" rel="nofollow">anarchy golf</a> using Perl, PHP, and <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a>. One day, shinh, the host of the site, introduced <a href="/wiki/GolfScript" title="GolfScript">GolfScript</a>, which is designed for coding-golf. In some courses, the script enables you to code with only one-byte files. This inspired them to design a new language for coding-golf working with zero-byte files.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Specifications">Specifications</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Virtual_machine">Virtual machine</span></h3>
<p>Pxem interpreter works with a virtual machine with a stack ― stores values as integer type ―, a buffer ― stores a string for stacking into the stack ―, a temporary memory ― stores only a value at the same time, as integer type. The stack and the temporary memory will be initialized with no values.
</p><p>According to original interpreter, it is distinguished whether temporary memory has been used or not.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="File_name_and_contents">File name and contents</span></h3>
<p>Pxem interpreter recognizes file name mainly as a source code of program. Contents of file, on the other hand, will be ignored unless file name includes either <code>.e</code> or <code>.f</code>, which is described in <a href="#Instructions">further sections</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="How_the_code_gets_read">How the code gets read</span></h3>
<p>At first content of file name will be read from beginning to end. When it reaches to <code>.d</code> or end, the program terminates. When it reaches to <code>.e</code>, the interpreter begins to read content of file as the new process, which will be interpreted as part of Pxem code, from beginning to end. When it reaches to <code>.d</code> or end of file, the process ends, then original process gets continued. Vice versa when it reaches to <code>.e</code> inside file.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Instructions">Instructions</span></h3>
<p>Each command is a <code>.</code> (dot), and a case-insensitive ASCII character. Before the pointer reaches to the command, the character currently read will be added to the buffer as a character code. When the pointer reaches to the command, the content in the buffer gets pushed into the stack before the command gets operated.
</p><p>For example, the file <code>abcd.stuv.pxe</code> can be separated into 5 parts: <code>abcd</code>, <code>.s</code>, <code>tuv</code>, <code>.p</code>, and <code>xe</code>. Before reaching to the first instruction <code>.s</code>, the four characters d, c, b, and a get stacked in those order, which d is in bottom while a is in top. Then, by <code>.s</code> instruction, the top value 'a' gets popped. Later, the three characters v, u, and t get stacked in that order. By <code>.p</code>, the stack will be empty, because each content gets outputted as an ASCII character. Finally, two characters get pushed in following order then the program terminates: e, and x.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Output">Output</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.p</code></td>
<td>Pops and outputs as a character, then repeats until the stack gets empty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-empty_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-empty-4">[ins 1]</a></sup>
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello world.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>hello world</code> (without newline at end)</dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.o</code></td>
<td>Pops once and outputs as a character.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-empty_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-empty-4">[ins 1]</a></sup>
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello world.o.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>h</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.n</code></td>
<td>Pops once and outputs as an integer value.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-empty_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-empty-4">[ins 1]</a></sup>
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello world.n.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>104</code> (<code>h</code> values 104 in ASCII)</dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Input">Input</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.i</code></td>
<td>User inputs a character of a byte to stack. EOF values -1.
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello.iworld.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Input example</dt>
<dd><code>3</code></dd>
<dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>world3hello</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>._</code></td>
<td>User inputs a signed integer to stack.
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello._world.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Input example</dt>
<dd><code>95</code> (values <code>_</code> in ASCII)</dd>
<dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>world_hello</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Operating_stack">Operating stack</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.c</code></td>
<td><b>Duplicate</b>: Pops once, then pushes the popped item twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-empty_4-3"><a href="#cite_note-empty-4">[ins 1]</a></sup>
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello world.c.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>hhello world</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.s</code></td>
<td><b>Drop</b>: Pops once and discards the item.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-empty_4-4"><a href="#cite_note-empty-4">[ins 1]</a></sup>
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello world.s.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>ello world</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.v</code></td>
<td>Reverses content of the stack.
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>hello world.v.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>dlrow olleh</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Operating_content_of_file">Operating content of file</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.f</code></td>
<td>Stacks content of file as a string. This command never erases content of file.
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd><code>world.f.pxe</code></dd>
<dt>Content of file</dt>
<dd><code>hello,</code></dd>
<dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>hello,world</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.e</code></td>
<td><b>Execution</b>: Recognizes content of file as a part of Pxem code and begins new process there, making a new stack memory(items in original stack will be copied) and a temporary register (empty)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blog_2-2"><a href="#cite_note-Blog-2">[2]</a></sup>. After the process ends,
<ul><li>Content of the stack will be stacked to original one.</li>
<li>Content of the temporary register will be lost<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[ins 2]</a></sup>.</li></ul>
<p>You may run this command as many times as you'd like.
</p>
<dl><dt>Example 1</dt>
<dd><code>hello.e.world.pxe</code> <i>(content is none)</i>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>worldhellohello</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<dl><dt>Example 2</dt>
<dd>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd><code>hello.e.world.pxe</code></dd>
<dt>Content</dt>
<dd><code>.v.c</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>worldllehhello</code></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Random_value">Random value</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.r</code></td>
<td>Pops an item x, then pushes a signed random integer between 0 and (x-1). For example, if x were 10, one of 0-9 would be generated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-empty_4-5"><a href="#cite_note-empty-4">[ins 1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[ins 3]</a></sup>
<dl><dt>Example</dt>
<dd><code>0.r.n.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd>One of 0-47 (character <code>0</code> values 48 in ASCII)</dd></dl></dd></dl>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Conditional_looping">Conditional looping</span></h4>
<p>All of the following instructions may be nested.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.w</code></td>
<td><b>Loop while not zero</b>: Pops top value and tests if it is 0 or not<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[ins 4]</a></sup>. If it's zero, skip to the matching <code>.a</code> instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cond_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-cond-8">[ins 5]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.x</code></td>
<td><b>Loop while less</b>: Pops two top values. If firstly popped value is equal or greater than secondly popped one<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[ins 6]</a></sup>, skip to the matching <code>.a</code> instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cond_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-cond-8">[ins 5]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.y</code></td>
<td><b>Loop while greater</b>: Pops two top values. If firstly popped value is equal or less than secondly popped one<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[ins 7]</a></sup>, skip to the matching <code>.a</code> instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cond_8-2"><a href="#cite_note-cond-8">[ins 5]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.z</code></td>
<td><b>Loop while not equal</b>: Pops two top values. If they are equal, skip to the matching <code>.a</code> instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cond_8-3"><a href="#cite_note-cond-8">[ins 5]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.a</code></td>
<td><b>End of loop</b>: Jumps back to corresponding one of four above. If there are not, the program results in an error<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blog_2-3"><a href="#cite_note-Blog-2">[2]</a></sup>.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<dl><dt>Note</dt>
<dd>Five commands above can be nested.</dd>
<dt>Example 1</dt>
<dd><code>Hello, world.w.pxe</code></dd>
<dd><code>Hello, world.a.pxe</code>
<dl><dd>Both two above results in an error during running. Former one is because of reaching to no <code>.a</code>'s while other is because of reaching <code>.a</code> before four others.</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<dl><dt>Example 2</dt>
<dd><code>abcdeffggghijj.z.a.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>hijj</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<dl><dt>Example 3</dt>
<dd><code>abcdeffggghijj.x.a.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>hijj</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<dl><dt>Example 4</dt>
<dd><code>abcdeffggghijj.y.a.pxe</code>
<dl><dt>Output</dt>
<dd><code>cdeffggghijj</code></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<dl><dt>Example 5</dt>
<dd><code>a.w.a.pxe</code>
<dl><dd>This program will never terminate, for causing an infinite loop.</dd></dl></dd></dl>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Temporary_memory">Temporary memory</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.t</code></td>
<td>Pops top value. The value gets stored in temporary register.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[ins 8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[ins 9]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.m</code></td>
<td>Pushes content in temporary register.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[ins 10]</a></sup> If the register is empty, nothing happens.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Termination">Termination</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.d</code></td>
<td><b>Return</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[ins 11]</a></sup>. This instruction works differently on either file name or content.
<dl><dt>In file name</dt>
<dd>The program gets terminated.</dd>
<dt>In content of file</dt>
<dd>The subprocess gets terminated, then content of stack gets stacked to parent one, and the temporary register gets destroyed.</dd></dl>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Arithmetic_operation">Arithmetic operation</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.+</code></td>
<td><b>Addition operation</b>: Pops two top values, then pushes sum of them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-op_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-op-15">[ins 12]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.-</code></td>
<td><b>Subtraction operation</b>: Pops two top values, then substrates smaller one from larger one. Pushes the result.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-op_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-op-15">[ins 12]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.!</code></td>
<td><b>Multiplication operation</b>: Pops two top values, then pushes their product.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-op_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-op-15">[ins 12]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.$</code></td>
<td><b>Division operation</b>: Pops two top values, then divides larger one by smaller one. Pushes the quotient.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-op_15-3"><a href="#cite_note-op-15">[ins 12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-div_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-div-16">[ins 13]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.%</code></td>
<td><b>Modulo operation</b>: Pops two top values, then divides larger one by smaller one. Pushes the remainder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-op_15-4"><a href="#cite_note-op-15">[ins 12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-div_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-div-16">[ins 13]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-empty-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">↑ <sup><a href="#cite_ref-empty_4-0">1.0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-empty_4-1">1.1</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-empty_4-2">1.2</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-empty_4-3">1.3</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-empty_4-4">1.4</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-empty_4-5">1.5</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">If stack is empty, nothing happens</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-5">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">This is not officially documented, but pxem.h of pxemi.7z satisfies this specification.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-6">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">It was not originally specified what would happen if top value were either 0 or -1 on <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120605223423/http://cfs.maxn.jp/neta/pxem.php" rel="nofollow">original description page</a>, but according to pxem.h of pxemi.7z, the original interpreter, it is implemented in following function:
<pre class="rectwrap">inline void Pxem::getRand(){
	int aaa = rand() % pStack.top();
	pStack.pop();
	pStack.push(aaa);
}
</pre>
<p>Therefore the program would result in an error by dividing by 0.
</p>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-7">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">It won't test if stack is empty.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-cond-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">↑ <sup><a href="#cite_ref-cond_8-0">5.0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-cond_8-1">5.1</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-cond_8-2">5.2</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-cond_8-3">5.3</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">It was not specified on original description page, but according to <a class="external text" href="https://vivibit.net/remember_pxem/" rel="nofollow">revival blog page</a>, the author clarified what would happen the number of values in the stack were not enough: nothing would happen to content of the stack. However, it was not clarified whether the program loops or not. But according to the original interpreter pxem.h of pxemi.7z, the program will loop.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-9">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Original description said: <i>if first-popped item is NOT smaller than the other</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-10">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Original description said: <i>if first-popped item is NOT greater than the other</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-11">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Old content in the register will be lost.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-12">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">It is not clarified what would happen if the stack were empty.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-13">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">The content of the register will not be lost.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-14">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Original description just says to stop execution.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-op-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">↑ <sup><a href="#cite_ref-op_15-0">12.0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-op_15-1">12.1</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-op_15-2">12.2</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-op_15-3">12.3</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-op_15-4">12.4</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">If the stack has less than two values, nothing happens.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-div-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">↑ <sup><a href="#cite_ref-div_16-0">13.0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-div_16-1">13.1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">The program would result in an error if top value were 0, according to pxem.h of pxemi.7z, the original interpreter.</span>
</li>
</ol></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_world.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_world!"><a href="/wiki/Hello,_world!" title="Hello, world!">Hello, world!</a></span></h3>
<p>To output <i>Hello, world!</i>, the filename should be:
</p>
<pre>Hello, world!.pxe
</pre>
<p>while the contents of file is arbitrary.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_example">Other example</span></h4>
<p>This alternative example is efficient if you prefer not to use symbols other than period and hyphen. This program outputs a newline, too.
</p>
<pre>Hello.pAa.-Am.-.pworld.pak.-Ab.-.pxe
</pre>
<h3><span id="Echo_.28or_cat_program_in_exact.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Echo_(or_cat_program_in_exact)">Echo (or <a href="/wiki/Cat_program" title="Cat program">cat program</a> in exact)</span></h3>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd><pre>1.w.o.i.c12.-.+.a.s.pxe</pre></dd>
<dt>File Contents</dt>
<dd><i>(none)</i></dd></dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ultimate_problem">Ultimate problem</span></h3>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd><pre>42.pxe</pre></dd>
<dt>File Contents</dt>
<dd><i>(none)</i></dd></dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="delete_last_line">delete last line</span></h3>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd>1.w.i.c12.-.+.a1.zak.-.a.v.pxe</dd>
<dt>File Contents</dt>
<dd><i>(none)</i></dd></dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="FizzBuzz"><a href="/wiki/FizzBuzz" title="FizzBuzz">FizzBuzz</a></span></h3>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd><pre>ak.-akbuzz.-ak4.-akfizz.-ak2.-1.p05.-.tab.z01.-.c.m.+.c.t05.-.%.w.s01.-.m03.-.%.W.s.m.nak.-.p00.-.c.c.c.a.wak.-fizz.p00.-.c.c.a.a.w01.-.m03.-.%.w.sak.-buzz.p00.-.c.c.a.wak.-fizzbuzz.p00.-.c.a.a.md2.-02.-.!.a.d.pxe</pre></dd>
<dt>File Contents</dt>
<dd><i>(none)</i></dd></dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prints_10_one-digit_random_numbers">Prints 10 one-digit random numbers</span></h3>
<dl><dt>Filename</dt>
<dd><pre>ak.-.z.tak.-.c.r.n.p.m01.-.-.c00.-.a.pxe</pre></dd></dl>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="By_original_designer">By original designer</span></h3>
<h4><span id="pxemi.exe_.28original.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="pxemi.exe_(original)">pxemi.exe (original)</span></h4>
<p>Original author used to publish its interpreter named "<b>pxemi.exe</b>", which was developed in C++ and would work on Windows only.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Lost_code_generator">Lost code generator</span></h4>
<p>On original page there used to be a code generator, which seems to be lost.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="pxemi.7z">pxemi.7z</span></h4>
<p>After ten years, its original interpreter got published again on original author's blog<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blog_2-4"><a href="#cite_note-Blog-2">[2]</a></sup>. In this page the interpreter is distributed as <b>pxemi.7z</b>, zipping two files <b>pxem.h</b> and <b>pxemInterpreter.cpp</b>.
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Bug">Bug</span></h5>
<p>As on January 1st, 2020, the header file <b>pxem.h</b> has a following bug:
</p>
<ul><li><code>inline void Pxem::copy()</code> — a method for command <code>.c</code> — is missing the procedure for an empty stack; the specification supposes the command works like an NOP in the case, but the actual implementation is missing the part.</li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="text2pxem.pl">text2pxem.pl</span></h4>
<p>There's also a simple supportive kit <b>text2pxem.pl</b>. It compiles a text file into Pxem code file and emulates with text file. The usage is:
</p>
<ol><li>Put pxemi.exe<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[4]</a></sup> and text2pxem.pl in the same directory.</li>
<li>Make a text file with any name (name does not matter).</li>
<li>Write filename first. You can separate into lines. You put any horizontal tab characters at the beginning of a line, they are ignored. You put a tab in the end, you can write a comment followed by the character.</li>
<li>If you'd like to write content of the file, you have to put <b>one line of</b> <code>__EOF__</code> to imply the end of filename. Then following contents are recognized as contents.</li>
<li>Run text2pxem.pl with following arguments:
<ul><li>1st argument must be filename for text file you made. With no 2nd argument, it compiles into Pxem file.</li>
<li>You specify 2nd argument <code>-e</code>, it does not only compile, but also execute with the file.</li></ul></li></ol>
<dl><dt>Usage example</dt>
<dd>
<dl><dt>Your file</dt>
<dd></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<pre class="rectwrap">n4-).-	mk ':-)'
ak.-	mk '\n'
n4-.-	mk ':-'
ak.-	mk '\n'
n4.-.p	mk ':'
01.-.t	mk 0 and toreg
.z	loop A
	n4-).-	mk ':-)'
	ak.-	mk '\n'
	.p	print
	.m	fromreg
	.e	exec file
	.v.s.v	delete flag
	.p	print
	.m	fromreg
	12.-.+	mk 1 and add
	.t	toreg
	 .m	
.a	end loop A
.d.pxe
__EOF__
.t	toreg
.z	loop B
	01)).-.m.-.t
	00.-.m
.a	end loop B
</pre>
<p>This file<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blog_2-5"><a href="#cite_note-Blog-2">[2]</a></sup>, for example, generates a file named <code>n4-).-ak.-n4-.-ak.-n4.-.p01.-.t.zn4-).-ak.-.p.m.e.v.s.v.p.m12.-.+.t .m.a.d.pxe</code>, with content <code>.t.z01)).-.m.-.t00.-.m.a</code>.
</p>
<dl><dd><dl><dt>Using the tool</dt>
<dd><code>txt2pxem.pl filename</code>
<dl><dd>Just a compilation.</dd></dl></dd>
<dd><code>txt2pxem.pl filename -e</code>
<dl><dd>Not only compilation, but also execution.</dd>
<dd>You must put an <code>-e</code> exactly on the second argument.</dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<p>By the way you have to replace every <code>\r\n</code> into <code>\n</code> if you're running text2pxem.pl on non-Windows environments.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Others">Others</span></h3>
<p>As on September 2018, there are three repositories for interpreter-development, which are on <a href="#External_Links">#External Links</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Turing-completeness">Turing-completeness</span></h2>
<p>"nk." originally predicted Pxem is not Turing-complete because Pxem has no built-in command for "swap" operation of the stack<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blog_2-6"><a href="#cite_note-Blog-2">[2]</a></sup>.
</p><p>In May 2020, several proofs of Turing-completeness of Pxem gets published on a personal blog <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[5]</a></sup>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_Links">External Links</span></h2>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120605223423/http://cfs.maxn.jp/neta/pxem.php" rel="nofollow">Original description page (Japanese)</a> <i>(from the <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="wikipedia:Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>; retrieved on 5 June 2012)</i></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://vivibit.net/remember_pxem/" rel="nofollow">The blog by original author</a> (Japanese) ― <b>Original interpreter source (and supportive tools) available!</b> (Stated to be licensed under WTFPL)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.nicovideo.jp/watch/sm5808782" rel="nofollow">Pxemでネギを振ってみた - NicoNico Video</a> ― The only video to try running Pxem.(Japanese)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/wktk/rpxem" rel="nofollow">wktk/rpxem</a> ― The interpreter developed in Ruby. Some commands (<code>.d</code> and some) doesn't work properly.
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://wktk.jp/tags/pxem/" rel="nofollow">wktk's blog</a> ― Two programs are shown. One is to output whether the number is prime number or not and the other one is to calculate the factorial.</li></ul></li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/rhwckl/pxem" rel="nofollow">rhwckl/pxem</a> ― The compiler-time interpreter developed in C++. Two libraries:Boost and Sprout are necessary in order to compiler. The syntax is modified.</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://github.com/GH-TpaeFawzen/Pxem2Cplusplus11" rel="nofollow">GH-TpaeFawzen/Pxem2Cplusplus11</a> — Implemented in Bourne shell. Translates into C++11 program.</li></ul>

</li>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p>Python is Magic is a very restricted version of Python 3. On Python is Magic, only magic functions can be used.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Warm-up"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Warm-up</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Programming_in_Python_is_Magic"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Programming in Python is Magic</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Constants"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Constants</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Variables"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Variables</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Example_codes"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Example codes</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Hello,_world!"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">Hello, world!</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#Implementation"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Implementation</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warm-up">Warm-up</span></h2>
<p>This is a valid Python is Magic code:
</p>
<pre>__name__.__class__.__name__.__len__().__sub__(__name__.__class__.__name__.__len__())
</pre>
<p>That's good, but not pretty. To prettify it, you can remove the underscores:
</p>
<pre>name.class.name.len().sub(name.class.name.len())
</pre>
<p>It will result in the same code as above.
</p><p>Literals, normal if-else, declaring classes normally, anything that is not magic functions are not allowed in Python is Magic. Other than that, it's just an unmodified Python 3.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Programming_in_Python_is_Magic">Programming in Python is Magic</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constants">Constants</span></h3>
<p>Here are some example constants of Python is Magic. A more complete list of constants can be found at <a href="/wiki/Python_is_Magic/Constants" title="Python is Magic/Constants">Python is Magic/Constants</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Constant</th>
<th>Code
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>False</code></td>
<td><code>__doc__.__bool__()</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>True</code></td>
<td><code>__doc__.__eq__(__doc__)</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>1</code></td>
<td><code>__doc__.__eq__(__doc__).__int__()</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>7</code></td>
<td><code>__doc__.__dir__.__name__.__len__()</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>a</code></td>
<td><code>__name__.__getitem__(__name__.__class__.__name__.__len__())</code> or <code>__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__getitem__(__name__.__len__().__bool__())</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>()</code></td>
<td><code>__name__.__getnewargs__().__class__()</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[]</code></td>
<td><code>__doc__.__dir__().__class__()</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Variables">Variables</span></h3>
<p>You can use <code>__builtins__.__setattr__</code> to store data. For example, this sets <code>__x__</code> to <code>1</code>:
</p>
<pre>__builtins__.__setattr__(__name__.__iter__().__next__().__add__(__name__.__iter__().__next__()).__add__(__doc__.__reduce_ex__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__sizeof__.__name__.__len__())).__add__(__name__.__iter__().__next__()).__add__(__name__.__iter__().__next__()),__name__.__len__().__bool__().__int__())
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Example_codes">Example codes</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_world.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_world!">Hello, world!</span></h3>
<p><code style="width:950px;display:inline-block;word-wrap: break-word;">
__builtins__.__getattribute__(__doc__.__class__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__le__.__name__.__len__()).__add__(__doc__.__repr__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__name__.__len__().__class__.__name__))(__builtins__.__getattribute__(__name__.__doc__.__getitem__(__name__.__len__()).__add__(__doc__.__hash__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__repr__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())))(__name__.__len__().__mul__(__name__.__len__().__invert__().__neg__())).__add__(__doc__.__str__().__getitem__(__name__.__class__.__name__.__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__bool__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__bool__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__str__().__getitem__(__name__.__len__().__bool__())).__add__(__doc__.__dir__().__str__().__getitem__(__doc__.__sizeof__.__name__.__len__())).__add__(__builtins__.__doc__.__getitem__(__name__.__len__())).__add__(__builtins__.__getattribute__(__name__.__doc__.__getitem__(__name__.__len__()).__add__(__doc__.__hash__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__repr__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())))(__doc__.__setattr__.__name__.__len__().__mul__(__name__.__len__()).__neg__().__invert__())).__add__(__doc__.__str__().__getitem__(__name__.__len__().__bool__())).__add__(__doc__.__repr__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__bool__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__bool__().__str__().__len__())).__add__(__name__.__mod__.__name__.__getitem__(__doc__.__str__().__len__())).__add__(__doc__.__ne__.__doc__.__getitem__(__doc__.__setattr__.__name__.__len__()))) 
</code>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementation">Implementation</span></h2>
<p>The following is a basic implementation of Python is Magic:
</p>
<pre>import re, sys
allowed = r"A-Za-z().,_"
regex = r"(?:__)?([{}]+)(?:__)?".format(allowed)
banned = r"[^{}]".format(allowed)
script = open(sys.argv[1]).read()

if re.findall(banned, script): 
	raise SyntaxError("Only letters, parenthesis, dot and underscore are allowed.")
exec(re.sub(regex,r"__\1__",script))
</pre>
<!-- 
NewPP limit report

Cache expiry: 86400
Reduced expiry: false
Complications: [show‐toc]
CPU time usage: 0.009 seconds
Real time usage: 0.023 seconds

Post‐expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes

Highest expansion depth: 2/100
Expensive parser function count: 0/100
Unstrip recursion depth: 0/20
Unstrip post‐expand size: 0/5000000 bytes
-->
<!--
Transclusion expansion time report (%,ms,calls,template)
100.00%    0.000      1 -total
-->
<!-- Saved in parser cache with key esolang_wiki:pcache:idhash:14484-0!canonical and timestamp 20250724053142 and revision id 152333. Rendering was triggered because: page-view
 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Qdeql</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> devised by <a href="/wiki/Scott_Feeney" title="Scott Feeney">Scott Feeney</a> that provides a single <a href="/wiki/Queue" title="Queue">queue</a> of bytes as the only form of memory available to programs.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Instructions"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Instructions</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Computational_capability"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Computational capability</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Factory"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Factory</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Cell_layout_and_command_translation"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Cell layout and command translation</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#Initial_setup"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Initial setup</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Example_structure"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Example structure</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Instructions">Instructions</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="2">Instruction
</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>=</code>
</td>
<td>NEXT
</td>
<td>Dequeue a byte and enqueue it again
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code>
</td>
<td>DEC
</td>
<td>Dequeue a byte, subtract one (wrapping around), and enqueue it
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>\</code>
</td>
<td>BEGIN
</td>
<td>Dequeue a byte and skip to the instruction after the corresponding END if the byte is zero; otherwise, enqueue the byte again, followed by two zero bytes
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>/</code>
</td>
<td>END
</td>
<td>Go back to the corresponding BEGIN
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&amp;</code>
</td>
<td>INPUT
</td>
<td>Read a byte from stdin and enqueue it (0 for EOF)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>*</code>
</td>
<td>OUTPUT
</td>
<td>Dequeue a byte and write it to stdout
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>If the queue is empty, any instruction that would normally use a value from the queue instead uses 0.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_capability">Computational capability</span></h2>
<p>Qdeql is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a> with a fixed number of unbounded non-negative cells can be reduced to it. (See <a href="/wiki/Collatz_function" title="Collatz function">Collatz function</a> for a proof that 3-cell brainfuck is Turing-complete.) A <a class="external text" href="http://oerjan.nvg.org/esoteric/qdeql/BFQdeql.hs" rel="nofollow">Haskell program</a> is available for performing such a translation, as well as <a class="external text" href="http://oerjan.nvg.org/esoteric/qdeql/gen75" rel="nofollow">some</a> <a class="external text" href="http://oerjan.nvg.org/esoteric/qdeql/genCat" rel="nofollow">translated</a> <a class="external text" href="http://oerjan.nvg.org/esoteric/qdeql/gen75" rel="nofollow">examples</a>.
</p><p>Qdeql was originally thought to be unusable for computation due to the difficulty of accessing a particular byte more than once when the queue is of arbitrary size. However, <a href="/wiki/%C3%98rjan_Johansen" title="Ørjan Johansen">Ørjan Johansen</a> observed that the code <code>\\/\//</code> will skip over (dequeueing and re-enqueueing) an arbitrary length string of <code>nonzero 0 0</code> triples terminated by a <code>0</code>, with the mild inconvenience that the terminating <code>0</code> at the end will be deleted.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Factory">Factory</span></h3>
<p>A fundamental building block in the n-cell brainfuck to Qdeql translation is the "factory" construction of the following table.  It consists of two alternating patterns and a subprogram such that when the subprogram is applied with either pattern at the beginning of the queue, it is deleted while four zeros followed by the other pattern are appended to the queue.
</p><p>An alternative subprogram leaves out the final <code>255 0 0</code> in the resulting pattern, instead absorbing it from whatever is to the pattern's right.
</p><p>With our brainfuck cell representation, the zeros are used to replenish those consumed by other actions, while the absorption feature allows a quicker decrement operation.
</p><p>The factory patterns/programs can conceptually be divided into three subregions:
</p>
<ul><li>The rightmost producer region (which flips between two phases on each cycle) either creates or absorbs value 255 cells, passing them on to</li>
<li>The decrementer region, which gradually decrements non-zero cells, and when they reach 2 passes them on to</li>
<li>The stretcher region, which decrements non-zero cells down to zero, while adjusting the intermediate zero cells so that a total of four zeros are passed on leftward per cycle.  (Four zeros are just enough to allow us to increment a brainfuck cell in a single cycle.)</li></ul>
<table class="wikitable plainpres">
<caption>Factory
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th> 
</th>
<th>Stretcher
</th>
<th>Decrementer
</th>
<th>Producer
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="2">Queue layout
</th>
<td rowspan="2"><pre>1 0 0 0 1 0 0 2 0 0</pre>
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><pre>2 3 0 0 3 4 0 0 ... 254 255 0 0 0</pre>
</td>
<td><pre>255 0 0 255 255 255 0 0 255 0 0 255 0 0 255 0         0</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre>0 255 0 0 255 0 0 255 0 0 255 0 0       255 255 255 0 0</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>Production program
</th>
<td rowspan="2"><pre>- = = = \ / = - = =</pre>
</td>
<td rowspan="2"><pre>\ - \/\/                        /</pre>
</td>
<td><pre>\   = = \           / \/\   / - =   /
  \   = \/\   / - =   \/\/\   / /       \           / \/</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>Absorption program
</th>
<td><pre>\   = = \           / \/=   = = =   \/\/=   /
  \   = \/=   = = =   \/\/=   \/\/      \           / / ===</pre>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cell_layout_and_command_translation">Cell layout and command translation</span></h3>
<p>Once initial setup is finished, the queue consists of the patterns for the brainfuck cells, conceptually arranged in a circle.
</p><p>Each brainfuck cell consists of three regions in order: its factory, its data (encoded as repetitions of <code>255 0 0</code>), and its zero padding.  Occasionally an additional scratch region is temporarily inserted before the data region of the "current" cell.
</p><p>The main part of the Qdeql program consists of a sequence of regional actions: a factory action is followed by a data action, which is followed by a padding action, which is followed by a factory action for the next cell in the queue, etc.  At each point in the Qdeql program we always know the type of region being passed through, as well as the relative position of the current brainfuck cell in the queue.
</p><p>With the exception of <code>&lt;</code> and <code>&gt;</code>, which simply change which relative position in the queue is considered the "current" brainfuck cell, the translation of a brainfuck command consists of a sequence of actions to be applied to particular regions of the current brainfuck cell.  This frequently requires first inserting NOP/default actions to navigate to the current cell and the correct region, and then inserting the substantial action.
</p><p>The NOP/default actions work as follows:
</p>
<ul><li>The data action moves the data section to the end of the queue, except that the final zero is deleted.</li>
<li>The padding action deletes the <code>0 0 0</code> padding.</li>
<li>The factory action replenishes the four zeros deleted by the previous actions, and moves the factory section to the end of the queue.</li></ul>
<p>Sometimes several consecutive brainfuck commands can be translated without navigating the queue between them.  E.g. the actions generated by <code style="white-space:nowrap">-[+&gt;-]+</code> all act on consecutive regions in the queue.
</p><p>The I/O commands are more complicated than the others, as they need to convert between unary representation and bytes (using a temporary scratch region), and so these take more than one regional action to translate.  This is done in order of row, then column/region.
</p>
<table class="wikitable plainpres">
<caption>brainfuck cell
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th> 
</th>
<th>Factory
</th>
<th>Scratch
</th>
<th>Data
</th>
<th>Padding
</th></tr>
<tr>

</th>

</td>
<td> 
</td>
<td><pre>255 0 0 255 0 0 ... 255 0 0 0</pre>
</td>
<td><pre>0 0 0</pre>
</td></tr>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Initial_setup">Initial setup</span></h3>
<p>The following table shows how to build <i>n</i> brainfuck zero cells from a <code>0</code> + 7<i>n</i> times <code>255</code> pattern.
Cells are built "in parallel", sharing the main loop of the first one.
</p><p>After this initial setup the queue will be correctly positioned for a data action.
</p>
<table class="wikitable plainpres">
<caption>Growing cells
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>First cell
</th>
<th>Each additional cell
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre>=\/</pre></td>
<td> 
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre>-\/\/\/=\--=========\/</pre></td>
<td><pre>-\/\/\/=\--=========\/</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre>\-\/\/      \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td>
<td><pre>            \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre> -\/\/      \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td>
<td><pre> -\/\/      \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre>/  -==- -== \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td>
<td><pre>\/ -==- -== \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><pre>==== \/=-== \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td>
<td><pre>==== \/=-== \-\/\// \==\/\/\/-=/ \=\/\/-=\/\/\// \/\/</pre>
</td></tr></tbody></table>

<th><pre>+</pre>
</th>
<td>Production</td>
<td><pre>\\/\//</pre></td>
<td><pre>\/\/\/</pre>
</td>
<td>Production</td>
<td> </td>
<td><pre>\\/\//</pre>
</td>
<th style="text-align:left"><pre>-==</pre>
</th></tr>
<tr>

</th>

</td>

</td>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><table style="float:right;border:1px solid silver;background-color:rgb(249, 249, 249);max-width:256px;padding:5px;">

</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Influenced by</th>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyclic_tag" title="Cyclic tag">Cyclic tag</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a>, <a href="/wiki/G85" title="G85">G85</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queuenanimous" title="Queuenanimous">Queuenanimous</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">File extension(s)</th>
<td><code>.qoob</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p><b>qoob</b> (/kub/ or /qub/, for queue + loop + based) is a <a href="/wiki/Queue" title="Queue">queue</a>-based language with 3 constructs.
</p>
<ul><li><code>0</code> enqueue a zero at the back of the queue</li>
<li><code>1</code> enqueue a one at the back of the queue</li>
<li><code>[...]</code> dequeue a value from the front of the queue
<ul><li>If it is one, then execute the contents before looping back around to dequeue and check again</li>
<li>If it is zero, skip beyond the matching <code>]</code></li></ul></li></ul>
<p>The behavior of dequeueing an empty queue is <a href="/wiki/Undefined_behavior" title="Undefined behavior">undefined</a>. Programs derived from the proof of completeness will never dequeue from an empty queue. A canonical but unnecessary result from dequeueing from an empty queue is to treat the null result as a 0.
</p><p>By convention, non-interactive input is either prepended as 1 and 0 commands before the program, or the queue is initialized with input. Non-interactive output is done by printing the queue when the program halts.
</p><p>All qoob programs are qoobular. Canonical qoob programs consist of only <code>0</code>, <code>1</code>, <code>[</code>, and <code>]</code> and are displayed in a font where 0 is a 180° rotationally symmetric circle or oval with a dot, and 1 is a vertical line (also rotationally symmetric), with [ and ] being self-vertical symmetric, but mutually horizontal and 180° rotationally symmetric. A super qoobular program is a qoob program where its canonical representation is horizontally mirror, vertical mirror, and 180° rotationally symmetric. A simple qoobular program is a non-super qoobular program.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#Super_Qoob"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Super Qoob</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Implementations"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Implementations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>The language is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a> by reduction from <a href="/wiki/Tag_system" title="Tag system">tag systems</a>. There is likely a simpler reduction from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyclic_tag" title="Cyclic tag">cyclic tag</a>.
</p><p>This reduction is based on the observation that 0 at the head of the queue executes a while loop (with no nested statements) no times, and 10 executes it once. From there, it uses the general structure of Cook's proof for the completeness of cyclic tag.
</p><p>To convert an arbitrary 2-tag system with halting symbols and input into the language:
</p>
<ol><li>Assign each of the <i>s</i> many symbols an index <i>i</i>, then replace every symbol with a one-hot vector paired with a halting flag, according to:
<ul><li>Non-halting symbols begin with a 1 (the non-halting flag), then <i>s</i> zeroes, where the <i>i</i>th zero is replaced with 10</li>
<li>Halting symbols are made up of <i>s</i> zeroes</li></ul></li>
<li>Order the productions by the matching/left hand side symbol's index. Discard the left hand side and wrap the production string with square brackets.</li>
<li>Add <i>s</i> many extra empty productions, each given the index <i>s</i>+1, <i>s</i>+2, etc. These are also wrapped.</li>
<li>Place all of the productions in order into an overarching loop.</li>
<li>Put the encoded input at the very beginning.</li></ol>
<p>This scheme produces a qoob program with identical halting conditions as the tag system, assuming the tag system only halts when encountering one of its halting symbols, and never from queue exhaustion.
</p><p>This Python function converts 2-tag systems with halting symbols into equivalent qoob programs. The input program must have all symbols have productions. The productions for the halting symbols of course do not matter since the system will halt immediately upon encountering them.
</p>
<pre>def two_tag_to_qoob(productions, indata, halting=[]):
    # ensure a consistent order, strictly unnecessary
    ordered = list(productions.items())
    # Construct the one-hot vectors
    lookup = {
        s: "1" + "0" * i + "10" + "0" * (len(productions) - i - 1)
        for i, (s, p) in enumerate(ordered)
    }
    # And the halting symbols
    for s in halting:
        lookup[s] = "0" * len(productions)
    lookup = str.maketrans(lookup)
    # Put the input at the start
    program = indata.translate(lookup)
    # Overarching loop
    program += "["
    # Productions
    for s, p in ordered:
        program += "[" + p.translate(lookup) + "]"
    # Empty discard productions
    for s, p in ordered:
        program += "[]"
    program += "]"
    return program

# Example
halt_system = {
    "a": "ccbaH",
    "b": "cca",
    "c": "cc",
    "H": ""
}

print(two_tag_to_qoob(halt_system, "baa", halting=["H"]))
</pre>
<p>An alternate reduction from unbounded <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a> is provided on the page <a href="/wiki/Quinary_Bueue" title="Quinary Bueue">Quinary Bueue</a> which is another name for this language. It is far less efficient, encoding the cells in unary, resulting in exponential slowdown and memory increase.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Super_Qoob">Super Qoob</span></h3>
<p>Any Qoob program can be translated into Super Qoob, making it also Turing complete.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Qoob</th>
<th>Super Qoob
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>0</code></td>
<td><code>000</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>1</code></td>
<td><code>001</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[</code></td>
<td><code>[][][</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>]</code></td>
<td><code>[][]]</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The program is then wrapped in <code>1[...00]</code>, duplicated, and the copy is reversed and appended back onto the program.
Example: <code>1[1]</code> is converted into <code>1[001[][][001[][]]00][00[[][]100][][]100]1</code>
</p><p>Explanation: To avoid any unwanted behavior, the 2nd outermost loop must never run. The bits are padded with 2 <code>0</code>s before them so that the program halts once it reaches the end of the 1st outermost loop (the end of the original Qoob program). The 2 <code>0</code>s in the end of 1st loop ensure that undefined behavior doesn't occur, in case of the program reaching the end with an empty queue.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<p>The following is a qoob to Python transpiler, in Python.
</p>
<pre>def compile(program):
    out = "q = []\n"
    indent = ""
    last = None
    for c in program:
        if c == "0":
            out += indent + "q.append(0)\n"
        elif c == "1":
            out += indent + "q.append(1)\n"
        elif c == "[":
            out += indent + "while q.pop(0):\n"
            indent += " "
        elif c == "]":
            if last == "[":
                out += indent + "pass\n"
            if len(indent) - 1 == -1:
                raise SyntaxError("Unmatched closing bracket")
            indent = " " * (len(indent) - 1)
        last = c
    if indent:
        raise SyntaxError("Unmatched opening bracket")
    return out
</pre>
<p>This <a href="/wiki/META_II" title="META II">META II</a> program compiles qoob programs to a virtual assembly where there are <code>ENQ</code> and <code>DEQ</code> mnemonics. The <code>DEQ</code> instruction dequeues a bit and sets the flags register accordingly.
</p>
<pre>.SYNTAX PROGRAM

PROGRAM = BLOCK .,
BLOCK = $ STMT .,
STMT = ZERO / ONE / LOOP .,
ZERO = '0' .OUT('ENQ 0') .,
ONE = '1' .OUT('ENQ 1') .,
LOOP = '[' .LABEL *1 .OUT('DEQ') .OUT('JZ ' *2) 
     BLOCK
     ']' .OUT('J ' *1) .LABEL *2 .,

.END
</pre>
<p>This META II based implementation compiles qoob to <a href="/wiki/Dequeasm" title="Dequeasm">Dequeasm</a>:
</p>
<pre>.SYNTAX PROGRAM

PROGRAM = BLOCK .OUT('HLT') .,
BLOCK = $ STMT .,
STMT = ZERO / ONE / LOOP .,
ZERO = '0' .OUT('PSH 0') .,
ONE =  '1' .OUT('PSH 1') .,
LOOP = '[' .OUT(*1 ':')
           .OUT('~PSH 1') .OUT('~XOR')
           .OUT('~PSH ' *2) .OUT('~JNZ')
       BLOCK
       ']' .OUT('PSH ' *1) .OUT('JMP')
           .OUT(*2 ':') .,

.END
</pre>
<p>This is a qoob interpreter in Python, where it must compile the program into an intermediate representation before running it, and prints the state of the queue after every instruction:
</p>
<pre>def compile(program):
    stack = [[]]
    i = 0
    for c in program:
        if c == "0":
            stack[-1].append(False)
        elif c == "1":
            stack[-1].append(True)
        elif c == "[":
            stack.append([i])
        elif c == "]":
            if not stack:
                raise SyntaxError("Unmatched closing bracket")
            top = stack.pop()
            back = -(top[0] + 1)
            forward = i + 1
            top[0] = forward
            top.append(back)
            stack[-1].extend(top)
        else:
            i -= 1
        i += 1
    if len(stack) &gt; 1:
        raise SyntaxError("Unmatched opening bracket")
    return stack[0]


def run(compiled, debug=False):
    q = []
    i = 0
    while i &lt; len(compiled):
        c = compiled[i]
        i += 1
        if type(c) is bool:
            q.append(c)
        elif c &gt; 0:
            if not q.pop(0):
                i = c
        elif c &lt; 0:
            if q.pop(0):
                i = abs(c)
        if debug:
            print("".join(map(str, map(int, q))))
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Quinary_Bueue" title="Quinary Bueue">Quinary Bueue</a> which provides an alternate proof based on reduction from <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a>, which results on exponentially more memory and time usage</li></ul>
<!-- 
NewPP limit report

Unstrip post‐expand size: 3304/5000000 bytes
-->

Transclusion expansion time report (%,ms,calls,template)
100.00%    2.119      1 -total
 52.62%    1.115      1 Template:Lowercase
 43.70%    0.926      1 Template:Infobox_proglang
-->
<!-- Saved in parser cache with key esolang_wiki:pcache:idhash:22477-0!canonical and timestamp 20250724234313 and revision id 158592. Rendering was triggered because: page-view
 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Queue based</b> is an esolang by <a href="/wiki/User:ChuckEsoteric08" title="User:ChuckEsoteric08">User:ChuckEsoteric08</a>. The name does not only implies that it stores data in queues but also means that using Queue is based. It's main inspirations were <a href="/wiki/Underload" title="Underload">Underload</a> and <a href="/wiki/Smurf" title="Smurf">Smurf</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Specification">Specification</span></h2>
<p><b>Queue based</b> stores data in two queues. When you go to nonexisting label or try to dequeue if queue is empty program will halt
</p>
<pre>(abc) - enqueue string abc
, - dequeue
@ declare new label
; - switch to diffirent queue
' - dequeue and goto label at index n, where n is length of dequeued element.
/ - enqueue a byte from user input
\ - dequeue and output
[abc_xyz] - this command is core of the language. It replaces every element which is equal to abc with xyz
~ - reverse queue
^ - dequeue and enqueue
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p><b>Queue based</b> is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> because there is (untested) <a href="/wiki/Bitwise_Cyclic_Tag" title="Bitwise Cyclic Tag">Bitwise Cyclic Tag</a> interpreter in it:
</p>
<pre>~@~/[0_..][1_...][$_....]~'@~(..)(.)~'@~(...)(.)~'@~;
~@~/[0_......][1_.......][$_........]~'@~(..)(.)~'@~(...)(.)~'@
[......_............][......_.............];[.._..........][..._...........]~
@[.............._..........][..............._...........]~'
@(..........);,;(.........)~'
@(...........);'
@~(............)~;(.........)~'
@~(.............)~;[.........._..............][..........._...............]'
@~(..............)~(.........);(............);~'
@~(...............)~(.........);(.............);~'
</pre>
<p>This interpreter dosen't use any ^ so this will also prove Turing-completeness even with this restriction. Input should be like that: Program$Data$
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Stack_based" title="Stack based">Stack based</a></li></ul>

Unstrip post‐expand size: 524/5000000 bytes

</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Queuenanimous</b> is an esolang by <a href="/wiki/User:PythonshellDebugwindow" title="User:PythonshellDebugwindow">User:PythonshellDebugwindow</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Memory_model"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Memory model</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Syntax"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Syntax</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Commands"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Commands</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Memory_model">Memory model</span></h2>
<p>Queuenanimous uses an unbounded <a href="/wiki/Queue" title="Queue">queue</a> of unbounded signed integers.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Syntax">Syntax</span></h2>
<p>Like in <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a>, each character of the program represents one command.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commands">Commands</span></h2>
<p>Dequeuing from an empty queue returns zero.
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>Effect
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>0</code></td>
<td>Enqueue zero
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code></td>
<td>Dequeue N, enqueue N + 1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code></td>
<td>Dequeue N, enqueue N - 1
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code></td>
<td>Dequeue N, enqueue N
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[</code>P<code>]</code></td>
<td>While loop: at each iteration, dequeue N, and break if N is zero; else run P and jump back to the start of this loop, dequeue N again, and so on
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class"><a href="/wiki/Computational_class" title="Computational class">Computational class</a></span></h2>
<p>Queuenanimous is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> as 3-cell <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a> can be translated into it (no IO).
</p><p>All programs must begin with <code>000000</code>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>brainfuck</th>
<th>Queuenanimous
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code></td>
<td><code>[+0]+000[+0]&gt;0[+0]&gt;0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code></td>
<td><code>[]</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code></td>
<td><code>[+0]&gt;0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code></td>
<td><code>[+0]&gt;0[+0]&gt;0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[</code></td>
<td><code>[+0[+0]&gt;0[+0]&gt;0[+0]&gt;0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>]</code></td>
<td><code>]&gt;0[+0]&gt;0[+0]&gt;0</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>This translation works by using pairs of integers to represent data as unary integers. Every <code>10</code> pair represents a 1 in unary and every <code>00</code> pair separates the integers from each other.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Queuefuck" title="Queuefuck">Queuefuck</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Qdeql" title="Qdeql">Qdeql</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_resources">External resources</span></h2>
<ul><li>An <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/PythonshellDebugwindow/esolangs/blob/master/queuenanimous/queuenanimous.py" rel="nofollow">interpreter</a> on GitHub</li></ul>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>QX</b> is a minimal language made by <a href="/wiki/User:%E2%86%91" title="User:↑">User:↑</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a class="mw-file-description" href="/wiki/File:QX_logo.png"><img alt="QX logo" class="mw-file-element" decoding="async" height="276" src="/w/images/thumb/6/6f/QX_logo.png/300px-QX_logo.png" srcset="/w/images/thumb/6/6f/QX_logo.png/450px-QX_logo.png 1.5x, /w/images/6/6f/QX_logo.png 2x" width="300"/></a><figcaption>Logo.</figcaption></figure>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Commands"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Commands</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a>
<ul>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#A+B_Problem"><span class="tocnumber">3.2</span> <span class="toctext">A+B Problem</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Lua_interpreter"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Lua interpreter</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commands">Commands</span></h2>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command</th>
<th>What it does
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>Q [a]</td>
<td>Increments the current value at pointer by a. Can decrement if a is negative
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>X [a] [b]</td>
<td>If a &lt;= previous item at pointer then go to previous item at pointer and jump to line b else go to next item at pointer.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>QX is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> by translation from unbounded <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a>.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command
</th>
<th>Translation
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code>
</td>
<td><code>Q 1</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code>
</td>
<td><code>Q -1</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code>
</td>
<td><code>X ∞ 0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code>
</td>
<td><code>X -∞ n</code>, where <code>n</code> is the next command
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[</code> and <code>]</code>
</td>
<td><code>X ∞ 0 X 1 s X -∞ e1 X -∞ e2</code>, where <code>s</code> is after the corresponding <code>[</code>, <code>e1</code> is <code>X -∞ e2</code>, and <code>e2</code> is after the corresponding <code>]</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Note that this assumes infinity is a valid constant. A translation from bounded brainfuck will avoid infinity:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Command
</th>
<th>Translation
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code>
</td>
<td><code>Q 1 X 257 0 X 256 d X 0 n1 X 0 n2 Q -256</code>, where <code>d</code> is <code>Q -256</code>, <code>n1</code> is <code>X 0 n2</code>, and <code>n2</code> is the next command
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code>
</td>
<td><code>Q -1 X 255 0 X 0 n X -1 d1 X -1 d2 Q 256</code>, where <code>n</code> is the next command, <code>d1</code> is <code>X -1 d2</code> and <code>d2</code> is <code>Q 256</code>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code>
</td>
<td><code>X 256 0</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code>
</td>
<td><code>X 0 n</code>, where <code>n</code> is the next command
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[</code> and <code>]</code>
</td>
<td><code>X 256 0 X 1 s X 0 e1 X 0 e2</code>, where <code>s</code> is after the corresponding <code>[</code>, <code>e1</code> is <code>X 0 e2</code>, and <code>e2</code> is after the corresponding <code>]</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>There is also a translation from <a href="/wiki/Brainpocalypse" title="Brainpocalypse">Brainpocalypse</a>:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Brainpocalypse</th>
<th>QX
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code></td>
<td><code>X 0 n</code> where n is next line
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code></td>
<td><code>X ∞ 0</code> where lim is the absolute limit of the numbers
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code></td>
<td><code>Q 1</code>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>-</code></td>
<td><code>X ∞ 0 X 1 d X -1 s X -1 1 Q -1</code>, where line <code>d</code> is <code>Q -1</code> and line <code>s</code> is <code>X -1 1</code>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples">Examples</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infinite_loop"><a href="/wiki/Infinite_loop" title="Infinite loop">Infinite loop</a></span></h3>
<pre>X 0 1
</pre>
<h3><span id="A.2BB_Problem"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="A+B_Problem"><a href="/wiki/A%2BB_Problem" title="A+B Problem">A+B Problem</a></span></h3>
<pre>Q ?
Q ?
</pre>
<p>If A and B must start separate:
</p>
<pre>Q ?
X 1 0
Q ?
X 1 6
X 0 12
Q -1
X 1 0
Q 1
X ∞ 0
X 0 4 
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Lua_interpreter">Lua interpreter</span></h2>
<p>Made by <a href="/wiki/User:Aadenboy" title="User:Aadenboy">User:Aadenboy</a>
</p>
<pre>assert(arg[1], "Argument 1 must be a file to interpret")
local file = io.open(arg[1], "r")
assert(file, "File not found")
local code = file:read("*a")
file:close()

local range = {1, 1}
local mem = {0}
local pointer = 1
local commands = {}
code = code:gsub("∞", "i")
for pos, qx, a, b in code:gmatch("()([QX])%s*([%d%-%?%.i]*)%s*([%d%-%?%.i]*)") do
  a = a == "?" and "?" or (a == "i" and math.huge or (a == "-i" and -math.huge or tonumber(a)))
  b = b == "?" and "?" or (b == "i" and math.huge or (a == "-i" and -math.huge or tonumber(b)))
  local line = ({code:sub(0, pos):gsub("\n", "")})[2] + 1
  local char = #code:sub(0, pos):match("\n?([^\n]+)$")
  assert(a, line..":"..char..": "..qx.." expects at least one integer")
  assert(qx == "Q" or b, line..":"..char..": X expects two integers")
  table.insert(commands, {qx = qx, a = a, b = qx == "X" and b})
end

local i = 1
local steps = 0
repeat
  steps = steps + 1
  local c = commands[i]
  local a = c.a == "?" and (tonumber(io.read()) or 0) or c.a
  local b = c.b == "?" and (tonumber(io.read()) or 0) or c.b
  if c.qx == "Q" then
    i = i + 1
    mem[pointer] = mem[pointer] + a
  else
    local pre = mem[pointer-1] or 0
    pointer = pointer + (a &lt;= pre and -1 or 1)
    mem[pointer] = mem[pointer] or 0
    i = a &lt;= pre and b or i + 1
  end
  range = {math.min(range[1], pointer), math.max(range[2], pointer)}
until i &lt; 1 or i &gt; #commands or steps &gt;= (tonumber(arg[2]) or math.huge)

print(steps.." steps\nPointer at "..pointer.."\nMemory:")
for i=range[1], range[2] do
  print("\t["..i.."]: "..mem[i])
end
</pre>
<!-- 
NewPP limit report
Cached time: 20251206061403
Cache expiry: 86400
Reduced expiry: false

CPU time usage: 0.029 seconds
Real time usage: 0.030 seconds
Preprocessor visited node count: 76/1000000
Post‐expand include size: 155/2097152 bytes

Highest expansion depth: 3/100
Expensive parser function count: 0/100
Unstrip recursion depth: 0/20
Unstrip post‐expand size: 1598/5000000 bytes
-->
<!--
Transclusion expansion time report (%,ms,calls,template)
100.00%    2.180      1 -total
 66.65%    1.453      8 Template:Cd
-->

 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>RAM0</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Category:Computational_models" title="Category:Computational models">computational model</a>, created by Schönhage in <a href="/wiki/Category:Before_1993" title="Category:Before 1993">1990</a>. It's notable for consisting of just a few basic commands that always do the same thing and take no parameters, plus flow control, as is used in many <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming languages</a>. However, its memory storage is based on an addressable RAM, rather than a tape (as is used by many imperative tarpits, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%27%27" title="P''">P''</a>).
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Data_storage"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Data storage</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Commands_and_a_suggested_syntax"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Commands and a suggested syntax</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Implementations"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Implementations</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Data_storage">Data storage</span></h2>
<p>RAM0 has three places in which it can store data: an unbounded RAM (i.e. addressable memory) for which each cell can store unbounded nonnegative integers; and two registers, called <b>n</b> and <b>z</b>, which each store unbounded nonnegative integers. (It's simplest to assume that this memory is initially zero, although the language's computational class does not change even if the program can make no assumptions about the initial memory state.)
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commands_and_a_suggested_syntax">Commands and a suggested syntax</span></h2>
<p>RAM0 has seven commands. Six have a single-letter name (and thus are most naturally represented by that letter in a program):
</p>
<ul><li><code>Z</code>: set <b>z</b> to 0</li>
<li><code>A</code>: increment <b>z</b></li>
<li><code>N</code>: copy <b>z</b> to <b>n</b>, leaving <b>z</b> unchanged</li>
<li><code>C</code>: execute the next command only if <b>z</b> is nonzero</li>
<li><code>L</code>: read memory at address <b>z</b>, storing the result in <b>z</b></li>
<li><code>S</code>: store the value <b>z</b> in memory at address <b>n</b></li></ul>
<p>The remaining command is a "goto" command, like in BASIC; this is the only command that takes an argument. As a computational model, RAM0 is not concerned with how this command is represented syntactically; however, a sensible option is for a decimal number <i>i</i> to represent a goto command that unconditionally jumps to the <i>i</i>th command in the program (using whitespace to separate two consecutive goto commands, and counting the first command as 1).
</p><p>Comments are a detail of syntax irrelevant to computation, and thus do not appear when RAM0 is viewed as a model. Viewed as a language, it seems most consistent with similar esoteric programming languages for RAM0 to ignore anything it doesn't understand, allowing characters other than <code>ZANCLS</code> and digits to be used to write comments.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>It's clear that RAM0's control flow can create an arbitrary state machine (you can use fixed memory addresses as Boolean flags), so the only issue is reading and writing unbounded storage. The simplest way to do this is to use specific pairs of RAM cells as counters, with the difference between them storing the value of the counter; this is obviously trivial to increment and decrement. Testing a counter for zero (i.e. testing the two halves of the counter for equality) is harder, but if you start the cells' values sufficiently high that they do not correspond to any memory address used to store a counter, you can simply write a 0 to the address stored in the first half of the counter, a 1 to the address stored in the second half of the counter, and then read from the address stored in the first half; this will read a 1 only if the two counters are equal (because the second write will have overwritten the first). This can implement a <a href="/wiki/Minsky_machine" title="Minsky machine">Minsky machine</a>, proving the language <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a> (even if the initial contents of memory are unknown).
</p><p>An alternative, and perhaps surprising, way to prove RAM0 Turing complete is to note that it's fairly trivial to compile <a href="/wiki/Three_Star_Programmer" title="Three Star Programmer">Three Star Programmer</a> without I/O into it: a Three Star Programmer command <code><i>i</i></code> translates to the run-length-decoding of <code>Z(A)*<i>i</i>LLNLAS</code>, with a <code>1</code> added at the end of the program (to put it into an infinite loop, matching the infinite loop around the Three Star Programmer program). Along similar lines, the <a href="/wiki/I/D_machine" title="I/D machine">I/D machine</a> can also be directly compiled into RAM0, with <code>I</code> compiling to <code>AS</code> and <code>D</code> compiling to <code>NL</code>.
</p><p>The compilation from the I/D machine does not use the <code>C</code> or <code>Z</code> commands, demonstrating that the language is Turing complete even without control flow or accumulator zeroing. This leads to a tarpit consisting of only <code>ANLS</code> and an implicit infinite loop around the program.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<p>A <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/bangyen/esolangs" rel="nofollow">Python interpreter</a> by <a href="/wiki/User:Bangyen" title="User:Bangyen">User:Bangyen</a>.
</p>

 -->
</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Record</b> (<b>Re</b>gex <b>co</b>ncatenate <b>r</b>ead <b>d</b>isplay) is an esolang invented by <a href="/wiki/User:None1" title="User:None1">User:None1</a>.
</p><p>Although Record is the name of the esolang, which is a <i>noun</i>, it should be pronounced like the English <i>verb</i> <code>record</code>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Memory"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Memory</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#String_and_RegEx"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">String and RegEx</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Commands"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Commands</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Examples"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Examples</span></a>
<ul>
