</div>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><a href="/wiki/Esolang:Featured_languages" title="Esolang:Featured languages"><span class="featured-icon" title="This is a featured language; *click* for more information."></span></a></p><div class="featured-text">
<dl><dd><i>This is a <a href="/wiki/Esolang:Featured_languages" title="Esolang:Featured languages">featured language</a>.</i></dd></dl>
</div>
<p><b>Thue</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> invented by <a href="/wiki/John_Colagioia" title="John Colagioia">John Colagioia</a> in 2000.  It is a <a href="/wiki/Matrioshka_language" title="Matrioshka language">matrioshka language</a> based on nondeterministic <a href="/wiki/String" title="String">string</a> <a href="/wiki/Rewriting" title="Rewriting">rewriting</a> which the author describes as a constraint-programming version of a <a href="/wiki/Turing_tarpit" title="Turing tarpit">Turing tarpit</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Computational_model"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Computational model</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Etymology"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Etymology</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Language_description"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Language description</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#Edge_cases"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">Edge cases</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Input_and_output"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Input and output</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Criticisms"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Criticisms</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#Sample_programs"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Sample programs</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_model">Computational model</span></h2>
<p>Thue is based on a <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/semi-Thue_grammar" title="wikipedia:semi-Thue grammar">semi-Thue grammar</a>, which is a generalized form of <i>Thue system</i> in which each association between a pair of strings is only one-way.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The language is presumably named after either Norwegian mathematician Axel Thue, or the grammar which bears his name (which the language employs).
</p><p>It is worth noting that while the mathematician's name is pronounced approximately "TOO-eh", the associated documentation explicitly gives the pronounciation of the name of the language as "TOO-ay".
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_description">Language description</span></h2>
<p>Each Thue program consists of two parts: a list of substitution rules of the form
</p>
<pre><i>&lt;original string&gt;</i>::=<i>&lt;replacement string&gt;</i>
</pre>
<p>which is terminated with a line having both <i>&lt;original string&gt;</i> and <i>&lt;replacement string&gt;</i> either empty, or consisting entirely of whitespace:
</p>
<pre>::=
</pre>
<p>followed by a string representing the initial program state, which may extend over multiple lines.
</p><p>Execution consists of picking, from the list of rules, an arbitrary rule whose original string exists as a substring somewhere in the program state, and replacing that substring by the rule's replacement string.  This process repeats until there are no rules that can be applied, at which point, the program ends.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Edge_cases">Edge cases</span></h3>
<p>The case where a substitution rule has nothing but whitespace or an empty string on its left-hand side, but something other than whitespace or an empty string on its right-hand side, is not defined.  Some implementations consider this to be a syntax error, while others (including the original interpreter) consider it to terminate the list of rules, just as a rule with whitespace on both sides of the ::=  would.
</p><p>It is also possible (and arguably reasonable) for an implementation to interpret it as a rule which rewrites the given whitespace (or zero-length string) to the right-hand side, when applied.  However, no such implementations have been brought to the attention of this article.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Input_and_output">Input and output</span></h2>
<p>Input is performed using a special rule like this:
</p>
<pre><i>&lt;original string&gt;</i>::=:::
</pre>
<p>When triggered, instead of replacing the original string with the string <code>:::</code> it will be replaced with one line from the input stream.
</p><p>Similarly, output is triggered by a line containing a rule like this:
</p>
<pre><i>&lt;original string&gt;</i>::=~<i>&lt;string to output&gt;</i>
</pre>
<p>When triggered, the original string is deleted (i.e. replaced by the null string) and the string to the right of the <code>~</code> character is sent to the output stream.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticisms">Criticisms</span></h3>
<p>Laurent Vogel complains that handling of newlines is not well defined in the specifications and proposes the following convention: when a string is sent to the output stream, no newline is printed at the end, except if the string is empty, in which case a newline is all that is printed.
</p><p>Ørjan Johansen complains that input is a lousy hack that has no way of handling arbitrary strings (think <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/code_injection" title="wikipedia:code injection">Wikipedia:code injection</a> here) and no well-defined behavior on end of file.  This makes an otherwise powerful language useless for implementing I/O-supporting programs properly in.
</p><p>Chris Pressey complains that the spec does not agree with the reference implementation on the matter of input.  The spec defines <code>:::</code> and <code>~</code> as "strings" or "symbols" which "trigger implicit rules", while the implementation treats them as special rule forms.  This leaves open questions such as whether a Thue program with no rules, but with initial data containing <code>:::</code>, is intended to replace that string with user input.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sample_programs">Sample programs</span></h2>
<p>Here's the traditional "Hello World!" in Thue:
</p>
<pre>a::=~Hello World!
::=
a
</pre>
<p><br/>
The following Thue program performs an increment of a binary number entered as the initial state surrounded by "_" characters, in this case the number 1111111111:
</p>
<pre>1_::=1++
0_::=1

01++::=10
11++::=1++0

_0::=_
_1++::=10

::=

_1111111111_
</pre>
<p><br/>
The following sample program is to demonstrate Thue's nondeterminism (and to show an example of an infinite loop, besides). The program outputs bits in an undefined (and quite possibly random) sequence.
</p>
<pre>b::=~0
b::=~1
ac::=abc
::=
abc
</pre>
<p>The following program is a typical truth machine:
</p>
<pre>*::=:::
1::=1_
_::=~1
0::=~0
::=
*
</pre>
<p>The following program shows the fallacy of attributing to Thue the same behavior as <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_algorithm" title="wikipedia:Markov algorithm">Markov algorithms</a>. It is supposed to convert a group of * to Roman numerals and it does work correctly as a Markov algorithm. However, due to Thue's non-determinism, it does <b>not</b> work on Thue (<a href="/wiki/Talk:Thue" title="Talk:Thue">Talk:Thue</a>):
</p>
<pre>*::=I
IIIII::=V
IIII::=IV
VV::=X
VIV::=IX
XXXXX::=L
XXXX::=XL
LL::=C
LXL::=XC
CCCCC::=D
CCCC::=CD
DD::=M
DCD::=CM
::=
******************
</pre>
<p>This program is an <a href="/wiki/InterpretMe" title="InterpretMe">InterpretMe</a> interpreter:
</p>
<pre>*::=:::
::=
*
</pre>
<p>The following program is a multiplier and multiplies 3x7. The result is on the state string.
</p>
<pre>(*::=a(
*)::=)b
(x)::=
ab::=ba*
*b::=b*
a*::=*a
{b::={
a}::=}
*}::=}*
{}::=
::=
{(***x*******)}
</pre>
<p>This program converts the input unary numbers into decimal numbers and prints the result:
</p>
<pre>&gt;**********::=*&gt;
&gt;_::=&lt;_0
&gt;*_::=&lt;_1
&gt;**_::=&lt;_2
&gt;***_::=&lt;_3
&gt;****_::=&lt;_4
&gt;*****_::=&lt;_5
&gt;******_::=&lt;_6
&gt;*******_::=&lt;_7
&gt;********_::=&lt;_8
&gt;*********_::=&lt;_9
*&lt;::=&lt;*
_&lt;*::=_&gt;*
_&lt;_::=o
l0::=~0
l1::=~1
l2::=~2
l3::=~3
l4::=~4
l5::=~5
l6::=~6
l7::=~7
l8::=~8
l9::=~9
o0::=ol0
o1::=ol1
o2::=ol2
o3::=ol3
o4::=ol4
o5::=ol5
o6::=ol6
o7::=ol7
o8::=ol8
o9::=ol9
i::=:::
::=
_&gt;i_

</pre>
<p>This program generates <a href="/wiki/Kolakoski_sequence" title="Kolakoski sequence">Kolakoski sequence</a> and prints it:
</p>
<pre>[1&gt;]1::=1[1&gt;]
[1&gt;]2::=2[1&gt;]
[1&gt;]*1::=[&lt;1]1*[a1&gt;]
[1&gt;]*2::=[&lt;1]2*[a1&gt;][a1&gt;]

(1)::=~1
(2)::=~2

1[&lt;1]::=[&lt;1]1
2[&lt;1]::=[&lt;1]2
&gt;[&lt;1]1::=1&gt;[2&gt;](1)
&gt;[&lt;1]2::=2&gt;[2&gt;](2)

[a1&gt;]1::=1[a1&gt;]
[a1&gt;]2::=2[a1&gt;]
[a1&gt;]|::=1|

[2&gt;]1::=1[2&gt;]
[2&gt;]2::=2[2&gt;]
[2&gt;]*1::=[&lt;2]1*[a2&gt;]
[2&gt;]*2::=[&lt;2]2*[a2&gt;][a2&gt;]

1[&lt;2]::=[&lt;2]1
2[&lt;2]::=[&lt;2]2
&gt;[&lt;2]1::=1&gt;[1&gt;](1)
&gt;[&lt;2]2::=2&gt;[1&gt;](2)

[a2&gt;]1::=1[a2&gt;]
[a2&gt;]2::=2[a2&gt;]
[a2&gt;]|::=2|

::=

|&gt;[1&gt;]12*2|

</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>By showing that there is a <a href="/wiki/Computational_class#Reduction" title="Computational class">reduction</a> to Thue from Type-0 languages in the Chomsky hierarchy (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unrestricted_grammar" title="Unrestricted grammar">unrestricted grammars</a>), which are computationally equivalent to <a href="/wiki/Turing_machine" title="Turing machine">Turing machines</a>, we can show that Thue is <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a>.
</p><p>Let some arbitrary set of non-zero-length potential substrings of the Thue state be called the nonterminals; the only restriction on these is that they don't show up in the final state of the program.  All other substrings are terminals.
</p><p>Both sides of every Thue substitution rule thus contain an arbitrary combination of terminals and nonterminals.  Each Thue substitution rule is in this way equivalent to a production in an unrestricted grammar, and the Thue program is equivalent to the grammar itself.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

<li><a href="/wiki/Thupit" title="Thupit">Thupit</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Whenever" title="Whenever">Whenever</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki////" title="///">///</a></li></ul>

<li><a class="external text" href="https://jsfiddle.net/mvhst5ae/" rel="nofollow">Thue interpreter in Javascript</a></li>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Tip</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> created by <a href="/wiki/User:Ais523" title="User:Ais523">User:ais523</a> in <a href="/wiki/Category:2018" title="Category:2018">2018</a>, as a minimization of iterated <a href="/wiki/Collatz_function" title="Collatz function">Collatz functions</a> (which were already pretty minimal to start with!). It allows for <i>very</i> terse implementations in many languages which have primitives for handling rational numbers. The name is an acronym for "times instruction pointer".
</p><p>As the language is intended as a target language for interpreter <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a>, it has no fixed syntax (interpreters are expected to use whatever encoding of the program is most convenient, which probably will not even be a sequence of bytes, and as such Tip programs cannot be stored in a file without an additional encoding step). However, it is likely to be trivial to convert between the syntaxes required by various interpreters. (As such, the language falls into a similar category as languages like Algol, which also just defined a list of syntactic elements the language needed and left it up to the various implementations as to how to spell them.)
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Specification"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Specification</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Relationships_to_other_languages_/_language_families"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Relationships to other languages / language families</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Variations"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Variations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Example"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Example</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Implementations"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Implementations</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7"><a href="#Perl"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Perl</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Specification">Specification</span></h2>
<p>A Tip program consists of a list of commands, plus an initial value for the instruction pointer (which must be a positive integer). There are two commands that can appear within the command list; goto commands and the halt command (which ends the program). A goto command takes a positive rational number as its argument, and is written simply by writing the argument in question in whatever syntax the implementation requires. (As a special case, using 0 or 1 as a goto command argument is syntactically invalid; this enables implementations to allow either of these values to be used as a special case for representing the halt command without making the implementation nonportable to Tip programs intended for other interpreters. Interpreters need not be able to diagnose this particular syntax error, or indeed any form of syntax error.) A halt command will also typically be represented as a number, but the choice of number will depend on what is most convenient for the implementation; however, it must be something that's invalid as a goto command argument (i.e. 0, 1, a negative number, an infinite number, an irrational number, or an imaginary/complex number), thus ensuring that it can always be distinguished from a goto command.
</p><p>Unusually, the program is seen not as a finite entity, but as covering the entirety of an infinite memory space; the program is conceptually repeated an infinite number of times to create an infinitely long program (in practice, implementations will instead use only one copy of the program and perform a modulo operation on the instruction pointer, thus saving the need to make an infinite number of copies before starting).
</p><p>The instruction pointer starts with the initial value specified by the program. (Depending on the implementation, the language might be 0-indexed or 1-indexed, i.e. command 1 might be the second or first command of the program; it's trivial to convert programs between these two language dialects by moving the first command to the end or vice versa.) When executed, a goto command multiplies the instruction pointer by its argument, i.e. it can be seen as <code>goto *(ip * a);</code> or as <code>ip *= a;</code>; there's no implicit increment of the IP (i.e. whichever line the goto command goes to, that's the line which will execute next). The halt command halts the program when executed. The language has no RAM or other similar mutable addressable memory; the only data used are the program (which never changes) and the instruction pointer (which is just a number).
</p><p>Allowing the instruction pointer to become anything other than an integer is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a>. (In order to prevent such undefined behaviour occurring, a Tip programmer can ensure that the denominator of each goto instruction divides into both its location within the program and the number of commands in the program, thus ensuring that whichever copy of the instruction is run, the IP will be divisible by the instruction's denominator and thus the result of the multiplication will be an integer.)
</p>
<h2><span id="Relationships_to_other_languages_.2F_language_families"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationships_to_other_languages_/_language_families">Relationships to other languages / language families</span></h2>
<p>Tip is almost an <a href="/wiki/OISC" title="OISC">OISC</a>. It can be seen as an OISC either via treating the "halt argument" as a special case, by using 0 as a halt argument and "memory-mapping" halt behaviour, or by using an imaginary number as the halt argument to effectively move the IP "outside the bounds of the program"; even though the program is being treated as infinite, it's only infinite along a single line in the complex plane.
</p><p>Tip is also a special case of a <a href="/wiki/Collatz_function" title="Collatz function">Collatz function</a> (specifically, the special case where all <code><i>s</i><sub>i</sub></code> are 0); halting behaviour for Collatz functions is normally defined as entering a trivial infinite loop, in which case either 0 or 1 works as a halt instruction.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Tip is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a>, which can be seen via implementing a <a href="/wiki/Minsky_machine" title="Minsky machine">Minsky machine</a> with two counters. We use a construction in which the Minsky machine commands can be an increment of either counter, an unconditional decrement of either counter (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Undefined_behaviour" title="Undefined behaviour">undefined behaviour</a> upon an attempt to decrement zero), or a zero-test (which goes to one of two states depending on whether a particular counter is zero).
</p><p>Let <i>p</i> be a prime number that's a) at least 7, b) at least 2 more than the number of states of the Minsky machine. (Each state of the Minsky machine, including the halt state, is given an arbitrary number from 2 to <i>p</i>-1 inclusive.) Let <i>x</i> equal 2<sup><i>p</i>-1</sup>, and <i>y</i> equal 5<sup><i>p</i>-1</sup>; and define <i>F</i>(<i>s</i>, <i>t</i>) as the set of positive integers which are equal to 1 mod 10 and to <i>t</i>÷<i>s</i> mod <i>p</i> (where the division symbol refers to finite field division mod <i>p</i>); by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, such a set exists and has infinitely many elements, because <i>p</i> and 10 are coprime. Let <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>, <i>t</i>) be the smallest element of <i>F</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>).
</p><p>At any given point in the program's execution (after the first Tip command has run), our invariant is that the Tip instruction pointer will equal <i>x</i> to the power of the first counter, times <i>y</i> to the power of the second counter, times an element of <i>F</i>(1, <i>t</i>) (where <i>t</i> is the number of the Minsky machine's current state).
</p><p>The compiled Tip program consists of 10<i>p</i> instructions, with initial instruction pointer value 1, and the instruction in position <i>n</i> of the Tip program is determined as follows:
</p>
<ul><li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is 0, the instruction is irrelevant (this construction never allows the instruction pointer to divide <i>p</i>).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is 1, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>x</i> to the power of the first counter, times <i>y</i> to the power of the second counter, times <i>f</i>(1, <i>t</i>) (where <i>t</i> is the Minsky machine's initial state). This obviously means that at the start of the program (where the IP has value 1), the simulated Minsky machine will be initialised appropriately.</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of the Minsky machine's halt state, the instruction is a halt instruction.</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that increments the first counter, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>xf</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>) (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that increments the second counter, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>yf</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>) (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that decrements the first counter, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>)/<i>x</i> (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that decrements the second counter, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>)/<i>y</i> (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that zero-tests the first counter, and <i>n</i> mod 2 is nonzero, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>) (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it when the first counter is zero).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that zero-tests the first counter, and <i>n</i> mod 2 is 0, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>) (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it when the first counter is positive).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that zero-tests the second counter, and <i>n</i> mod 5 is nonzero, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>) (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it when the second counter is zero).</li>
<li>If <i>n</i> mod <i>p</i> is the number of a state that zero-tests the second counter, and <i>n</i> mod 5 is 0, the instruction is a goto instruction, and its argument is <i>f</i>(<i>s</i>,<i>t</i>) (where <i>s</i> is the number of the state being compiled, and <i>t</i> is the number of the state that follows it when the first second is positive).</li></ul>
<p>It can be seen that, given our invariant for how the Tip IP and Minsky machine memory state relate, each Tip instruction will have exactly the same effect as the corresponding Minsky machine instruction. (By Fermat's Little Theorem, <i>x</i> and <i>y</i> both equal 1 mod <i>p</i>, and all <i>f</i> values are 1 mod 10, so multiplying or dividing by <i>x</i> or <i>y</i> won't change the value of the instruction pointer mod <i>p</i>, and multiplying by an <i>f</i> value won't change number of multiples of 2 or 5 that exist within the instruction pointer, and so we can treat the "two parts" of the IP's state independently.)
</p><p>Note that more efficient constructions are available: for example, it's possible to inline a whole sequence of increments and decrements into a single Tip instruction. However, the simple construction above is enough to demonstrate the computational class of the language.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Variations">Variations</span></h2>
<p>Although Tip is defined in terms of rational numbers, it's still Turing-complete if restricted to (bignum) decimal fixed-point numbers with sufficiently many decimal places; in the construction above, all the goto commands used are terminating decimals. It is not Turing-complete when using (binary) floating-point for the instruction pointer rather than an integer; even allowing for a bignum exponent, it becomes a one-counter machine, as only finitely many mantissas exist, and for any given mantissa, there's no way to distinguish more than finitely many values for the exponent via which command is running. (This in turn means that in most languages, it's difficult to accept the program as floating point, as the instruction will typically be "promoted" to floating point as a consequence.)
</p><p>It's fairly simple to add batch I/O to the language. One simple construction that fits into the spirit of the rest of the language is to start at minus the IP's stated initial value, and to negate it (i.e. multiplying by -1) after a number of commands have run equal to the input (which must be a positive integer); and when the program halts, to output the number of times copies of the same command were run in a row immediately before halting (this will also be a positive integer); when input is not in use, this is equivalent to an (otherwise invalid) input of 0 (i.e. the IP gets negated twice before the program even runs).
</p><p>The requirement to allow programs to specify the initial instruction pointer is not necessary (and is added only because taking it from input is often terser than requiring it to be hardcoded); always starting the instruction pointer at 1 is still sufficient for Turing-completeness, as shown by the construction above.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Example">Example</span></h2>
<p>Here's a simple program to double a number (it doubles 4 when I/O is not used, or the input when I/O is used):
</p>
<ul><li>Initial IP: 1</li>
<li>Commands: [1/4, 196608, 16, <i>halt</i>, 3, 16]</li></ul>
<p>and here are debug traces, produced using the Perl implementation below:
</p>
<dl><dt>With no I/O</dt>
<dd><pre>Initial IP: 1
Program: [1/4 196608 16 0 3 16]
IP 1: running command: 196608 (index 1 of program)
IP 196608: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 49152: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 12288: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 3072: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 768: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 192: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 48: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 12: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 3: running command: 0 (index 3 of program)
</pre></dd>
<dt>Doubling 5</dt>
<dd><pre>Initial IP: 1
Program: [1/4 196608 16 0 3 16]
IP -1: running command: 16 (index 5 of program)
IP -16: running command: 16 (index 2 of program)
IP -256: running command: 16 (index 2 of program)
IP -4096: running command: 16 (index 2 of program)
IP -65536: running command: 16 (index 2 of program)
IP 1048576: running command: 3 (index 4 of program)
IP 3145728: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 786432: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 196608: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 49152: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 12288: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 3072: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 768: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 192: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 48: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 12: running command: 1/4 (index 0 of program)
IP 3: running command: 0 (index 3 of program)
10
</pre></dd></dl>
<p>The program works by using the exponent of 4 to store the number being doubled, and the value of the instruction pointer mod 3 as a state machine.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Implementations">Implementations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Perl">Perl</span></h3>
<p>Here's an implementation in Perl, which sends copious debug output to stderr, and takes input from stdin but will run the program without input if given an empty file on stdin. It uses 0-indexing for the program, places the initial IP before the program, and represents halt as 0.
</p>
<pre>use warnings;
use strict;
use Math::BigRat;

my $ip = Math::BigRat-&gt;new(scalar &lt;&gt;);
my @program;
while (defined ($_ = &lt;&gt;)) {
    if (/H/) {
        push @program, 0;
    } else {
        push @program, Math::BigRat-&gt;new($_);
    }
}

print STDERR "Initial IP: $ip\n";
print STDERR "Program: [@program]\n";

my $input = &lt;&gt;;
my $inputdefined = defined $input;
my $lastci = .5;
my $output = 0;

while ($ip) {
    my $eip = $input ? -$ip : $ip;
    $eip &lt; 0 and $input--;
    my $ci = $eip % @program;
    $ci &lt; 0 and $ci += @program;
    my $cmd = $program[$ci]-&gt;copy();
    print STDERR "IP $eip: running command: $cmd (index $ci of program)\n";
    $ip-&gt;bmul($cmd);

    if ($ci == $lastci) {
        $output++;
    } elsif ($ip) {
        $output = 1;
        $lastci = $ci;
    }
}

$inputdefined and print "$output\n";
</pre>

<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Major implementations</th>
<td><a class="external autonumber" href="https://github.com/aadenboy/Trampolines" rel="nofollow">[1]</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Influenced by</th>
<td><a href="/wiki/Befunge" title="Befunge">Befunge</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">Influenced</th>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ball_Pit" title="Ball Pit">Ball Pit</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align: left;vertical-align: top;">File extension(s)</th>
<td><code>.tramp</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p><b>Trampolines</b> is a physics-based <a href="/wiki/Category:Two-dimensional_languages" title="Category:Two-dimensional languages">two-dimensional</a> <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> made by <a href="/wiki/User:Aadenboy" title="User:Aadenboy">User:Aadenboy</a>. The program is ran with a single "marble", directed through the "course" with a set of pre-defined physics. See below for info on the physics.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>

<ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_Overview">Language Overview</span></h2>
<p><i>This language was last updated on May 16th, 2024 (10:48 AM GMT-8)</i>
</p><p>A Trampolines program must be formatted correctly in order to run.
</p>
<ol><li>The left side of each line must contain the <code>|</code> trampoline.</li>
<li>The right side of each line must contain the <code>#</code> command.</li>
<li>The script must contain one <code>o</code> command.</li>
<li>Each line is uniform in length. <i>(Note: trailing spaces are not allowed.)</i></li></ol>
<p>Each step the marble gains 0.5 vertical velocity. Do note that a positive vertical velocity is used to descend, and the opposite for ascending.
</p><p>The horizontal and vertical velocity is rounded <u>away</u> from zero, and then is used to set the new position of the marble.
</p><p>The symbol that is on the marble after the marble is repositioned is then ran.
</p><p><br/>
</p><p>Trampolines and pipes are <b>not</b> commands, and are instead used to redirect the marble.
</p>
<pre>| - \ /
</pre>
<p>These are trampolines. <code>|</code> and <code>-</code> invert the marble's horizontal and vertical velocity respectively.
<code>\</code> sets the marble's horizontal and vertical velocity to (1, -1) if it is being approached from either the top or the right. The opposite is true (-1, 1) from the bottom and left.
<code>/</code> is similar to <code>\</code>, only that the new values are (-1, -1) from top and left, and (1, 1) from bottom and right.
</p>
<pre>H =
</pre>
<p>These are pipes. The <code>H</code> pipe will set the marble's horizontal velocity to 0, effectively nullifying any horizontal velocity it previously had. If vertical velocity is zero, it will default to a vertical velocity of -1. The <code>=</code> pipe acts similarly, but nullifies the vertical velocity rather than horizontal velocity, and will set the horizontal velocity to 1 if it was 0 before.
</p><p>Trampolines uses three stacks, with a stack pointer to pick which stack to manipulate.
An error will occur if there is nothing left to pop from the stack, i.e when running <code>~</code> on an empty stack, or running <code>+</code> on a stack with only one value.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>CMD
</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&lt;</code>
</td>
<td>Check the last two values of the selected stack, if A &lt; B, allow the marble to pass, otherwise, act as a `-` trampoline.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&gt;</code>
</td>
<td>Check the last two values of the selected stack, if A &gt; B, allow the marble to pass, otherwise, act as a `-` trampoline.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>0-9</code>
</td>
<td>Push the corresponding number onto the selected stack.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>^</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, discarding the value.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>~</code>
</td>
<td>Duplicate the last item on the selected stack.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>?</code>
</td>
<td>Push a random float from 0.000-1.000 to the selected stack.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>$</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, and push the result of rounding it.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>(</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, and push the result of flooring it.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>)</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, and push the result of ceiling it.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>*</code>
</td>
<td>Pop two values from the selected stack, A and B, and push the result of A * B.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>%</code>
</td>
<td>Pop two values from the selected stack, A and B, and push the result of A % B.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>+</code>
</td>
<td>Pop two values from the selected stack, A and B, and push the result of A + B.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>:</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, and write it's corresponding UTF8 character.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>;</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, and write it.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>!</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, and push it's negative counterpart.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>'</code>
</td>
<td>Pop the last value from the selected stack, then push it's reciprocal (1/x).
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>,</code>
</td>
<td>When stack 1 is selected, push the user's input as a number.<br/>When stack 2 is selected, push the user's input as it's UTF8 value (base 10).<br/>When stack 3 is selected, push the user's input as it's individual UTF8 values to the stack in reverse order.<hr/>You can optionally place a string to the right of the command to have a custom prompt message. By default, it says <code>AWAITING NUMBER INPUT: </code>, <code>AWAITING CHAR INPUT: </code> and <code>AWAITING INPUT: </code>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>_</code>
</td>
<td>Swap the last two items on the selected stack.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>@</code>
</td>
<td>Pop two values from the selected stack, A and B, and push the result of concatenating B to A.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>&amp;</code>
</td>
<td>Pop two values from the selected stack, A and B, and push the result of the left-half of splitting A at B. (e.g if A was 182 and B was 2, the value 18 would be pushed)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>#</code>
</td>
<td>End the program.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>[</code>
</td>
<td>Move the last item from the selected stack to the previous stack. (stack 3 precedes stack 1)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>]</code>
</td>
<td>Move the last item from the selected stack to the next stack. (stack 1 follows stack 3)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>{</code>
</td>
<td>Select the previous stack. (stack 3 precedes stack 1)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>}</code>
</td>
<td>Select the next stack. (stack 1 follows stack 3)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>"</code>
</td>
<td>Declares a string, assuming it is closed.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>.</code>
</td>
<td>Writes any string that exists to the immediate right. If there is none, write a newline.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><code>`</code>
</td>
<td>Declares a comment, assuming it is closed.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Example_Programs">Example Programs</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infinite_Loop"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infinite_Loop" title="Infinite Loop">Infinite Loop</a></span></h3>
<pre>|o#
| #
| #
|-#
</pre>
<pre>| o      #
|        #
|        #
| \    / #
</pre>
<pre>|o\#
|\ #
</pre>
<h3><span id="Hello_World.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello_World!"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hello_World!" title="Hello World!">Hello World!</a></span></h3>
<pre>|o              #
|."Hello World!"#
|#              #
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="FizzBuzz"><a href="/wiki/FizzBuzz" title="FizzBuzz">FizzBuzz</a></span></h3>
<pre>|                      \#
| H====================H#
|            -         H#
|o.          H         H#
|1  15   0  ."FizzBuzz"H#
|=H~  @ %  &gt;           H#
| \    -    |          H#
| H=========           H#
| H                    H#
| ^ 3%   H             H#
| ^~  0 ."Fizz"        H#
| \    &gt;               H#
|       |              H#
| H=====               H#
| H                    H#
| ^ 5%   H             H#
| ^~  0 ."Buzz"        H#
| \    &gt;               H#
|       |              H#
| H===== H=======/     H#
| ^      ^             H#
| ^      ^             H#
| ~                    H#
| ;                    H#
| H========/  =========H#
| H +1   0H # H        -#
| H1  0 @ @&gt; ^-         #
| \    -  \ -           #
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Truth_Machine"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Truth_Machine" title="Truth Machine">Truth Machine</a></span></h3>
<pre>|o   /   #
|,   ~;  #
|0   H==H#
|=  ^-  /#
|  &lt;     #
|   ;    #
|    #####
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat_Program"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cat_Program" title="Cat Program">Cat Program</a></span></h3>
<pre>|o          #
|{          #
|1          #
|!    \     #
|,H===H     #
|=H   H     #
| 1 ^:H     #
| !&gt;  H     #
| \ # -     #
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="99_bottles_of_beer"><a href="/wiki/99_bottles_of_beer" title="99 bottles of beer">99 bottles of beer</a></span></h3>
<pre>|oH=                                   #
|9. .                                  #
|9  =/                                 #
|@  ." bottles of beer on the wall."   #
|=H H ;~                               #
| ~  -  +                              #
| ;     =/                             #
| ." bottles of beer on the wall,"     #
| .     H                              #
| ~     H                              #
| ;    \=                              #
| ." bottles of beer."                 #
| .      =/                            #
| ."Take one down, pass it around,"    #
| .   1! H                             #
| =3 ^  -                              #
|   &lt;                                  #
|    H                                 #
|    ."1 bottle of beer on the wall."  #
|    .                                 #
|    .                                 #
|    ."1 bottle of beer on the wall,"  #
|    .                                 #
|    ."1 bottle of beer."              #
|    .                                 #
|    ."Take one down, pass it around," #
|    .                                 #
|    ."No bottles of beer on the wall."#
|    #                                 #
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Exponent_Calculator">Exponent Calculator</span></h3>
<p><i>Note: This example does not support non-integer exponents.</i>
</p>
<pre>|o                                  #
|,"Value: "                         #
|.                                  #
|$                                  #
|,"Exponent: "                      #
|.                                  #
|$ =H."Result: 1"                   #
|0&lt;    #                            #
|\ &gt;                                #
|                                   #
|   HH                              #
|   H^                }^            #
|   H[                  {           #
|   H]H==================/          #
|   H1  ~[   {1   H =H==}           #
|   H=H}  { *  ! +0&lt;    H."Result: "#
|   H \    -    - \ &gt;   H ;         #
|   H                ====/ #        #
|   H                               #
|   ^                }^             #
|   [                  {            #
|   ]H==================/           #
|   1  ~[   *{   H =H==}            #
|   =H}  { '  1 +0&lt;    H."Result: " #
|    \    -    - \ &gt;   H ;          #
|                   ====/ #         #
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Deadfish_Implementation"><a href="/wiki/Deadfish" title="Deadfish">Deadfish</a> Implementation</span></h3>
<pre>|              \  #
| H============H  #
| ^            H  #
| ^            H  #
| }            H  #
| 1  H^^       H  #
| !&lt;    0      H  #
| \ &gt;    H     H  #
| H==H   H     H  #
| ^  /   H     H  #
| 2      H     H  #
| 5      H     H  #
| @      H     H  #
| 6  H^^ H     H  #
|o@&lt;    0H     H  #
|0\ &gt;    H     H  #
|{H==H   H     H  #
|1^  /   H     H  #
|!H======H     H  #
|,{      /     H  #
|=H            H  #
| 1 ^          H  #
| !&gt;  H        H  #
| \ #          H  #
|     1        H  #
|     0        H  #
|     @        H  #
|     5  H}1   H  #
|     @&lt;    +  H  #
|     \ &gt;    { H  #
|     H==H    -H  #
|     ^  /     H  #
|     1        H  #
|     0        H  #
|     @        H\ #
|     0  H}1   HH #
|     @&lt;    !  -H #
|     \ &gt;    +  H #
|     H==H    { H #
|     ^  /     -H #
|     1        /H #
|     1        HH #
|     @        H- #
|     5  H}~   H  #
|     @&lt;    *  H  #
|     \ &gt;    { H  #
|     H==H    -H  #
|     ^  /     H  #
|     1        H  #
|     1        H  #
|     @        H  #
|     1  H}~   H  #
|     @&lt;    ;  H  #
|     \ &gt;    { H  #
|     H==H    -H  #
|     ^  /     H  #
|     1        H  #
|     0        H  #
|     @        H  #
|     4  H#    H  #
|     @&lt;       H  #
|     \ &gt;      H  #
|     H==H     H  #
|     ~  /     H  #
|     H========H  #
|     \        -  #
</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Interpreters">Interpreters</span></h2>
<p>- <a class="external text" href="https://github.com/aadenboy/Trampolines" rel="nofollow">Lua Interpreter</a>
</p>

<div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" dir="ltr" lang="en"><p><b>Trianguish</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Esoteric_programming_language" title="Esoteric programming language">esoteric programming language</a> created by Radvylf in <a href="/wiki/Category:2022" title="Category:2022">2022</a>. It is almost a <a href="/wiki/Cellular_automaton" title="Cellular automaton">cellular automaton</a>, but has additional features such as I/O support and random number generation.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Specification"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Specification</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Computational_class"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Computational class</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_resources"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External resources</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Specification">Specification</span></h2>
<p>Trianguish programs exist on an infinite triangular tiling (although all but finitely many cells of the grid are blank); the triangles are equilateral, and oriented so that one of the sides is horizontal. Each cell of the grid, known as an "op", stores two pieces of information: the "pin value", which is either an integer from 0 to 215 inclusive or the special value NIL; and the "ID", which specifies one of 16 different commands, and also which side each of that command's arguments ("pins") are connected to. (Commands can therefore exist in 1, 3 or 6 different orientations, depending on how symmetrical they are with respect to their pins.)
</p><p>Execution consists of alternating between two operations forever (or until the program enters a tight infinite loop, defined as a state in which no input or output occurs and no changes to ops' values or IDs occur:
</p>
<ul><li>Pin value updates: each op's pin value is updated based primarily on the pin values that adjacent ops had on the previous cycle;</li>
<li>Building: if there are any active builders on the grid, they change the ID of adjacent ops (making Trianguish a self-modifying language). In the reference implementation, building on an op also changes its pin value to NIL, but this may be a bug rather than an official part of the language.</li></ul>
<p>For most commands, an op with that command will have one or more sides designated as output pins. It is impossible to read a op's pin value except through its output pins. When an op is said to "read via" a particular pin, it means that its behaviour is based on the pin value of the op that's adjacent on the side of that pin (all commands run simultaneously, so it sees the value of that op before the current cycle's updates); or if that op does not have an output pin on its side adjacent to this op, this op behaves as though it read NIL instead (because it cannot read the pin value in this situation).
</p><p>Trianguish is represented graphically; a command is drawn as three colored lines connecting the centre of the op to the midpoints of its edges. A command is defined by which colors of lines exist (and its orientation by which color connects to which edge); sometimes more than one command uses the same set of colors, in which case a character is placed on the op to disambiguate (or in the case of builders, a line between two of the pins). Here are the commands:
</p>
<dl><dt>No-op (A=gray, B=gray, C=gray) [0]</dt>
<dd>This command always has a pin value of NIL (although it has no output pins, so this value cannot be read anyway).</dd>
<dt>Zero (A=blue, B=blue, C=blue with <code>0</code>) [18]</dt>
<dd>This command has three output pins, and always has the pin value 0.</dd>
<dt>One (A=blue, B=blue, C=blue with <code>1</code>) [24]</dt>
<dd>This command has three output pins, and always has the pin value 1.</dd>
<dt>Minus one (A=blue, B=blue, C=blue with <code>-</code>) [30]</dt>
<dd>This command has three output pins, and always has the pin value 215/-1 (pin values are calculated modulo 216, so these are equivalent).</dd>
<dt>Wire (A=green, B=gray, C=blue) [36]</dt>
<dd>This command changes its pin value to match a value read from the green pin. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>Split wire (A=green, B=blue, C=blue) [54]</dt>
<dd>This command changes its pin value to match a value read from the green pin. Both blue pins are output pins.</dd>
<dt>Logical AND (A=green, B=purple, C=blue with <code>T</code>) [72]</dt>
<dd>This command reads a value through the green and purple pins; if either is NIL, its pin value becomes NIL, else it changes to match the value read via the green pin. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>Logical OR (A=green, B=purple, C=blue with <code>S</code>) [90]</dt>
<dd>This command reads a value through the green and purple pins; it changes to match the value read via the green pin if that is not NIL, or via the purple pin if that is not NIL, or otherwise becomes NIL. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>Excluding wire (A=green, B=purple, C=blue with <code>N</code>) [108]</dt>
<dd>This command reads a value through the green and purple pins; it changes to match the value read via the green pin unless the purple pin has the same value, in which case it becomes NIL. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>Adder (A=green, B=green, C=blue with <code>+</code>) [126]</dt>
<dd>This command adds the values read through the green pins (mod 216), and changes its value to match, or to NIL if either of them were NIL. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>Multiplier (A=green, B=green, C=blue with <code>×</code>) [144]</dt>
<dd>This command multiplies the values read through the green pins, and changes its value to match, or to NIL if either of them were NIL. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>Comparator (A=green, B=purple, C=blue with <code>C</code>) [162]</dt>
<dd>This command subtracts the value read through the purple pin from the value read through the green pin, and changes its value to match the sign of the result (215/-1 if negative, 0 if zero, 1 if positive). The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>I/O command (A=green, B=purple, C=blue with <code>I</code>) [180]</dt>
<dd>This command outputs any non-NIL value read through the green pin. If the purple pin is non-NIL, it reads a value from input and changes its pin value to match; otherwise, its pin value becomes NIL. The blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dt>I-Builder (A=brown, B=green, C=blue, line connecting brown to green) [198]</dt>
<dd>During value calculation, this command changes its pin value to match a value read from the green pin, and the blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dd>During building, this command changes the ID of the op connected via the green pin based on the builder's pin value, unless the builder's pin value is NIL.</dd>
<dt>O-Builder (A=brown, B=blue, C=green, line connecting brown to blue) [204]</dt>
<dd>During value calculation, this command changes its pin value to match a value read from the green pin, and the blue pin is an output pin.</dd>
<dd>During building, this command changes the ID of the op connected via the blue pin based on the builder's pin value, unless the builder's pin value is NIL.</dd>
<dt>S-Builder (A=brown, B=gray, C=blue, line connecting brown to gray) [210]</dt>
<dd>During value calculation, this command changes its pin value to match the ID (not value) of the op connected via the gray pin.</dd>
<dd>During building, this command changes the ID of the op connected via the gray pin based on the builder's pin value, unless the builder's pin value is NIL.</dd></dl>
<p>Builders can translate between pin values and commands (because they change a pin value based on an ID or vice versa). Thinking of the three sides of a triangular op as being in the directions <code>/</code>, <code>-</code> and <code>\</code> (regardless of whether the triangle is pointing up or down), it is possible to calculate an orientation value from 0 to 5 based on how the pins of the op match the pin colors in the order listed above:
</p>
<pre>  / | \ orientation of the pin from the centre to the side of the triangle
  \ - / orientation of the triangle side itself
0 A B C
1 C B A
2 B C A
3 B A C
4 C A B
5 A C B
</pre>
<p>The translation between an ID and pin value is then done by adding a number representing the command (listed above) to the number representing its orientation. Some commands are symmetrical, but seem to internally have an orientation anyway, meaning that, e.g., the ID for a "zero" command could be 18, but could also be, e.g., 22 (depending on which of the three blue wires is considered to be which).
</p><p>Building nonexistent commands is allowed (and their IDs can be read back as a pin value via using an S-builder, round-tripping correctly). With default settings, the reference interpreter defines their behaviour by repeatedly subtracting 6 from the ID until a valid command is reached, and then behaving like that command.
</p><p>In most cases, commands are defined in such a way that the order in which they run within a cycle is irrelevant. There are two exceptions: I/O commands (which order do they output / input in?) and builders (if two builders build on the same cell, which one wins?). The language is defined to randomize in this situation, although the reference interpreter has some options to change this behaviour.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Trianguish is pretty powerful in terms of what it can do with finite amounts of memory. For example, arbitrary constants can be produced by adding lots of ones together. As long as you don't mind a potentially large delay between the input and the output, it is possible to implement an arbitrary function from non-NIL values to values including NIL (with NIL mapping to NIL) in a range of different ways (a very inefficient but simple method is to use split wires to make a number of copies of the input equal to the number of input values that produce non-NIL outputs, use excluding wires to exclude 215 of the 216 possibilities from each wire so that each possible input value goes down a different wire, then use an adder to adjust each value to the desired output, using logical ORs to ensure that all the resulting values end up back in the same place). It is also possible to use circuitously routed wires to delay a signal by any sufficiently large even number of cycles. (Using wires, the delay must be even because the pin values move between an upwards- and downwards-pointing triangle, or vice versa, on very cycle. As it happens, odd delays are also possible via using S-builders, but this is not required for the computational class proof.)
</p><p>By using multiple such functions, and combining the output with a logical OR, it is possible to create a function which, when it receives a non-NIL input, will produce a specified sequence of outputs, in a particular order, and with full control over the timing of each output modulo 6 (except that the parity of timing of each output depends on that of the input, but you can still choose 0/2/4 modulo 6 freely). In order to construct a <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> language from this, it would be sufficient to have a set of six unbounded stacks, that work along the following principle: there is one input wire shared among all the stacks; the values of the stacks do not change as long as that input is NIL; for most non-NIL inputs, sending that input along the input wire pushes it onto one of the stacks (chosen based on the timing of the input modulo 6); for one specific non-NIL input (e.g. 215), sending that input along the input wire instead pops one of the stacks (again, chosen based on the timing of the input modulo 6); there is an output wire that can be used to read the popped values. This is enough power to implement <a href="/wiki/Esimpl" title="Esimpl">Esimpl</a>, without pushback instructions, with 3 stacks, and with a maximum of 215 stanzas (which is easily enough for Esimpl to be Turing-complete, e.g. <a href="/wiki/UT19" title="UT19">UT19</a> uses fewer resources than this when compiled into Esimpl): the idea is to arrange the program something like this:
</p>
<pre>  /------------&gt;-- stack input (push/pop commands)
  |
 ROM
  ^
split--&lt;--\
  v       |
 ROM      |
  |       |
  \--&gt;--adder--&lt;-- stack output (popped value)
</pre>
<p>in which the top ROM, upon receiving a stanza number, sends the sequence of push commands and the "pop" half of a pop-goto command to the stack input, and the bottom ROM, upon receiving a stanza number, sends the "goto" half of a pop-goto command towards the adder, so that it arrives at the same moment that the value popped from the stack does (and thus adds to the popped value in order to produce the number of the new stanza, as Esimpl requires). A goto command (as opposed to pop-goto) can be implemented by pushing 0 onto an arbitrarily chosen stack, and then doing a pop-goto on that stack.
</p><p><a class="external text" href="https://radvylf.github.io/trianguish/#BIP~v-4OLl6DRCBGfkshDrDECRotQUDTqQwORcYKVz5zo5YhT8LpVHa2rWLflb77Doczp2r4C8eEefxH_-0A7yan9Ee7F.UfvOYkZKIFwh0PpSwNn.izBIjJwur7FvJnJOH3m.WBPN5IzWGDmztySZ_E4jxTPicVcqP~ux3YmLHCeP3Gwx8q1KhQj5y5kZlaM_tbx1ukuE_8GQh9UErceec9HGUXcnw2z0z_HHNk86Ptz_X~knV9E8CotKwxkwwXTdcX~9FAsli-mqZMOruqk_tYQ7pmRfk3~R40CuThoYJAj-o5LaNjXcxQpd4Jtc~5XIpJlcmUu3.1.KOuIyL~ROCuDzf7NgCJzxmhGGbc8id.~P9i_bItd_fJOjiQ90ADfr6f3hV3-_mLexnoYOwD~GGJqZ.KULxCuMggjQ9u.EOzl_Y0MGJKWf~oirOldyXw-AQDmkjjmbdZXlMCy.1HEBGYTvt9nr-f.v2rBVIz22_e2IuuIP0FPUx2iEjwEZiyyNuumtlYPcxtgTum~40zpq1hu0p8n1UUMFfqnAyyvIaqhWlH.nPMuffM5efuPxAcLDbzAJYJ_pS5Z56cfh-O9SyERcLfAAytM6ch0B5upxEGrtxSseDalhV2XszT_Ru1Y1ZgBrUpS9NtCfxKE8495h~Z.HStxlTyCTDVDPV_yj3b.90wvzpI-_CtBh-hfY2x6yzkQ6GnzSGiITV0cU1R_-TwZ7wdwQ3bsadvtK9tFE.9-WIhZ-i~vig4s7K.sY8mWpttBfWYS75Dv7X-rnZF3StrH.kRLasJdjkPO_cfxW_k3jsJxYdiRVzF1arnBaUuxq2Cxk8ZdZeS8W6VCVK1vRNZOnIb2-iduMRKA2jMTnRwN7lmi0Tpow.sAlecJhCNVWtopm-zZGBKDnK1rf6yrnEjhaT0cd756F1N-yW6VObOiBirzDCxExgBgmbt2TA0wLl0-nG9zPBsR1ub5mkki1Kq7X0KBkTgzrd6iLYtFGYrhly-f6sN5.ZmDPsvkMsJk_PFntOD2f45x03M51Gq~TIAjq2LX0snqgz13e~FsjizcyKj.RP_p60-S7~iB5FtkHIDtQtVlrJnTYA6ddUHSrvJxh_7UcbvT63jEkvDr_1mmNphSG.TrhnIotr7GOhP.0DPd5x.Y6pqu_FtUHCuw~M1J8tD~3UvfK4vm.KrxrD0LahXYKrAcNp_eT_HNauUBdPUv2rDKeevTvuthFHABgkEKLC7~8K1VQVyL_egFnE8v_~epep3uJFKG4MdYaf83IAr9F4ZJK2~5XoGN1KtYVGKVrNDqn0woYH0ckqKWv_SHnVWgI9pYtUkY11kByOgt5upV5ps2xikB-hqjaGR0SV~pWRs8J8iGI6wJIEeGyAiToaPJJwGrJUDC2.sNMYgwsC9cyNAKqSR_qZlX~fZ7jveWKIyDWxZQQ_E_OgfxK.PjGJyFpLgRbIE-mTZp4pRwjH..ouH0B5P9hfFW22n5iLz8-.~RR9oKb.6B.aDSjnd9OAJzzlSrTt9VIa~c263gPC0FYvgqcS3sv281c3Fts0TKNl-JsiSGe52w3OYrSt8FPdwP5dd0PpnViW~QD8Mj-FCTQf~_ysDmFysB7q1r.FwNp3k51VmttBHy17KAmoDVgRWN3T7ipOW20OgbExqbzIjQklyVTeuEFY400F.PP4A2JmEtBPFOF5kiXVAjOo-zZEPdCgAvqfF_H5BZ1ikJqeCunBbXCquBP.PZae7LIdwdILmFxoqqb8-loZs-mR4L.ACvjESPADCiZu1l49Yn42Xyv1htusfP1Tv-~E0dvHv~1lN02EsrWN3jEbdU3G6lby96BoCifkkBnxnwQEU41Zk-y7kB-wuav9Uwuk3jY.SwhnlIYRyi~p8V0M9hPRB.lJ3m1izUDKKgzg861gW_Os.tl5InGmxBjDzxH8QZgNWoSxXVPuKb3RP rel="nofollow">Here's an example of how the infinite stacks can be implemented.</a> The top part of the linked program is a finite section of a repeating pattern; this finite section implements six stacks that use the communication protocol listed above (using 215 as a "pop" command), but can each store only finitely many elements (in this case, four of them). Extending the pattern by adding additional copies would increase the number of elements that can be stored.
</p><p>The idea behind the construction of the stacks is that the data is stored in the hexagons in the middle of the pattern: the six ops that make up the hexagons each store the value of one stack, with the top of the stack being on the left. When a value to be pushed onto the stack is received from the input, it is used to replace the appropriate value in the leftmost hexagon via being sent through the "strong" (green) side of a logical OR; it also passes along the wire at the top of the construction, activating the logical ANDs for one cycle each and allowing one non-NIL value to pass through (the value from the appropriate stack), which then arrives on the strong side of a logical OR and replaces the appropriate value in each non-leftmost hexagon with the correct value from the hexagon to its left. Because the paths between the hexagons are more circuitous than the path along the top, these paths will be storing the value from before the push (rather than afterwards), so each of the new values is based on the old value of the hexagon on the left, rather than the new value, simulating a stack push.
</p><p>Pops work in much the same way; the difference is that, due to the arrangement of comparators and excluding wires, a value of 215 will be sent along the bottom rather than the top. This causes the values to move to the left in exactly the same way as a push moves them to the right (the bottom-most value on the stack becomes duplicated, but Esimpl programs can be and usually are written so that the stacks never empty, causing this duplication to be unobservable). In order to implement reading of the popped value, the value of the top of the stack is constantly output on the output wire; when using the Esimpl construction above, this will only actually be read when a table number is sent towards the adder (otherwise, the adder's left input is NIL and thus its right input won't matter). "Pop and read the popped value" is thus implemented by reading the popped value <i>before</i> popping it.
</p><p><a class="external text" href="https://radvylf.github.io/trianguish/#Ej0fPe8xTGnSgxkukvbAKA8EHXa8XqVO_DjyKWbdIPaDY9CxQyu9cjjmvL8VNeqeGQFXvKxTrSwAi0WTZa-sxqb_0FbsHhOthe_y1dj0leaYqDvlJ_kxLRuBSQ9E8Meh-dt9..i3E5l5VIqSse7YXA4Yj7~Ii-GAARRE2JJaqmZge0ZAOYFtRCrTef_OB5mVw_IzBNiNy81FjbW-x2LxLbG35kBhezdN7KJJsMY7XkYrGpLZa7nO8juI9a.EhxMgL-Jfz-y9hwU97FHT2WJWzaR4u4o1yHGjHBK-YzbY-VG9TaKIY-nQ~.QVD0piLvoDMgiwziD746gF_GlfE7N-pn.2~T0TcyVUfeWy303Tzqp2nge-blIs1j7Tm9p6tjtiMF6Yt9US0f.2P779Rr0M4FrwsReDdYtCGg4BaDxzKKdJQVz1MfzcOmwckmjRMjx45KE76.E9tI2sa9sd.vmvyOsFxcLYw.MVGdl0Wzs_Ntdl0s8XrXe1gCZUcqVYYl9xZ4gHtRFbyoyloQvFUNMfGsY7XTYsxjzLFmHzXDErTxr5sMkUj._a1Szto4ZsG~9irbGwD_7VCMJscB" rel="nofollow">Here's a demonstration of the stacks in action.</a>
</p><p>The bottom part of the linked program shows how to cause the stack to grow during runtime (and you can run that program to actually see how the stack grows). For demonstration purposes, this uses an I/O command to read a long sequence of IDs-converted-to-pin-values from the input; however, a full construction would generate this sequence arithmetically, place it into a very large loop of wire, and have the sequence repeat forever (rather than the two repeats used in the demonstration). The sequence is used to power a "universal constructor" that can build arbitrary Esimpl code. The universal constructor consists of two parts: a wire that goes to the right and stores the sequence (sent at the rate of 1 per 3 cycles), at the top of the bottom part; and an I-builder that alternately builds either a wire or a builder on the cell at the end of the wire. This makes it possible to build something on the next op along, then provide input to that op, then replace that op with something else, provide input to the replacement, etc.. This makes it possible to build anything using the following mutually recursive algorithm: to build on a given op, build a builder on the previous op, then build a wire up to that builder, then send a value along that wire to tell the builder to build.; and to build a wire up to a given op, build a wire on the op before, then build a wire up to the newly built wire. (This algorithm is exponentially slow – there ways to speed it up a little, but the linked program is nonetheless still pretty slow to build.)
</p><p>The linked construction takes a constant (although fairly large) amount of time to build one new repeat of the pattern that makes up the stack. In order to do this, it needs to both build the stack pattern itself, and also to build a new universal constructor further to the right. The only part of the construction that is not straightforward is to cause a "changeover" in which one universal constructor stops alternating between its two states, and just becomes a wire permanently, whereas the newly built universal constructor starts to run (rather than being an inert object, like it is during building). In the linked construction, this is achieved using an I-builder, which makes it possible for the old constructor to build a wire up to the builder of the new constructor and send data through it (I-builders act like wires when they aren't building). The data sent through the I-builder is connected to another builder, which builds a wire from the old constructor to the new one and causes the new one to "power up", getting data inside its hexagon and causing it to start building (which overwrites the wire that went into the I-builder with the alternating pattern of "builder that builds to the right" and "wire that sends to the right" that allows the universal constructor to work). At the bottom of each universal constructor is a builder that runs unconditionally as long as the universal constructor is running, and which builds a break in the hexagon of the constructor to the left, causing it to stop; thus, once the new constructor has non-NIL values in its hexagon, it will break the constructor to the left and cause it to stop building, so that the wire at the point of its I-builder can permanently be a wire (which is necessary to be able to send data to the new constructor).
</p><p>This is therefore sufficient to prove Trianguish to be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turing_complete" title="Turing complete">Turing complete</a>; you can use very long wires in the Esimpl-interpreter part of the program to ensure that it runs sufficiently slowly that the stacks will always have time to grow before they fill, in order to get an implementation of Esimpl that has unbounded stacks, and sufficiently many stacks and stanzas to be Turing-complete.
</p>

<p><b>Trigbf</b> is an esolang invented by <a href="/wiki/User:None1" title="User:None1">User:None1</a>, inspired by <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck</a>.
</p><p>Trigbf is also known as Trigbf7, you'll know why in the Dialects section.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Memory">Memory</span></h2>
<p>Trigbf uses an unbounded (in both directions) tape which contains signed unbounded infinite-precision real numbers. Initially, every cell is zero.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commands">Commands</span></h2>
<p>Trigbf has these commands:
</p>
<ul><li><code>,.&gt;&lt;[]</code>: The same as bf, except <code>.</code>, which rounds before printing as ASCII.</li>
<li><code>s</code>: Let current cell value be <code>x</code>. <code>x</code> becomes <code>sin(x rad)</code> after the command.</li>
<li><code>c</code>: Let current cell value be <code>x</code>. <code>x</code> becomes <code>cos(x rad)</code> after the command.</li>
<li><code>t</code>: Let current cell value be <code>x</code>. <code>x</code> becomes <code>tan(x rad)</code> after the command. It is <a href="/wiki/Undefined_behavior" title="Undefined behavior">undefined behavior</a> to run this command when current cell is an invalid value for tangent (e.g.: pi/2).</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Dialects">Dialects</span></h2>
<p>Trigbf has 8 dialects: Trigbf0 to Trigbf7. After converting the dialect number (0~7) to a big-endian binary number, the 1st, 2nd and 3rd digits decide whether the <code>s</code>, <code>c</code> and <code>t</code> commands are available: 0 if unavailable, 1 if available. The original Trigbf has all three commands, so it's also known as Trigbf7.
</p>
<h2><span id="Examples_.28In_Trigbf7.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Examples_(In_Trigbf7)">Examples (In Trigbf7)</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cat"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cat" title="Cat">Cat</a></span></h3>
<pre>c[,.]
</pre>
<p>or:
</p>
<pre>,[.,]
</pre>
<h3><span id="Hello.2C_world.21"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hello,_world!"><a href="/wiki/Hello,_world!" title="Hello, world!">Hello, world!</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">cttctttccttscttsttsttttstttsttcttttstttttcscttsttttscttscttstttscttstttcttsttstttsttttcttsttscttsttttcstttscsttttcttstttcttttttttsctttttsttstttsttccttcttttscttstttscttscttstctttsttscttsccttsttstttscttsttcttscttstttcttssttsttctttstttttccttsttttcttttcctttccttcttsttsctttsttsttsttctttt.&gt;.&gt;.&gt;cttctttctcttsttsttscttcttstttstttsttttcttttstttctttcttcscttsttscsttttcttsttcttccttccttsttstttcttsctttstttcctttttsttt.&gt;.&gt;cttctttccttsscttstttsttcttstttctttcctttsctttttttcttcttcttttsttsttstttcttscttscttccttttstttsttstttscttstttststtsctttctsttstttcttttttccttctt.&gt;ctstttttctctttctttsttscttsttsttstcctcctststststststststststststttttstt.&gt;.&gt;.&gt;.&gt;.&gt;.&gt;.</pre>
<p>Wonder how this HUGE program was generated? In fact, I (None1) wrote a weird greedy+randomization algorithm to generate constants:
</p>
<pre>from math import *
from random import *
def gen(x,lim): # x is the value to generate, lim is the maximum code length x是要生成的数，lim是最大代码长度
    r=''
    k=0.0
    for i in range(lim):
        dst=[abs(sin(k)-x),abs(cos(k)-x),abs(tan(k)-x),abs(tan(k)-x),abs(tan(k)-x)] # Add more tan's to let the code choose tan more when ramdomizing 增加更多tan使代码随机化时更多地选择tan
        z=min(dst) # Choose the best solution first 先选择最优解
        if randint(1,10)==1:
            z=choice(dst) # 1/10 probability to give up best solution and pick a random solution 1/10的概率放弃最优解并选择随机解
        if z==dst[0]:
            r+='s'
            k=sin(k)
        elif z==dst[1]:
            r+='c'
            k=cos(k)
        else:
            r+='t'
            k=tan(k)
        if z&lt;=0.5:
            print('Found') # 找到了
            return r
    print('Failed') # 没找到
    return r
r=''
for i in b'Hello, world!':
    print(f'Generating character: {i}')
    res=gen(i,1001)
    while len(res)==1001: # run gen() unless it succeeds 只要失败就一直跑，直到成功
        res=gen(i,1001)
    r+='&gt;'+res+'.'
print(r)
</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nope."><a href="/wiki/Nope." title="Nope.">Nope.</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">.&gt;.&gt;cttctttccttsscttstttsttcttsttttttscttsttsttsttscttcttsttscttsttsttscttsctttstttscttstttsttccttscttctccttcttscttcttctttcctttctttcttstcctttcttttttttsttstttccttsttsttscttcscttstttcttcctttsttscttttscttscttsctttcttsttttttcttccccttsttt.&gt;.&gt;cttctttcscttsctttscttstttctttcttsctcttsccttsttsttsttstttscttsttscttscttstttctcttscttttcttccttttcttsttscttttsttctttctttcttscttsttstttsttstttcttcttttttscttcctttcctccttctttsttsttcttsscttscttstttcttscttctttscttsttsctttcttccttsttsttttsttccttccttsttscttsttttsttsctt.</pre>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="XKCD_Random_Number"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/XKCD_Random_Number" title="XKCD Random Number">XKCD Random Number</a></span></h3>
<pre class="rectwrap">.</pre>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_class">Computational class</span></h2>
<p>Dialects without the <code>c</code> command are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FSA" title="FSA">FSAs</a> because they can't do anything to the tape, making the tape useless.
</p><p>Dialects with the <code>c</code> command are <a href="/wiki/Turing-complete" title="Turing-complete">Turing-complete</a> because <a href="/wiki/Brainfuck#Computational_class" title="Brainfuck">brainfuck is Turing-complete even if only changing 0s into 1s is allowed</a>.
</p>
<h2><span id="Interpreter_.28Trigbf7_dialect.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Interpreter_(Trigbf7_dialect)">Interpreter (Trigbf7 dialect)</span></h2>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Python" title="Python">Python</a>:
</p>
<pre>import sys
from math import *
def tbf(code):
    s=[]
    matches={}
    tape=[0.0]*2000000
    for i,j in enumerate(code):
        if j=='[':
            s.append(i)
        if j==']':
            m=s.pop()
            matches[m]=i
            matches[i]=m
    cp=0
    p=1000000
    while cp&lt;len(code):
        if code[cp]=='s':
            tape[p]=sin(tape[p])
        if code[cp]=='c':
            tape[p]=cos(tape[p])
        if code[cp]=='t':
            tape[p]=tan(tape[p])
        if code[cp]==',':
            c=sys.stdin.read(1)
            tape[p]=(ord(c) if c else 0)%256
        if code[cp]=='.':
            print(chr(int(round(tape[p],0))),end='')
        if code[cp]=='&lt;':
            p-=1
        if code[cp]=='&gt;':
            p+=1
        if code[cp]=='[':
            if not tape[p]:
                cp=matches[cp]
        if code[cp]==']':
            if tape[p]:
                cp=matches[cp]
        cp+=1
tbf(sys.stdin.read())
</pre>
